Text

THE light was fading among [the Derbyshire hills]288-the derbyshire hills . The trees , now almost bare , were stirred by the fretful wind into what seemed like a passionate wail for [their]289-their own lost loveliness , and on [the wide bare stretch of moorland behind [the house]291-the house]290-the wide bare stretch of moorland behind the house the strange weird cry of the plovers sounded like a dirge over the dead summer . The sharp , intermittent rain had beaten all the beauty out of the few late autumn flowers in [the garden]292-the garden , and it was tender of the twilight to hasten to deepen into a darkness heavy enough to hide such a grey desolate picture . Inside [Thornsett Edge]1-thornsett edge another and a deeper darkness was falling . [Old Richard Ferrier]104-richard was sick unto death , and [he]104-richard alone of all [the household]293-the household knew it . [He]104-richard knew it , and [he]104-richard was not sorry . Yet [he]104-richard sighed . ' What is it , [Richard]104-richard ? Can [I]104-richard get [you]104-richard anything ? '[104-richard] [A woman sitting behind [his]104-richard bed - curtain]294-a woman sitting behind his bed - curtain leaned forward to put the question — [a faded woman , with grey curls and a face marked with deep care lines]295-a faded woman , with grey curls and a face marked with deep care lines . It was [[his]104-richard sister]296-his sister . ' Where are [the boys]2863-the boys ? '[296-his sister] ' Gone to [Aspinshaw]105-aspinshaw . '[294-a woman sitting behind his bed - curtain] ' [Both of [them]2863-the boys]2864-both of them ? '[294-a woman sitting behind his bed - curtain] ' Yes ; [I]297-the old man asked [Dick]106-dick to take a note for [me]297-the old man , and [Roland]107-roland said [he]106-dick 'd go too . '[297-the old man] [The old man]297-the old man looked pleased . ' Did [you]297-the old man want either of [them]2863-the boys ? '[294-a woman sitting behind his bed - curtain] [she]294-a woman sitting behind his bed - curtain asked . ' [I]294-a woman sitting behind his bed - curtain want [them]2863-the boys both when [they]2863-the boys come in . '[294-a woman sitting behind his bed - curtain] ' Suppose [you]297-the old man are asleep ? '[294-a woman sitting behind his bed - curtain] ' [I]297-the old man shall not sleep until [I]297-the old man have seen [[my]297-the old man sons]2865-my sons . '[297-the old man] ' Art [thee]297-the old man better to - night , [Richard]104-richard ? '[294-a woman sitting behind his bed - curtain] [she]294-a woman sitting behind his bed - curtain asked in a tone of tender solicitude , dropping back , as [people]298-people so often do in moments of anxiety , into the soft sing - song accent that had once been habitual to [her]294-a woman sitting behind his bed - curtain . ' Ay , [I]297-the old man 'm[297-the old man] better , [lass]299-lass , ' [he]297-the old man said , returning the pressure of the hand [she]294-a woman sitting behind his bed - curtain laid on [his]297-the old man . '[299-lass] Wilt have a light ? ' '[297-the old man] Not yet a - bit , ' [he]297-the old man answered . '[297-the old man] [I]0-i like to lie so , and watch the day right out , ' and [he]297-the old man turned [his]297-the old man face towards the square of grey sky framed by the window . There was hardly more pleasantness left in [his]297-the old man life than in [the dreary rain - washed garden outside]2866-the dreary rain - washed garden outside . And yet [his]297-the old man life had not been without its triumphs — as [the world]2867-the world counts success . [He]297-the old man had , when still young , married [the woman [he]297-the old man passionately loved]2868-the woman he passionately loved , and work for [her]294-a woman sitting behind his bed - curtain sake had seemed so easy that [he]297-the old man had risen from poverty to competence , and from competence to wealth . Born in [the poorest ranks of [the workers]2870-the workers in [a crowded Stockport alley]2871-a crowded stockport alley]2869-the poorest ranks of the workers in a crowded stockport alley , [he]297-the old man had started in life as a mill '[0-i] hand , ' and [he]297-the old man was ending [it]2872-it now [a millowner]2873-a millowner , and master of many hands . [He]297-the old man had [himself]297-the old man been taught in no school but that of life ; but [he]297-the old man did not attribute [his]297-the old man own success to [his]297-the old man education any more than [he]297-the old man did the fatuous failure of [some University men]2874-some university men to [their]2874-some university men peculiar training ; so [he]297-the old man had sent [[his]297-the old man sons]2875-his sons to [Cambridge]2-cambridge , and had lived to see [them]2875-his sons leave [[their]2875-his sons college]2876-their college well - grown and handsome , with not more than the average stock of prejudices and follies , and fit to be compared , not unfavourably , with [any young men in [the county]2878-the county]2877-any young men in the county . But by some fatality [he]297-the old man had never tasted the full sweetness of any of the fruit [his]297-the old man life - tree had borne [him]297-the old man . [[His]297-the old man parents]2879-his parents had died in want and misery at a time when [he]297-the old man [himself]297-the old man was too poor to help [them]2879-his parents . [[His]297-the old man wife , who had bravely shared [his]297-the old man earlier struggles]2880-his wife , who had bravely shared his earlier struggles , did not live to share [their]2879-his parents reward . [She]2880-his wife , who had bravely shared his earlier struggles patiently bore the trials of [their]2879-his parents early married life , but in the comfort that was to follow [she]2880-his wife , who had bravely shared his earlier struggles had no part . [She]2880-his wife , who had bravely shared his earlier struggles died , and left [him]297-the old man almost broken - hearted . [Her]2880-his wife , who had bravely shared his earlier struggles memory would always be the dearest thing in [the world]2867-the world to [him]297-the old man ; but [a man]2882-a man 's warm , living , beating heart needs something more than a memory to lavish its love upon . This something more [he]297-the old man found in [[her]2880-his wife , who had bravely shared his earlier struggles children]2883-her children . In [them]2883-her children all [his]297-the old man hopes had been centred ; for [them]2883-her children all [his]297-the old man efforts had been made . [They]2883-her children were , individually , all that [he]297-the old man had dreamed [they]2883-her children might be , and [they]2883-her children were both devoted to [him]297-the old man ; and yet , as [he]297-the old man lay on [his]297-the old man deathbed , [his]297-the old man mind was ill at ease about [them]2883-her children . Did [he]297-the old man exaggerate ? Was it weakness and illness , the beginning of the end , that had made [him]297-the old man think , through these last few weeks , that there was growing up between [these two beloved sons]2884-these two beloved sons a coolness — a want of sympathy , an indisposition to run well in harness together — which might lead to sore trouble ? There certainly had been one or two slight quarrels between [them]2883-her children which had been made up through [his]297-the old man own intervention . How would it be , [he]297-the old man wondered , when [he]297-the old man was not there any more to smooth things over ? Somehow [he]297-the old man did not feel that [he]297-the old man cared to live any longer , even to keep peace between [[his]297-the old man boys]2885-his boys . That must be done some other way . Truth to say , [he]297-the old man was very tired of being alive . The October day faded , and presently [the sick - room]2886-the sick - room was lighted only by the red flickering glow of the fire , which threw strange fantastic shadows from the handsome commonplace furniture , and made the portraits on the walls seem to look out of their frames with quite new expressions . [Old Ferrier]104-richard lay looking at the pictures in a tremor of expectation that made the time seem very long indeed . At last [his]297-the old man strained sense caught the faint click of the Brahma lock as it was opened by a key from without , and the bang of the front door as it was closed somewhat hurriedly from within . '[0-i] There they are , ' [he]297-the old man said at once . '[0-i] Send [them]300-them up , [Letitia]108-miss letitia . ' As [she]108-miss letitia laid [her]108-miss letitia hand on the door to open it , another hand grasped the handle on the other side , and [a tall , broad - shouldered young fellow]2887-a tall , broad - shouldered young fellow came in , with the glisten of rain still on [his]2887-a tall , broad - shouldered young fellow brown moustache , and on [his]2887-a tall , broad - shouldered young fellow great - coat , seeming to bring with [him]2887-a tall , broad - shouldered young fellow a breath of freshness and the night air . '[108-miss letitia] Ah , [Dick]106-dick ! [I]0-i was just coming down for [you]106-dick . Where is [Roland]107-roland ? ' '[107-roland] [He]107-roland stayed awhile at [Aspinshaw]105-aspinshaw . How 's [father]301-father ? ' '[301-father] Awake , and asking for [you]106-dick , ' said [[his]106-dick aunt]2888-his aunt , and went away , closing the door softly . '[301-father] Well , [dad]302-dad , how goes it ? ' said [the new - comer , stepping forward into the glow of the firelight]2889-the new - comer , stepping forward into the glow of the firelight . '[301-father] Light the candles , ' said [[his]106-dick father]2890-his father , without answering the question , and [the young man]2891-the young man lighted two in heavy silver candlesticks which stood on the dressing - table . As [their]2892-their pale light fell on the white face lying against the hardly whiter pillow , [Dick]106-dick 's eyes scrutinised it anxiously . '[301-father] [You]106-dick do n't look any better , ' [he]106-dick said , sitting down by the bed , and taking [[his]106-dick father]2890-his father 's hand . '[106-dick] [I]0-i wish [I]0-i 'd been at [home]303-home when [that doctor]304-that doctor came yesterday . ' '[304-that doctor] [I]0-i 'm glad [you]106-dick were n't [Dick]106-dick ; [I]305-the other 'd rather tell [you]106-dick [myself]305-the other . [I]305-the other wish [[your]106-dick brother]2894-your brother were [here]2895-here . '[305-the other] ' [I]305-the other daresay [he]2894-your brother wo n't be long , '[305-the other] said [the other]305-the other , frowning a little , while the lines about [his]305-the other mouth grew hard and set ; ' but what did [the doctor]2896-the doctor say ? [Aunt Letitia]109-aunt letitia did n't seem to know anything about it . '[305-the other] ' [He]2896-the doctor told [me]297-the old man [I]297-the old man should n't live to see another birthday , '[297-the old man] said [the old man]297-the old man . [He]297-the old man had rehearsed in [his]297-the old man own mind over and over again how [he]297-the old man should break this news to [[his]297-the old man boys]2885-his boys , and now [he]297-the old man was telling it in a way quite other than any that had been in [his]297-the old man rehearsals . ' Not see another birthday ! '[297-the old man] echoed [[his]297-the old man son]308-his son . ' Nonsense ! Why , [father]301-father , '[297-the old man] [he]297-the old man added , with a sudden start , ' [your]308-his son birthday 's on Wednesday . How could [he]2896-the doctor ? [I]297-the old man 'll write to [him]2896-the doctor . '[297-the old man] ' [[My]297-the old man dear boy]2898-my dear boy , [I]297-the old man felt it before [he]2896-the doctor told [me]297-the old man . [He]2896-the doctor only put into words what [I]297-the old man 've known ever since [I]297-the old man 've been lying here . There 's no getting over it . [I]297-the old man 'm[297-the old man] going . ' [Dick]106-dick did not speak . [He]106-dick pressed [[his]106-dick father]2890-his father 's hand hard , and then , letting it fall , [he]106-dick walked over to the hearthrug , and stood with [his]106-dick hands behind [him]106-dick , looking into the fire . '[297-the old man] Come back ; come here ! ' said the wavering voice from the bed . '[0-i] [I]0-i want [you]309-you , [Dick]106-dick . ' '[106-dick] Ca n't [I]0-i do something for [you]310-you , [dad]302-dad ? ' [he]106-dick said , in very much lower tones than usual , as [he]106-dick sat down again by the bed . [He]106-dick kept [his]106-dick face in the shadow of the curtain . '[0-i] [We]312-we 've always got on very well together , [Dick]106-dick . ' '[106-dick] Yes — we've been [very good friends]313-very good friends . '[0-i] ' [[Your]0-i brother]2894-your brother will soon be the nearest thing in [the world]2867-the world to [you]0-i . Oh , [[my]107-roland boy]2904-my boy , '[107-roland] said [old Ferrier]107-roland , suddenly raising [himself]107-roland on [his]107-roland elbow , and clasping [Dick]106-dick 's strong right hand in both [his]107-roland , ' for [God]110-god 's sake , do n't quarrel with [him]2894-your brother ! If [you]0-i ever cared for [me]107-roland , keep friends with [him]2894-your brother . If [you]0-i and [he]2894-your brother were n't [friends]2905-friends , [I]107-roland could n't lie easy in [my]107-roland grave . And it 's been a long life — [I]107-roland should like to lie easy at last ! '[107-roland] ' [I]0-i do n't quarrel with [him]2894-your brother , [father]301-father . '[0-i] ' Well , [lad]2907-lad — well , [I]107-roland 've thought [you]0-i did ; perhaps [I]107-roland 'm[107-roland] wrong . ' [He]2891-the young man turned and went to [[his]2891-the young man own room]2913-his own room . A quarter of an hour later [Roland]107-roland stood outside [[his]107-roland father]2890-his father 's door . [He]107-roland opened it gently , and entered , [his]107-roland slippered feet treading the floor of [the sick - room]2886-the sick - room as silently as [a nurse]2916-a nurse 's . As [he]107-roland stood a moment in the dim light , eyes less keen and less expectant than those looking at [him]107-roland from the bed might have easily mistaken [him]107-roland for [[his]107-roland brother]2917-his brother . The slight difference in breadth of shoulder and depth of chest was concealed by the loose indoor jacket [he]107-roland wore . There was no trace about [him]107-roland of [his]107-roland wet and muddy walk , and [he]107-roland looked altogether [a much fitter occupant for the easy - chair that stood at [the sick man]2919-the sick man 's bedside]2918-a much fitter occupant for the easy - chair that stood at the sick man 's bedside than [the stalwart , weather - stained , and unsympathetic - looking figure that had last sat in it]2920-the stalwart , weather - stained , and unsympathetic - looking figure that had last sat in it . '[111-miss ferrier] [Rowley]112-rowley , why did n't [you]112-rowley come before ? ' began [the old man]297-the old man . '[111-miss ferrier] Oh , [I]0-i could n't , [father]301-father . It is a beastly night . [I]0-i was awfully wet and muddy . [I]0-i only waited to change [my]0-i things , and make [myself]0-i presentable . How are [you]112-rowley to - night ? ' '[112-rowley] [[Your]112-rowley brother]2894-your brother came up wet enough , ' was all the answer . '[2894-your brother] Did [he]2894-your brother ? [Roland]107-roland seemed unable to utter anything save incoherent protestations of love and sorrow . '[297-the old man] ' Oh , no ; and it 's such a little way for [him]114-gates to come . '[114-gates] [Mr Gates]114-gates was [a member of [a firm of Stockport solicitors]334-a firm of stockport solicitors]333-a member of a firm of stockport solicitors , and [[his]114-gates country house]335-his country house was but a stone's - throw from [Thornsett Edge]1-thornsett edge . It was not long before [he]114-gates in [his]114-gates turn occupied that chair by the bed . [He]114-gates bore with [him]114-gates an atmosphere of jollity which even the hush of [that sick - room]336-that sick - room was powerless to dispel . [He]114-gates was not unsympathetic either , by any means , but [he]114-gates seemed made up of equal parts of kindheartedness and high spirits , and looked much more like [an ideal country squire]337-an ideal country squire than like [the ordinary legal adviser]338-the ordinary legal adviser . As a matter of fact , [he]114-gates was more at [home]303-home on [the moor side]340-the moor side or in [the stubble]341-the stubble than among dusty documents and leather - bound Acts of Parliament . ' What , [Mr Ferrier]107-roland , still in bed ! Why , [we]2930-we thought [old Gibson]113-doctor gibson would have had [you]107-roland on [your]107-roland legs again in no time . ' In an eager , tremulous voice [Ferrier]107-roland begged the other to believe that [his]107-roland fate was sealed , and that whatever was done must be done quickly . Then [he]107-roland proceeded to explain the changes [he]107-roland wished to have made in the will . [He]107-roland told [the lawyer]2931-the lawyer , without any of that reserve which ordinarily characterised [him]107-roland , all [his]107-roland fears about [[his]107-roland sons]2875-his sons , and then unfolded the scheme by which [he]107-roland thought to bind [the two]2933-the two together . [He]107-roland wished [their]2933-the two worldly interests to be so strongly bound up in [their]2933-the two relations to [each other]2934-each other that a quarrel à outrance would mean ruin to [both of [them]2933-the two]2864-both of them ; and to this end [he]107-roland proposed to leave [the mill]2936-the mill to [them]2933-the two jointly , on condition that [they]2933-the two worked it together , and [both]2937-both took an active part in the management of it . Should [they]2933-the two dissolve partnership before twenty - one years , or should either retire with consent of [the other]305-the other , the personal property was not to be touched by either , and at end of ten years — if [they]2933-the two were both alive and still separated — the whole was to go to [the [Manchester]5-manchester Infirmary]2939-the manchester infirmary . [Mr Gates]114-gates noted this extraordinary scheme down on the back of an old letter , and when [Mr Ferrier]107-roland had ended , read [his]107-roland notes through and shook [his]107-roland head . '[107-roland] Far better leave it alone , [Mr Ferrier]107-roland ; [they]350-they seem [the best of friends]351-the best of friends , and legacies like this never help matters much , anyhow . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i ca n't leave it alone , [Gates]114-gates . [I]0-i 've very little time left . The will is in that despatch - box , and there are pen and ink somewhere about . '[0-i] [Mr Gates]114-gates shrugged [his]114-gates shoulders , got out the will , and settled [himself]114-gates at the round table , on whose crimson velvet - pile cloth stood a papier - maché inkstand , a recent purchase of [Miss Letitia]108-miss letitia 's . [He]114-gates sat there biting [his]114-gates pen , and making aimless little scribbles on a sheet of blank paper . After some minutes [he]114-gates leaned forward , and for a little time no sound was heard but the squeak of [his]114-gates pen . At last [he]114-gates flung down the quill and rose . ' It is the only way it can be done , [sir]318-sir , '[114-gates] [he]114-gates said , and read it out . It carried out [Ferrier]107-roland 's plans , but placed the personal pro perty in the hands of [trustees]352-trustees , who were to pay to [Roland]107-roland and [Richard]104-richard the interest thereof so long as [they]352-trustees worked [the mill]2936-the mill together . If at the end of twenty - one years there had been no dissolution between [them]352-trustees , the money was to pass unconditionally to [them]352-trustees , in equal shares , or to [the survivor of [them]352-trustees]354-the survivor of them , or to [[their]352-trustees heirs]355-their heirs if [they]352-trustees were both dead . If [they]352-trustees quarrelled , the interest was to be allowed to accumulate for ten years , and then , if [the brothers]356-the brothers were still not on friendly terms , it should go , with the capital , to [the Infirmary]357-the infirmary . ' That 's right , '[104-richard] said [old Richard]104-richard , in a voice so changed as to convince [the solicitor]358-the solicitor that [he]104-richard was right in saying [he]104-richard had not much more time to spend . The codicil was signed , duly attested , and attached to the will , and [Ferrier]104-richard lay back exhausted , but with a light of new contentment in [his]104-richard eyes . ' [I]104-richard 'm[104-richard] right down tired out , ' [he]104-richard said ; '[0-i] [I]0-i shall sleep now . ' And sleep [he]104-richard did till the cold hour of the dawn , when there came a brief waking interval , before the longest , soundest sleep of all . [He]104-richard opened [his]104-richard eyes then . '[0-i] It 's nearly over , ' [he]104-richard said ; '[0-i] [[my]0-i boys]359-my boys — [[my]0-i boys]359-my boys ! [Roland]107-roland was in the sound sleep that often follows violent emotion , and it was hard to rouse [him]107-roland . [He]107-roland came in softly just as [[his]107-roland brother]2917-his brother laid gently down on the pillow [the worn old face]2947-the worn old face , at rest at last , and closed the kindly eyes that would never meet [Roland]107-roland 's any more . Never any more ! THE curtain had fallen on the last scene of the most popular play in [London]6-london . The appreciative criticism of the pit and the tearful sympathy of the upper boxes were alike merging in one common thought , that of '[0-i] something nice for supper . ' [The gallery]2948-the gallery was already empty . [[Its]2948-the gallery occupants]2949-its occupants were thirstier and more prompt of action than the loungers in the stalls and boxes . THE funeral was over , and [Thornsett Mill]13-thornsett mill was closed for the day . Fortunately the '[0-i] Spotted Cow ' was not closed , so that [the majority of the hands]3003-the majority of the hands did not find [themselves]3003-the majority of the hands without resources . Added to the subtle pleasure which so many derive from drinking small beer in [a sanded kitchen furnished with oak benches]3004-a sanded kitchen furnished with oak benches , there was to - day the excitement of discussing a great event , for to the average mind of [Thornsett]126-thornsett the death and burial of [old Richard Ferrier]104-richard were great events indeed . [So John Bolt]127-bolt , [the landlord]3006-the landlord , had [his]3006-the landlord hands pretty full , and the state of the till was so satisfactory that it was a really praiseworthy sacrifice to the decencies of [society]3007-society for [him]3006-the landlord to persist in not shortening by one fraction of an inch the respectfully long face which [he]3006-the landlord had put on in the morning as appropriate to the occasion . This startling economic theory meeting with no support , the original toast was drunk with a feeble attempt at honours . [The ' new masters '[128-murdoch] whose health had thus been unenthusiastically drunk]457-the ' new masters ' whose health had thus been unenthusiastically drunk found it hard to realise the peculiar position in which [they]457-the ' new masters ' whose health had thus been unenthusiastically drunk found [themselves]457-the ' new masters ' whose health had thus been unenthusiastically drunk . The will was a great surprise to [them]457-the ' new masters ' whose health had thus been unenthusiastically drunk both . [Neither]138-neither had thought that the slight breach which had come between [them]457-the ' new masters ' whose health had thus been unenthusiastically drunk was sufficiently wide to be noticed , and the very fact of its having been noticed made it appear deeper and more serious than [they]457-the ' new masters ' whose health had thus been unenthusiastically drunk had before considered it to be . It was a bitter thought to [Richard Ferrier]130-richard that [the old man]297-the old man 's last moments should have been made unquiet through any conduct of [his]297-the old man , and [he]297-the old man reproached [himself]297-the old man for not having concealed [his]297-the old man own feelings better , and for not having watched more keenly over those of [[his]297-the old man father]2890-his father . The most crushing part of bereavement is always the consciousness that so little more thought , so little more tact and tenderness , would have sufficed to spare that ended life many an hour of sorrow , that quiet heart many a pang of pain . It is then that [we]460-we would give [our]460-we heart 's blood for one hour with [the beloved]461-the beloved in which to tell [them]462-them all that [we]460-we might have said so easily while [they]462-them were [here]2895-here . This universal longing is responsible for that deeply rooted belief in the life beyond the grave which causes [two - thirds of human - kind]464-two - thirds of human - kind to dispense with evidence and to set reason at nought . So long as [the sons]465-the sons and daughters of [men]466-men Weep by silent graves alone , so long will [the priest]467-the priest find [[his]467-the priest penitent]468-his penitent , [the professor of modern spiritualism]469-the professor of modern spiritualism [his]467-the priest open - mouthed dupe , and [the shrine its devotee]470-the shrine its devotee . The ages roll on , each year [the old earth]471-the old earth opens [her]471-the old earth bosom for [[our]460-we dearest]472-our dearest , and still [man]473-man — [slow learner that [he]473-man is]474-slow learner that he is — will not realise that ( whatever may be the chances of another life in which to set right what has been here done amiss ) in this life , which is the only one [he]473-man can be sure of having , it rests with [him]473-man to decide whether there shall be any acts of unkindness that will seem to need atonement . The consolation which so many find in the idea of a future life was a closed door to [Dick]106-dick . [He]106-dick had belonged to the ' advanced '[106-dick] school of thought at college , and to [him]106-dick the gulf which separated [him]106-dick from [[his]106-dick father]2890-his father was one that could never be bridged over . [Roland]107-roland 's grief was more absorbing than [[his]107-roland brother]2917-his brother 's , though it was not so acute ; and by its very nature could not be so lasting . Yet through it all [he]107-roland felt rather — not vexed — but grieved that [[his]107-roland father]2890-his father should have not only divined [his]107-roland inmost feelings , but should have published them to [the world]2867-the world by means of this will . [He]107-roland had an uneasy consciousness that [he]107-roland was made to appear ridiculous , and for [Roland]107-roland to be possibly absurd was to be certainly wretched . It was very irritating that [two brothers]479-two brothers could not have an occasional difference without having [their]479-two brothers ' sparring '[107-roland] made the subject of a solemn legal document ; and without being [themselves]479-two brothers placed in such a situation that the eyes of [all [their]479-two brothers acquaintances]480-all their acquaintances must be turned expectantly on [them]479-two brothers to see what [they]479-two brothers would do next . The differences arose from an only too complete agreement on one particular point . When [they]479-two brothers had come back from [Cambridge]2-cambridge a year before , [they]479-two brothers had found a new and interesting feature in the social aspect of [Firth Vale]11-firth vale . [Clare Stanley]139-clare had come [home]303-home from [the German boarding - school where [she]139-clare had spent the last three years]482-the german boarding - school where she had spent the last three years . [The young men]483-the young men had not seen [her]139-clare since [she]139-clare was [a child]484-a child , and now [they]483-the young men met [her]139-clare in the full blossom of very pretty and sufficiently - conscious young womanhood . For about two months [they]483-the young men discussed [her]139-clare freely in [their]483-the young men more sociable hours , admired [her]139-clare prodigiously , and congratulated [each other]2934-each other on [their]483-the young men good luck . Then came reticence ; then occasional half - hearted sarcasms , directed against [her]139-clare , varied by a criticism of [each other]2934-each other , the sincerity of which was beyond a doubt . For some months before [the old man]297-the old man 's death the rivalry that had sprung up between [them]483-the young men had been too strong to be always kept under , even in [his]297-the old man presence , and [he]297-the old man had seen the effect , though not guessed the cause . Strangely enough , another cause of dissension between [the brothers]356-the brothers had been also touched on by [[their]356-the brothers critics]489-their critics in the tap of the Spotted Cow : [Alice Hatfield]134-alice . When [Mrs. Ferrier]140-mrs. ferrier had died [Mrs. Hatfield]141-mrs hatfield had been [foster - mother to [the two boys]491-the two boys]490-foster - mother to the two boys , and during [their]491-the two boys childhood [they]491-the two boys were [the constant playfellows of [little Alice]134-alice]492-the constant playfellows of little alice . Of course as [they]491-the two boys grew older the distance between [them]491-the two boys increased , but [Richard]130-richard was still very fond of [Alice]134-alice , and it was a great blow to [him]130-richard when one day , about three months after [their]491-the two boys return from college , [the girl]367-the girl suddenly disappeared , taking leave of [no one]494-no one , and leaving no word of explanation . All that [anyone]495-anyone could gather was that during a visit [she]367-the girl had recently paid to [an aunt in [Liverpool]14-liverpool]496-an aunt in liverpool [she]367-the girl had been seen to talk more than once to [a gentleman]497-a gentleman , and that [she]367-the girl had left [the Firth Vale Station]498-the firth vale station for [Manchester]5-manchester by [an early train]499-an early train alone . But the worst of it was that [Roland]107-roland had that very day abruptly announced [his]107-roland intention of taking a holiday , and had gone North without any apparent object ; and village gossip busied itself rarely with this portentous coincidence . At the end of a month [Roland]107-roland returned , looking worn and harassed . [[His]107-roland brother]2917-his brother asked [him]107-roland point blank where [he]107-roland had been , and for what . [Roland]107-roland indignantly denied [his]107-roland right to question , and flatly refused to answer . A quarrel ensued — the first of many , which grew more frequent as [they]501-they saw more of [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley . On the morning on which [Mr Ferrier]107-roland died , [she]367-the girl and [[her]367-the girl father]391-her father had gone to [London]6-london to spend a month ; and the time of [her]367-the girl absence was the most peaceful [the young men]483-the young men had known for some time . [Clare]139-clare [herself]139-clare was glad to go to [London]6-london , though not so glad to leave the scene of [her]139-clare conquests . [One]504-one can not blame [her]139-clare much for knowing that [she]139-clare was charming . [The two Ferriers]505-the two ferriers were the most desirable young men [the country - side]506-the country - side could offer , and [no girl]507-no girl could have wished [a finer pair of captives]508-a finer pair of captives to grace [her]139-clare chariot - wheels . And [— Aspinshaw]105-aspinshaw was very dull . WHEN [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley opened [her]122-miss stanley hazel eyes the morning after the mischance on the way [home]303-home from [the theatre]365-the theatre , [her]122-miss stanley first waking impression was that something pleasant was to happen . [She]122-miss stanley laughed at [herself]122-miss stanley a little when complete wakefulness made [her]122-miss stanley conscious that , after all , it was only [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's acquaintance and promised call which were answerable for that dreamy feeling of anticipated enjoyment . [She]122-miss stanley let [her]122-miss stanley thoughts stray in [his]121-litvinoff direction several times that day , and at the table d'hôte looked out for [him]121-litvinoff with interest . But [he]121-litvinoff was not there . Bearing in mind [Mr Stanley]119-mr stanley 's invitation , [Count Michael Litvinoff]121-litvinoff had thought it as well to absent [himself]121-litvinoff from the table d'hôte . It would have been rather awkward to meet [[his]121-litvinoff new acquaintances]511-his new acquaintances at dinner and then to call on [them]511-his new acquaintances immediately afterwards . ' [I]119-mr stanley do n't see [[our]3038-our Russian friend]3039-our russian friend , [Clare]139-clare , '[119-mr stanley] remarked [Mr Stanley]119-mr stanley as the fish was removed . ' [I]119-mr stanley think [you]139-clare must have been mistaken about [his]121-litvinoff staying [here]2895-here . '[119-mr stanley] ' Perhaps [I]139-clare was , [papa]361-papa , '[139-clare] said [Clare]139-clare , submissively , but with a sparkle in [her]139-clare eyes that contradicted [her]139-clare words . ' Or perhaps [his]121-litvinoff foot hurt [him]121-litvinoff so much that [he]121-litvinoff could n't come down . '[139-clare] ' If [he]121-litvinoff does n't come up after dinner [we]3042-we 'd better make inquiries . ' [[My]119-mr stanley daughter]409-my daughter tells [me]119-mr stanley [you]139-clare are staying in [this hotel]3044-this hotel , '[119-mr stanley] [he]119-mr stanley began ; and as [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , taking this as an introduction , bowed low to [her]139-clare , with [his]121-litvinoff eyes on the ground , [she]139-clare hoped [he]121-litvinoff did not notice the sudden flush that swept over [her]139-clare face . '[0-i] ' No , [I]0-i 'm[0-i] not ; but [I]0-i 'm afraid [you]119-mr stanley are ; do sit down . '[0-i] As [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff and [[her]139-clare father]391-her father went on talking , [Clare]139-clare , who had not yet spoken a word , could not help thinking that [this gentleman with the foreign name]514-this gentleman with the foreign name was somehow very different from [any man [she]139-clare had hitherto met]515-any man she had hitherto met , not even excepting those fine specimens of [young English manhood]516-young english manhood , [the Ferriers]142-the ferriers . " [The Ash Grove]526-the ash grove . " ' [Clare]139-clare sang it . '[144-bonnie doon] It always seems to [me]0-i , ' [he]0-i said when [she]139-clare had finished , '[144-bonnie doon] that that music carries in it all the longing that makes the hearts of exiles heavy . ' [Clare]139-clare looked up at [him]0-i brightly . '[144-bonnie doon] Oh , but [their]528-their hearts ought not to be heavy , [you]0-i know , ' [she]139-clare said . '[144-bonnie doon] The Revolution is of [no country]529-no country — [I]0-i thought banishment from [one country]530-one country ought merely to mean work in another for an exile for freedom . Surely there is a fight to be fought here in [England]15-england , for instance , too . [I]0-i do n't know much about it ; [I]0-i 've scarcely seen anything , but it seems to [me]0-i there is much to be put straight here — many wrongs to be redressed , much misery to be swept away . ' [The Count]3057-the count 's bold eyes fixed [themselves]528-their on [her]139-clare with a new interest in [them]528-their . '[0-i] [Exiles]531-exiles here do what [they]531-exiles can , [I]0-i think ; but [the wronged and miserable]532-the wronged and miserable will not have long to wait , if there are many [Miss Stanleys]146-the stanleys to champion [their]531-exiles cause . Still it does make [one]504-one 's heart heavy to know that horrors unspeakable , worse than anything here , take place daily in [one 's own country]534-one 's own country , which [one]504-one is powerless to prevent . [One]504-one feels helpless , shut out . Ah , heaven ! death itself is less hard to bear . ' '[0-i] [You]0-i speak as if [you]0-i had felt it all [yourself]0-i , ' said [Clare]139-clare , a little surprised at the earnestness of [his]0-i tone . '[0-i] [I]0-i did not mean to speak otherwise than generally . [I]0-i believe in [England]15-england it is considered " bad form " to show feeling of any sort — and [you]0-i English hate sentiment , do n't [you]0-i ? ' '[0-i] [I]0-i do n't think [we]537-we hate sincere feeling of any kind ; but forgive [me]0-i for asking — are [you]0-i really an exile ? ' [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff bowed . And [one]504-one is driven to make music for [oneself]504-one when [one]504-one lives a very lonely life . ' '[0-i] Wo n't [you]0-i make music for [us]537-we ? ' [she]3058-she asked , ignoring the fact that [[her]3058-she father]391-her father was still snoring with vigour . '[0-i] Yes , if [you]0-i wish it . ' [He]0-i took [her]3058-she place at the piano , and , in a low voice , sang a Hungarian air , wild and melancholy , with a despairing minor refrain . While [her]3058-she thanks were being spoken [his]0-i fingers strayed over the keys , and , almost insensibly as it seemed , fell into a few chords that suggested the air of the Marseillaise . '[0-i] Oh , do sing that ! [I]0-i 've never heard [anyone]495-anyone but [a schoolgirl]541-a schoolgirl attempt it , and [I]0-i long so to hear it really sung . [I]0-i think it 's glorious . ' Without a word [he]0-i obeyed [her]3058-she , and launched into the famous battle song of [Liberty]165-liberty . [His]0-i singing of the other song had been a whisper , but in this [he]0-i gave [his]0-i voice full play , and sang it with a fire , a fervour , a splendid earnestness and enthusiasm , that made the air vibrate , and thrilled [Clare]139-clare through and through with an utterly new emotion . [She]3058-she understood now how this song had been able to stir [men]466-men to such deeds as [she]3058-she had read of — had nerved [ragged , half - starved , untrained battalions]3061-ragged , half - starved , untrained battalions to scatter like chaff [the veteran armies of [Europe]17-europe]3062-the veteran armies of europe . [She]3058-she understood it all as [she]3058-she listened to the mingled pathos , defiance , confidence of victory , vengeance and passionate patriotism , which [Rouget de Lisle]147-rouget de lisle alone of [all men]3063-all men has been able to concentrate and to embody in one immortal song , in every note of which breathes the very soul of [Liberty]165-liberty . As the last note was struck and [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff turned round from the piano , [he]0-i almost smiled at the contrasts in the picture before [him]0-i — [a girl]3064-a girl leaning forward , [her]3064-a girl face lighted up with sympathetic fire , and [her]3064-a girl eyes glowing with sympathetic enthusiasm , and [an old gentleman standing on the hearthrug]3065-an old gentleman standing on the hearthrug , very red in the face , very wide awake , and unutterably astonished . [The girl]367-the girl was certainly very lovely , and if [the exile]3067-the exile thought so , as [he]0-i glanced somewhat deprecatingly at [the old gentleman]2966-the old gentleman , who shall blame [him]0-i ? ' This reduced the situation to the absurd — and [they]542-the waiters all laughed . AS a rule , it was not an easy matter to turn [Richard Ferrier]130-richard from any purpose of [his]130-richard , and when [his]130-richard purpose was that of visiting [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley and at the same time of putting a stop to any chance of a tête - à - tête between [[his]130-richard divinity]547-his divinity and [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother , no ordinary red herring would have drawn [him]130-richard off the track . [The street]557-the street was one of [those long , straight , melancholy streets]558-those long , straight , melancholy streets , the deadly monotony and general seediness of which no amount of traffic can relieve — which bear the same relation to [Regent Street]19-regent street and [Oxford Street]20-oxford street as the seamy side of a stage court suit does to the glitter and gaudiness that charm the pit , and stir the æsthetic emotions of [the gallery]2948-the gallery . There are always plenty of people moving about in [these streets]560-these streets whom [one]504-one never sees anywhere else — and [you]562-you may pass up and down [them]560-these streets a dozen times a day without meeting [anyone whose dress does not bear tokens , more or less pronounced , of a hand - to - hand struggle with hard - upness]563-anyone whose dress does not bear tokens , more or less pronounced , of a hand - to - hand struggle with hard - upness . It is a peculiarity of this struggle that in it [those who struggle hardest appear to get least , or at any rate those who get least have to struggle hardest]564-those who struggle hardest appear to get least , or at any rate those who get least have to struggle hardest . [This Society]21-this society recognises with unconscious candour — and when [it]565-it sees [a man or woman shabbily dressed and with dirty hands]566-a man or woman shabbily dressed and with dirty hands , it at once decides that [he]567-he or [she]568-she must belong to [the ' working '[565-it] classes]569-the ' working ' classes ; thus naïvely accepting the fact that those whose work produces the wealth are not usually [those who secure it]570-those who secure it . The face which had attracted [Dick]106-dick 's notice was as careworn as any other in [that crowd]571-that crowd — the figure as shabbily clad as [the majority]572-the majority . But [the young man]2891-the young man turned and followed with an interest independent of fair features or becoming raiment — an interest which had its rise in a determination to solve a problem , or at any rate to silence a doubt . Yet it was [a young woman]574-a young woman [he]2891-the young man was following — more than that , [a pretty young women]575-a pretty young women ; and the very evident fact that [this handsome , well - dressed young man]576-this handsome , well - dressed young man was openly following [this shabby girl]577-this shabby girl with a parcel inspired some of the loafers whom [they]578-they passed to the utterance of comments , the simple directness of which would perhaps not have pleased [the young man]2891-the young man had [he]2891-the young man heard them . [He]2891-the young man heard nothing . [He]2891-the young man was too intent on keeping [her]577-this shabby girl in sight . '[2891-the young man] Oh , [I]0-i manage to get along pretty well , ' [she]583-her replied , with an effort at a smile , which was more pathetic in [Dick]106-dick 's eyes than [her]583-her tears had been . [He]2891-the young man thought gloomily of the time , not so very long ago either , when [her]583-her face had been the brightest as well as the fairest in [Thornsett village]3089-thornsett village , and [his]2891-the young man heart was sore with indignant protest against [him]2891-the young man who had so changed [her]583-her face , [her]583-her life , [her]583-her surroundings . [He]2891-the young man looked at [her]583-her tired thin face , still so pretty , in spite of the grief that had aged and the want that had pinched it , and found it hard to believe that this was indeed [the Alice with whom [he]2891-the young man had raced through [the pastures at [Firth Vale]11-firth vale]3091-the pastures at firth vale]3090-the alice with whom he had raced through the pastures at firth vale — [the Alice who had taken the place in [[his]2891-the young man boyish heart of [a very dear little sister]3094-a very dear little sister]3093-his boyish heart of a very dear little sister]3092-the alice who had taken the place in his boyish heart of a very dear little sister . Ah , if [she]583-her had only been [[his]2891-the young man sister]296-his sister really , then [their]3096-their friendship would not have grown less and less during [his]2891-the young man school and college days , and [his]2891-the young man protection would have saved [her]583-her , perhaps , from this . These foster - relationships are uncomfortable things . [They]3097-they inflict the sufferings of a real blood tie , and give none of the rights which might mitigate or avert such suffering . '[0-i] How 's [mother]523-mother and [father]301-father ? ' [she]583-her said , breaking in among [his]2891-the young man sad thoughts . '[523-mother] [They]586-they were well when [I]0-i saw [them]586-they , but [I]0-i 've not seen [them]586-they lately . [We]587-we 've been in great trouble . ' '[587-we] Yes . '[0-i] Then [you]0-i do n't know how [they]586-they are at [home]303-home ? ' '[0-i] [I]0-i only know [they]586-they 're grieving after [you]0-i still . [I]0-i 've sowed and [I]0-i must reap . [I]0-i must go through with it . [I]0-i live just down here . Good - night . ' It did not look [a very inviting residence]3098-a very inviting residence — [a narrow street]3099-a narrow street , leading into [a court]3100-a court which was too dark and too distant to be seen into from the corner where [she]3101-she had stopped . '[0-i] [I]0-i sha'n't say good - night till [you]0-i say when [I]0-i shall see [you]0-i again . ' '[0-i] What 's the use ? ' [DICK]106-dick did not feel inclined to go to [[Morley]118-morley 's]3104-morley 's after this rencontre , so [he]106-dick turned back towards [[his]106-dick hotel]3105-his hotel . The problem was not actually solved , certainly ; but [he]106-dick was disposed to take all that had passed as a confirmation of [his]106-dick worst suspicions — so much so , that [he]106-dick felt [he]106-dick could not meet [[his]106-dick brother]2917-his brother just then , as if nothing had happened . [He]106-dick took two or three turns up and down [that festive promenade]3107-that festive promenade , [the Euston Road]22-the euston road , thinking indignantly that [his]106-dick position ought to have been [Roland]107-roland 's , and [Roland]107-roland 's [his]107-roland — that [he]106-dick was suffering for [[his]106-dick brother]2917-his brother 's misdeeds , while [[his]106-dick brother]2917-his brother was enjoying bright glances from eyes that would hardly look so kindly on [him]106-dick could [[their]3110-their owner]3111-their owner have known how [Dick]106-dick was spending the evening . For the first time , too , [he]106-dick saw , though only dimly , a few of the difficulties that would lie in [his]106-dick way . It would be harder than ever to keep on any sort of terms with [[his]106-dick brother]2917-his brother now that [he]106-dick could no longer respect [him]2917-his brother , and to respect [a man who had brought misery into [a family which [he]106-dick was bound by every law of honour to protect]3114-a family which he was bound by every law of honour to protect was not possible to [Dick]106-dick . As [[his]106-dick rival]3115-his rival [he]106-dick had almost hated [Roland]107-roland ; as [the man who had ruined [Alice Hatfield]134-alice [he]106-dick both hated and despised [him]107-roland]3116-the man who had ruined alice hatfield he both hated and despised him , and [he]106-dick knew well enough that between [partners in business]3117-partners in business these sort of feelings do not lead to commercial success . [He]106-dick did not care to follow out all the train of thought that this suggested ; but the remembrance of [[his]106-dick father]2890-his father 's strange will]3113-a man who had brought misery into a family which he was bound by every law of honour to protect was not possible to dick . as his rival he had almost hated roland ; as the man who had ruined alice hatfield he both hated and despised him , and he knew well enough that between partners in business these sort of feelings do not lead to commercial success . he did not care to follow out all the train of thought that this suggested ; but the remembrance of his father 's strange will was very present with [him]106-dick as [he]106-dick went to bed . In the morning things looked different . It is a way things have . [Colours]148-colours seen by candle lightWill not look the same by day . After all , was it proved ? When [he]106-dick came to think over what [the girl]367-the girl had said there seemed to be nothing positively conclusive in it all . It was a strange contradiction — [he]106-dick had been very eager to trace the matter out — to prove to [himself]106-dick that [Roland]107-roland was utterly unworthy to win [Clare Stanley]139-clare ; and yet now [he]106-dick felt that [he]106-dick would give a good deal to believe that [Roland]107-roland had not done this thing . And this was not only because of the grave pecuniary dilemma in which [he]106-dick must involve [himself]106-dick by any quarrel with [Roland]107-roland . Perhaps it was partly because blood is , after all , thicker than water . It did not seem to [Dick]106-dick that [his]106-dick knowledge was much increased by [his]106-dick conversation with [Alice]134-alice . The blackest point was still that mysterious holiday trip , taken at such an unusual time , and about which [[his]106-dick brother]2917-his brother had been so strangely reticent . And that might be accounted for in plenty of other ways . [Alice]134-alice 's disappearance at that particular time was very likely only a rather queer coincidence . [Dick]106-dick had thought all this , and more , before [he]106-dick had finished dressing , and [he]106-dick was ready to meet [[his]106-dick brother]2917-his brother at breakfast with a manner a shade more cordial than usual — the reaction perhaps from [his]106-dick recent suspicions . [Roland]107-roland was in particularly high spirits . '[305-the other] Wherever did [you]596-you get to last night ? ' [he]107-roland asked . ' [This]149-this smote [Dick]106-dick with some compunction , and [he]106-dick resolved not to dislike this soi - disant count until [he]106-dick had cause to do so , which cause [he]106-dick did not doubt that [their]3124-us first meeting would furnish forth abundantly . But [he]106-dick was wrong . [Litvinoff]143-litvinoff came , and [Dick]106-dick found [his]106-dick prejudices melting away . [The count]3057-the count seemed a standing proof of the correctness of the parallels which have been drawn between [Russian and English character]3126-russian and english character . [He]3057-the count was English in [his]3057-the count frankness , [his]3057-the count modesty , [his]3057-the count off - hand way of telling [his]3057-the count own adventures without making [himself]3057-the count [the hero of [his]3057-the count stories]3127-the hero of his stories . Before the evening was over [Dick]106-dick began to realise that [Nihilists]150-nihilists were not quite so black as [they]150-nihilists are sometimes painted , and that there are other countries besides [England]15-england where progressive measures are desirable . [The brothers]356-the brothers were both interested , and tried very hard to get more particulars of Nihilist doctrines , but as [they]356-the brothers grew more curious [Litvinoff]143-litvinoff became more reticent . '[143-litvinoff] This offer was too tempting to be refused . '[106-dick] [Dear Mr Richard,—I]151-dear mr richard,—i promised to write to [you]151-dear mr richard,—i but [I]0-i did not mean to see [you]151-dear mr richard,—i again .
