'[0-i] This letter revived [his]107-roland doubts , but [he]107-roland was very glad of the chance of seeing [her]623-her again , and [he]107-roland determined not to be deterred from pressing the question which [he]107-roland had at heart by any pain which it might cause [her]623-her or [himself]107-roland . Jealousy , curiosity , regard for [the girl]367-the girl — all these urged [him]107-roland to learn the truth , and besides [them]625-them all a certain sense of duty . If [her]623-her sorrow had come to [her]623-her through [[his]107-roland brother]2917-his brother it surely was all the more incumbent on [him]107-roland to see that [her]623-her material sufferings , at any rate , were speedily ended . If not [.... Men]152-.... men almost always move from very mixed motives , and of these motives [they]627-they only acknowledge one to be [their]627-they spring of action . This sense of duty was the one motive which [Dick]106-dick now admitted to [himself]106-dick . At any rate [he]107-roland did not mean to think any more about it till Monday came , so [he]107-roland thrust the letter into [his]107-roland pocket , and let [his]107-roland fancy busy itself with [Clare Stanley]139-clare after its wonted fashion . [It]628-it found plenty of occupation in the anticipation of that Sunday afternoon call . When the call was made [Mr Stanley]119-mr stanley was asleep , and though [he]119-mr stanley roused [himself]119-mr stanley to welcome [them]629-them [he]119-mr stanley soon relapsed into the condition which is peculiar to [the respectable Briton]630-the respectable briton on Sunday afternoons . [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley was particularly cheerful , but as soon as [she]122-miss stanley heard where [they]629-them intended to spend the evening , the conversation took a turn so distinctly [Russian]153-russian , as to be almost a forestalment of the coming evening 's entertainment . Nihilism in general and Nihilist counts in particular seemed to be the only theme on which [she]122-miss stanley would converse for two minutes at a time . [Roland]107-roland made a vigorous effort to lead the conversation to things English , but it was a dead failure . [Dick]106-dick sought to elicit [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley 's opinion of [the reigning actress]631-the reigning actress , but this , as [he]107-roland might have foreseen , only led to a detailed account of that adventure in which the principal part of [hero]632-hero had been played by [a Russian]3050-a russian , [a Nihilist]634-a nihilist , or [a count]605-a count , and there were [all the favoured subjects]636-all the favoured subjects at once over again . [The young men]483-the young men felt that the visit had not been a distinct success , and when [Clare]139-clare woke [[her]139-clare father]391-her father up to beg [him]391-her father to take [her]139-clare to [that Radical club in [Soho]23-soho]639-that radical club in soho , even [his]391-her father explosive refusal and anathematising of [Radicals as pests of society]640-radicals as pests of society failed to reconcile [the Ferriers]142-the ferriers to [[their]483-the young men lady]641-their lady 's new enthusiasm . The conversation at dinner , however , was a complete change . [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff appeared to feel no interest in life , save in the question of athletics at [the English universities]642-the english universities ; but on this topic [he]121-litvinoff managed to be so entertaining that [[his]121-litvinoff guests]643-his guests quite forgot , in [his]121-litvinoff charm as [talker]644-talker , the irritation [he]121-litvinoff had caused [them]643-his guests to feel when [he]121-litvinoff was merely the subject of [someone else]402-someone else 's talk . When dinner was over , and [the three]646-the three started to walk to [Soho]23-soho , [they]646-the three were all on the very best of terms with [themselves]646-the three and [each other]2934-each other . Would [one of [them]646-the three]648-one of them have been quite so much at ease if [he]648-one of them had known that the announcement of the coming lecture had been seen in the paper by [Alice Hatfield]134-alice , and that [she]134-alice — not being much by way of going to [church]649-church — had made up [her]134-alice mind to be [there]2994-there ? [THE average English citizen]651-the average english citizen and [[his]651-the average english citizen wife]522-his wife have a certain method of spending Sunday which admits of no variation , and is as essential to [their]643-his guests religion as any doctrine which that religion inculcates . Indeed , it is very often the only tribute which [they]643-his guests pay to [those supernatural powers who are supposed to smile upon virtue and to frown upon vice]653-those supernatural powers who are supposed to smile upon virtue and to frown upon vice . When [church]649-church and [chapel]655-chapel — [St Waltheof]154-st waltheof 's and [Little Bethel]155-little bethel — unite in teaching that ceremonial observance is at least as important as moral practice , is it to be wondered at that [[their]643-his guests congregations]656-their congregations , feeling that it would be more than human to combine the two , choose to move along the line of least resistance ? It is comparatively easy , though perhaps somewhat tiresome , especially in hot weather , to get up only a little late on Sunday mornings , instead of a good deal late , as [the ' natural man]3132-the ' natural man '[3132-the ' natural man] would prefer to do ; to assume a more or less solemn aspect at the breakfast - table ; to wear garments of unusual splendour , which do not see daylight during the week , and in assuming [them]643-his guests to feel tremors of uneasiness lest [they]643-his guests should be outshone by [[Mr Jones]156-mr jones ' wife]3133-mr jones ' wife , [[Mr Smith]157-mr smith 's daughter]3134-mr smith 's daughter , [[Mr Brown]158-mr brown 's sister]3135-mr brown 's sister , or [[Mr Robinson]159-mr robinson 's maiden aunt]3136-mr robinson 's maiden aunt . It is not quite so easy , but still possible , to sit for two hours on a narrow seat , evidently made by someone who knew [he]3137-he [would never have to sit on it , and to keep awake]3138-would never have to sit on it , and to keep awake ( in the old pews this was not imperative ) , while [a preacher]3139-a preacher , whom [one]504-one does not care for , talks , in language [one]504-one does not understand , on subjects in which one takes not the slightest interest . And then , as a compensation , [one]504-one has the heavy early dinner and the afternoon sleep , in itself almost a religious exercise . Perhaps [one 's ungodly neighbours]3143-one 's ungodly neighbours curse the day [they]3143-one 's ungodly neighbours were born as [they]3143-one 's ungodly neighbours hear [one]504-one , after tea , playing long - drawn hymn tunes on a harmonium , till the bells begin to go for evening '[659-himself'—to] worship ' ; then [[one]504-one 's wife]3146-one 's wife goes to put on [her]3146-one 's wife bonnet ( which has been lying in state all day on the best bed , covered with a white handkerchief ) , and [one]504-one goes to [one]504-one 's '[659-himself'—to] sitting ' again with a delicious sense that the worse of it is over . All this is not so difficult , and an eternity of bliss is cheap at the price — distinctly . But to refrain from sanding the sugar or watering the milk — especially for a '[659-himself'—to] [family man]657-family man , ' who has '[659-himself'—to] [others]658-others to think of besides [himself'—to]659-himself'—to keep [one]504-one 's hand from this , and [one]504-one 's tongue from evil - speaking , lying and slandering , to keep [one]504-one 's body in temperance and soberness , to be true and just in all one 's dealings — this would be not only difficult but absurd , nowadays . There are [a good many who try to carry out the moral teachings and let the ceremonial observances alone]663-a good many who try to carry out the moral teachings and let the ceremonial observances alone , and there are far more who disregard [the one and the other]664-the one and the other ; and for both these classes there are ways of spending Sunday evening of which [the strict Sabbatarian]665-the strict sabbatarian has no conception . Among others are the entertainments provided by [[working men]666-working men 's clubs]667-working men 's clubs . These are not the wildest form of dissipation ; but , as a rule , they have some practical bearing on [this world]668-this world and its affairs and , though rather solid pudding , are appreciated by [the audiences]669-the audiences , mostly [working men , who have a strong and increasing taste for solids , and no small discernment in the matter of flavours]670-working men , who have a strong and increasing taste for solids , and no small discernment in the matter of flavours . To - night the dish provided for [the Agora Club]671-the agora club was a Russian one , and was likely to be highly spiced . ' Do [you]121-litvinoff expect [a large audience]3149-a large audience ? '[130-richard] [Richard Ferrier]130-richard asked [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , as [they]672-they walked along . ' [I]121-litvinoff hope so , '[121-litvinoff] [he]121-litvinoff said . ' [I]121-litvinoff can always speak better to [a full room]3150-a full room . Perhaps the physical heat does something to grease [one]504-one 's tongue ; and then , again , in a large audience , [you]674-you 're[121-litvinoff] sure to have [some people who agree with [you]674-you]673-some people who agree with you , and [you]674-you and [they]673-some people who agree with you reflect enthusiasm backwards and forwards between [you]674-you . [We]672-they 're close there now , '[121-litvinoff] [he]121-litvinoff added , as [they]672-they turned down [a narrow street of high , unhappy - looking houses]675-a narrow street of high , unhappy - looking houses . ' How in [the world]2867-the world do [you]121-litvinoff come to be lecturing at a place like this ? How do [you]121-litvinoff know anything about it ? '[107-roland] asked [Roland]107-roland . ' There is [a freemasonry among [the soldiers of [Liberty]165-liberty which holds good all over [the world]2867-the world]3154-the soldiers of liberty which holds good all over the world , and [[we]672-they who serve [her]3153-a freemasonry among the soldiers of liberty which holds good all over the world , and we who serve her]3156-we who serve her]3153-a freemasonry among the soldiers of liberty which holds good all over the world , and we who serve her are pledged to carry [her]3153-a freemasonry among the soldiers of liberty which holds good all over the world , and we who serve her light into the darkest corners . '[107-roland] If this seemed somewhat rhetorical to [the young Englishmen]676-the young englishmen , [they]676-the young englishmen were ready enough to excuse it in [a foreigner]2963-a foreigner , and especially in [a foreigner who was about to make a speech]678-a foreigner who was about to make a speech . It did occur to [Dick]106-dick that [the locality in which [they]672-they were at the moment]679-the locality in which they were at the moment was [a dark corner which stood as much in need of the services of [the Metropolitan Gas Company]681-the metropolitan gas company]680-a dark corner which stood as much in need of the services of the metropolitan gas company as of [those of [the torch - bearers of Freedom]683-the torch - bearers of freedom]682-those of the torch - bearers of freedom ; but there was light enough in [the room into which [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff soon led [them]672-they]684-the room into which count litvinoff soon led them . [It]684-the room into which count litvinoff soon led them was long and rather low , not unlike [a certain type of dissenting meeting - room]685-a certain type of dissenting meeting - room . At one end was [a platform]686-a platform , on which stood two wooden chairs , and a deal table which had upon [it]686-a platform a tumbler , a bottle of water , and a small wooden hammer , similar to those used by [auctioneers]687-auctioneers . [The room]2910-the room was well filled — so well filled that all the wooden forms and chairs were occupied , and even [the standing room]689-the standing room was so much taken up that [the three young men]690-the three young men found a little difficulty in working [their]690-the three young men way to the upper end of [the room]2910-the room . [Roland]107-roland noticed , with some surprise , that among [the audience]692-the audience were [several women , who seemed quite as much at [home]303-home [there]2994-there as [the husbands]696-the husbands and brothers with whom [they]690-the three young men had come]693-several women , who seemed quite as much at home there as the husbands and brothers with whom they had come . [The two Ferriers]505-the two ferriers were placed on a seat facing the platform , which [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff at once ascended , in company with [the chairman]698-the chairman . [The two]2933-the two were received with cheers and applause , which redoubled when [the chairman]698-the chairman in [his]698-the chairman opening remarks referred to [the count]3057-the count as ' [one who had suffered and worked for years for the cause [he]121-litvinoff was about to advocate]3157-one who had suffered and worked for years for the cause he was about to advocate . '[698-the chairman] Much as [the Ferriers]142-the ferriers had already wondered at [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's mastery of English , [they]505-the two ferriers wondered still more after the first ten minutes on [his]121-litvinoff speech . It is one thing to carry on a social conversation in a tongue not one 's own ; it is another and a widely different thing to be able to hold [a foreign audience]702-a foreign audience , and to sway and move it , to rouse its enthusiasm and to thrill it with horror , at one 's will and pleasure . Yet such was the power of [this young Russian rebel]703-this young russian rebel . [He]121-litvinoff spoke without notes , and without the slightest hesitation . [His]121-litvinoff voice in the opening sentences was very low , but so clear as to be heard distinctly all over [the room]2910-the room . The first part of [his]121-litvinoff address was simply a narrative . In a calm , unimpassioned way [he]121-litvinoff told [[his]121-litvinoff hearers]705-his hearers the story , from its beginning , of a struggle for freedom ; [he]121-litvinoff told [them]705-his hearers how a movement which had begun in a spirit of love , enthusiasm , and self - sacrifice , had been turned by blind tyranny and brutal oppression into one of wild vengeance and bitter relentless hatred . [He]121-litvinoff told [them]705-his hearers how , for a chance expression of sympathy with [the down - trodden peasants]706-the down - trodden peasants ; for the possession of a suppressed book ; sometimes even for less than these offences , for having incurred the personal spite of [some members of [the police]708-the police]707-some members of the police , [aged men]709-aged men and [tender girls]710-tender girls had been , and were , at that moment while [he]121-litvinoff spoke to [them]705-his hearers , being delivered over to [the torture chambers of [the Russian monarch]712-the russian monarch]711-the torture chambers of the russian monarch , to be scourged and starved , to be devoured by disease and riven by madness . [He]121-litvinoff told [them]705-his hearers how tyranny always had treated — how while it exists , tyranny always will treat [the sons of [men]466-men]713-the sons of men . Then , when [many among [[his]121-litvinoff audience]716-his audience]715-many among his audience had broken out into groans of indignation and cries of ' Shame ! '[121-litvinoff] the usual note of [an indignant English audience]717-an indignant english audience , [the speaker]718-the speaker dropped the narrative tone and became argumentative . Here , when [he]121-litvinoff justified [the Nihilists]150-nihilists ' '[121-litvinoff] deeds of death ' as the lawful punishment of [criminals]3158-criminals — punishment inflicted by the only power that has the right to execute vengeance , [the outraged spirit of man]3159-the outraged spirit of man — [he]121-litvinoff seemed to lose for a moment the sympathy of [some of [[his]121-litvinoff hearers]705-his hearers , and certainly of [the Ferriers]142-the ferriers , who like [most Englishmen]3162-most englishmen , believed in the efficacy of Parliamentary reforms , and also forgot , like [most Englishmen]3162-most englishmen , that these patent remedies for all the ills of life are hardly applicable to nations that have [no parliament]3164-no parliament]3160-some of his hearers , and certainly of the ferriers , who like most englishmen , believed in the efficacy of parliamentary reforms , and also forgot , like most englishmen , that these patent remedies for all the ills of life are hardly applicable to nations that have no parliament . With the ready apprehension of [a true orator]3165-a true orator , [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff saw the slight shade of coldness as it passed over some of the upturned faces before [him]121-litvinoff , and , with a consummate skill that was the result either of long practice or oratorical genius , [he]121-litvinoff changed , without seeming to change , the argumentative and defensive attitude for one of stern and glowing denunciation . [His]121-litvinoff voice rang through [the room]2910-the room now like a trumpet - call . A very little of this sort of thing was sufficient to rouse [the men before [him]121-litvinoff]3167-the men before him to stormy approbation , and [Richard]130-richard whispered to [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother that if [any Russian dignitary]3169-any russian dignitary were to come in just then , while [the speaker]718-the speaker was in the full tide of [his]121-litvinoff invective , [he]121-litvinoff would have very much the sort of reception that was given to [the Austrian woman - flogging general]3171-the austrian woman - flogging general some years ago by [the stalwart draymen of [Messrs Barclay & Perkins]160-messrs barclay & perkins]3172-the stalwart draymen of messrs barclay & perkins . Apparently satisfied with the applause of [[his]121-litvinoff audience]716-his audience , in which [he]121-litvinoff seemed to delight and revel , [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff turned from the present and the past , and invited [[his]121-litvinoff hearers]705-his hearers to look with [him]121-litvinoff into the future , '[121-litvinoff] not only of [Russia]26-russia , but of [mankind]719-mankind , ' [he]121-litvinoff said ; '[121-litvinoff] what [the world]2867-the world might be — what it would be . ' Then were done into rhetorical English the concluding pages of that famous Russian pamphlet , '[121-litvinoff] A Prophetic Vision'—the pamphlet for whose sake [Russian peasants]721-russian peasants had braved the spydom of [the police]708-the police , and to hear which read aloud by some of [[their]721-russian peasants fellows]723-their fellows who could read , [they]721-russian peasants had crowded together at nights in [outhouses]724-outhouses and [sheds]725-sheds , by the dim light of tallow candles — the pamphlet for whose possession [St Petersburg]27-st petersburg and [[Moscow]28-moscow [students]727-students]726-moscow students had quarrelled and almost fought , knowing all the time that the mere fact of its being found upon [[their]721-russian peasants persons]728-their persons or among [their]721-russian peasants belongings meant certain imprisonment , and possible death — the pamphlet , in short , the discovery of whose authorship three years back had sent [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff and [[his]121-litvinoff luckless secretary]729-his luckless secretary flying for [the Austrian frontier]730-the austrian frontier . It was certainly a pleasant vision this of [the Russian noble]731-the russian noble , whether it was prophetic or no , a dream of a time when [men]466-men would no longer sow for [other men]733-other men to reap , when the fruits of [the earth]734-the earth would be the inheritance of [all the earth 's children]735-all the earth 's children , and not only of [[her]731-the russian noble priests]736-her priests and [[her]731-the russian noble rulers]737-her rulers ; when , in fact , [rulers]738-rulers would be no more , for all would rule and each would obey ; when [every man]344-every man would do as [he]344-every man liked , and [every man]344-every man would like to do well . All this seemed very high - flown and remote to [the young university critics on the front seats]741-the young university critics on the front seats , though even [they]741-the young university critics on the front seats were moved for a moment or two , by the vibrating tones of [the speaker]718-the speaker , out of the attitude of English stolidity which [they]741-the young university critics on the front seats had carefully kept up during the evening . But those behind [them]741-the young university critics on the front seats were less reserved , and perhaps more credulous — more given to believing in visions ; and when [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff sat down , the walls of [the Agora]743-the agora rang again and again with the cheers of [a sympathetic and delighted audience]744-a sympathetic and delighted audience . When [the chairman]698-the chairman had announced that ' [Mr '[698-the chairman] Litvinoff]143-litvinoff would be happy to answer any questions that might be sug gested by the lecture , there was a moment or two of that awkward silence which always occurs on these occasions , when [everyone]746-everyone feels that there are at least half - a - dozen questions [he]121-litvinoff would like to ask , but experiences the greatest possible difficulty in putting even one into an intelligible shape . At length [a man in one of the far corners of the room]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room rose to put a question . [His]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room accent showed [him]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room to be [a foreigner]2963-a foreigner , but that was not a very remarkable thing in [Soho]23-soho . [He]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room had a scrubby chin and dirty linen , two other characteristics not uncommon in [that region]749-that region . After a preliminary cough [he]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room explained that [his]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room question was rather personal than general , and [he]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room quite allowed that [the lecturer]750-the lecturer was not bound to answer it ; but [he]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room said that , having been in [Russia]26-russia , [he]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room could bear testimony to the truth of all that had been said that evening , and that while in [the south of [Russia]26-russia]751-the south of russia [he]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room had come across a small pamphlet , called ' A Prophetic Vision , '[747-a man in one of the far corners of the room] which [he]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room had been told had been written by [a Count]605-a count [Michael Litvinoff]121-litvinoff . Some parts of the address to - night had reminded [him]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room of that excellent pamphlet , and [he]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room thought it would be interesting to [the audience]692-the audience to know whether [the author of that pamphlet]754-the author of that pamphlet was [the speaker of the evening]755-the speaker of the evening . [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff rose at once . ' [I]121-litvinoff had no idea , '[121-litvinoff] [he]121-litvinoff said , ' that the little brochure would ever be heard of outside [the country]3175-the country for whose children it was written ; but since the question is asked [me]121-litvinoff so frankly to - night , [I]121-litvinoff will answer as frankly — Yes , [I]121-litvinoff wrote it . '[121-litvinoff] An approving murmur ran through [the room]2910-the room , and [the foreigner]757-the foreigner rose again . [He]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room was sorry again to trouble [Citizen Litvinoff]161-litvinoff , but was [he]747-a man in one of the far corners of the room right in supposing ( it had been so reported ) that the discovery of this pamphlet by [the Russian Government]38-the government had occasioned [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's exile ? [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff was very pale as [he]121-litvinoff answered , — ' Yes ; it was that unhappy pamphlet which deprived [me]121-litvinoff of the chance of serving [[my]121-litvinoff country]3176-my country on the scene of action , and which lost [me]121-litvinoff a life [I]121-litvinoff valued above [my]121-litvinoff own — that of [a fellow - countryman of [the audience]692-the audience which [I]121-litvinoff have the pleasure of addressing to - night]3177-a fellow - countryman of the audience which i have the pleasure of addressing to - night — [[my]121-litvinoff secretary]3179-my secretary and friend , whom [I]121-litvinoff loved more than [a brother]3180-a brother . '[121-litvinoff] [His]121-litvinoff voice trembled as [he]121-litvinoff ended . There was another round of applause , and , no more questions being forthcoming , the meeting broke up , and [people]298-people stood talking together in [little groups]759-little groups . [Richard]130-richard was discussing a knotty economic point with [a sturdy carpenter and trades unionist]760-a sturdy carpenter and trades unionist , and [Roland]107-roland , close by , was earnestly questioning [a French Communist to whom [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff had introduced [him]107-roland]761-a french communist to whom litvinoff had introduced him , and was receiving an account of the so - called murder of [the hostages very different from any which had appeared in the daily papers of the period]762-the hostages very different from any which had appeared in the daily papers of the period , when [the Count]3057-the count came up to [them]764-them . ' Excuse [me]121-litvinoff , '[121-litvinoff] [he]121-litvinoff said , ' [I]121-litvinoff am désolé ; but [I]121-litvinoff shall be unable to stay longer . [You]3181-you will be able , doubtless , to pilot [yourselves]3181-you back to civilisation , and will pardon [my]121-litvinoff abrupt departure . [I]121-litvinoff have just seen someone going out of the door whom [I]121-litvinoff 've been trying to catch for the last three months , and [I]121-litvinoff 'm[121-litvinoff] off in pursuit . ' And [he]121-litvinoff was off . As [he]121-litvinoff passed [a small knot of [youths outside the door]3183-youths outside the door]3182-a small knot of youths outside the door [they]3182-a small knot of youths outside the door looked after [him]121-litvinoff , and [one of [them]3182-a small knot of youths outside the door]648-one of them said with a laugh , '[121-litvinoff] Blest if [I]0-i do n't believe [he]121-litvinoff 's after [that handsome gal]765-that handsome gal . What chaps [these foreigners]766-these foreigners are for [the ladies]767-the ladies . ' [The discerning youth]3185-the discerning youth was right . [He]121-litvinoff was after [that girl]3186-that girl — but though [he]121-litvinoff followed [her]3186-that girl and watched [her]3186-that girl into [the house where [she]3186-that girl lived]3187-the house where she lived , [he]121-litvinoff did not speak to [her]3186-that girl . '[767-the ladies] Think twice before [you]768-you speak once is a good rule , ' [he]121-litvinoff said to [himself]121-litvinoff , as [he]121-litvinoff turned westwards , '[0-i] and [I]0-i know where [she]765-that handsome gal lives , at any rate . ' Even discussions on political economy , and historical revelations by [those who helped to make the history]3188-those who helped to make the history , must come to an end at last , and [the Ferriers]142-the ferriers came away , after [Dick]106-dick had received a pressing invitation from [the chairman]698-the chairman to address [the club]3190-the club , and to choose [his]106-dick own subject , and [Roland]107-roland , who had suddenly conceived a passion for [foreigners of a revolutionary character]3191-foreigners of a revolutionary character , had made an appointment with [[his]107-roland Communist acquaintance]3192-his communist acquaintance for an evening in the week . As [they]3193-they passed down [the street]557-the street , [two men standing under a lamp]3195-two men standing under a lamp looked at [them]3193-they with interest . [One]504-one was [the man who had put the questions regarding the pamphlet]3197-the man who had put the questions regarding the pamphlet . [The other]305-the other was [a foreigner]2963-a foreigner too , though [he]305-the other was clean in [his]305-the other attire and had not a scrubby chin , but a long , light silky beard . [He]305-the other wore the slouch hat so much affected by [the High Church Clergy]3200-the high church clergy , and which is popularly supposed to mark [any non - clerical wearer]3201-any non - clerical wearer as [a man of revolutionary views]3202-a man of revolutionary views . [He]305-the other was tall , and pale , and thin , and had very deeply - set hollow eyes , which [he]305-the other kept fixed on [the retreating millowners]3203-the retreating millowners till [they]3203-the retreating millowners turned the corner and went out of sight . Then [he]305-the other said , in a Hungarian dialect , — '[0-i] [[Our]769-our pamphlet - writing friend]770-our pamphlet - writing friend does n't seem to choose [[his]770-our pamphlet - writing friend friends]771-his friends solely among [the poor and needy]772-the poor and needy ; and that is politic to say the least of it . ' '[770-our pamphlet - writing friend] Money seeks money , ' growled [the other]305-the other , '[770-our pamphlet - writing friend] and [he]770-our pamphlet - writing friend has plenty . ' '[773-you] Not so much as [you]773-you 'd suppose . [The greater part of [the Litvinoff property]775-the litvinoff property]774-the greater part of the litvinoff property is quite out of [his]770-our pamphlet - writing friend reach . [[Our]769-our " little father]776-our " little father " takes good care of that . ' '[770-our pamphlet - writing friend] That which [he]770-our pamphlet - writing friend has [he]770-our pamphlet - writing friend takes care to keep , ' said [the other]305-the other . '[770-our pamphlet - writing friend] [I]0-i 'm not so sure ; at anyrate , [he]770-our pamphlet - writing friend uses [his]770-our pamphlet - writing friend tongue , which is a good one , in [our]769-our cause . Speeches like that are good . [A man who can speak so]3206-a man who can speak so is not to be sneered at , and [I]770-our pamphlet - writing friend 'm[770-our pamphlet - writing friend] certain [he]770-our pamphlet - writing friend could not speak like that unless [he]770-our pamphlet - writing friend felt some of it at least . The Mantle of [the Prophet]777-the prophet fits [him]770-our pamphlet - writing friend uncommonly well . ' '[118-morley] [[Morley]118-morley 's Hotel]417-morley 's hotel , Sunday Evening . [DEAR MR FERRIER,—You]162-dear mr ferrier,—you were so full of [Russia]26-russia yesterday afternoon that [you]162-dear mr ferrier,—you made [me]0-i forget to say to [you]162-dear mr ferrier,—you what might have saved [you]162-dear mr ferrier,—you the trouble of answering this by post . Will [you]162-dear mr ferrier,—you and [[your]162-dear mr ferrier,—you brother]2894-your brother dine with [us]769-our ( [papa]361-papa says ) to - morrow evening at seven ? [I]0-i hope [you]162-dear mr ferrier,—you enjoyed [yourselves]162-dear mr ferrier,—you last night . [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i should have done if [I]0-i had been [there]2994-there . With [papa]361-papa 's and [my]0-i kind regards to [you]162-dear mr ferrier,—you and [Mr Roland,—I]163-mr roland,—i am , dear [Mr Ferrier]107-roland , [yours]162-dear mr ferrier,—you very truly , ' [Clare Stanley]139-clare . '[107-roland] [P.S.—Count Litvinoff]164-litvinoff , [[your]107-roland interesting Russian friend]783-your interesting russian friend , will be [here]2895-here . ' [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley smiled to [herself]122-miss stanley rather wickedly as [she]122-miss stanley folded this note . [She]122-miss stanley had noticed that [her]122-miss stanley interest in [the Russian acquaintance]3207-the russian acquaintance did not seem to enhance [theirs]3207-the russian acquaintance , and [she]122-miss stanley thought to [herself]122-miss stanley that whatever the dinner might be at which [those three]3208-those three assisted , it certainly would not be dull for [her]122-miss stanley . In [Derbyshire]12-derbyshire , where [her]122-miss stanley amusements were very limited , [she]122-miss stanley would have thought twice before permitting [herself]122-miss stanley to risk offending [the masters of [Thornsett]30-thornsett]3209-the masters of thornsett , but here that risk only seemed to offer a new form of amusement . But experimenting on the feelings of [these gentlemen]3210-these gentlemen was an entertainment which was somehow not quite so enthralling as it had been , and [she]122-miss stanley now longed , not for [a fresh world to conquer]3211-a fresh world to conquer — here was one ready to [her]122-miss stanley hand — but for the power to conquer it . [She]122-miss stanley would have given something to be able to believe that [she]122-miss stanley had anything like the same power over [this hero of romance]3212-this hero of romance , whom fate had thrown in [her]122-miss stanley way , as [she]122-miss stanley had over [the excellent but commonplace admirers with whom [she]122-miss stanley had amused [herself]122-miss stanley for the last year]3213-the excellent but commonplace admirers with whom she had amused herself for the last year . [Litvinoff]164-litvinoff had distinctly told [her]122-miss stanley that [the goddess of [his]164-litvinoff idolatry]3214-the goddess of his idolatry , [the one mistress of [his]164-litvinoff heart]3215-the one mistress of his heart , was [Liberty]165-liberty , and though this statement was modified in [her]122-miss stanley mind by [her]122-miss stanley recollection of certain glances cast at [herself]122-miss stanley , [she]122-miss stanley yet believed in it enough to feel a not unnatural desire to enter into competition with [that goddess]3216-that goddess . [Her]122-miss stanley classical studies taught [her]122-miss stanley that [women]3217-women had competed successfully with [such rivals]3218-such rivals , and [she]122-miss stanley was not morbidly self - distrustful , especially when a looking - glass was near [her]122-miss stanley . With the letter in [her]122-miss stanley hand [she]122-miss stanley glanced at the mirror over the mantelpiece , and the fair vision of dark - brown lashes , gold - brown waving hair , delicate oval face , and well - shaped if rather large mouth , might have reassured [her]122-miss stanley had [she]122-miss stanley felt any doubts of [her]122-miss stanley own attractions . But the glance [she]122-miss stanley cast at [herself]122-miss stanley over [her]122-miss stanley shoulder was one of saucy triumph , and the smile with which [she]122-miss stanley sealed [her]122-miss stanley letter one of conscious power . Would [she]122-miss stanley have been gratified if [she]122-miss stanley could have seen the effect of [her]122-miss stanley note ? It was not at all with the sort of expression [you]3219-you would expect to see on the face of [a man who had just received a dinner invitation transmitted through [the lady of [his]3220-a man who had just received a dinner invitation transmitted through the lady of his heart from that lady 's papa heart]3221-the lady of his heart from [[that lady]3222-that lady 's papa]3223-that lady 's papa]3220-a man who had just received a dinner invitation transmitted through the lady of his heart from that lady 's papa , that [Richard Ferrier]130-richard passed the note over to [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother next morning . '[783-your interesting russian friend] Here [you]785-you are , ' [he]130-richard said . '[785-you] Bouquet de Nihilist , trebly distilled . ' '[785-you] Well , do n't let ['s]786-'s go , then . ' '[786-'s] Why , [I]0-i thought [you]785-you were so fond of [the Count]3057-the count . [I]0-i wonder [you]785-you do n't jump at it . [I]0-i thought it would please [you]785-you . ' '[0-i] So [I]0-i do like [him]3057-the count — [he]3057-the count 's [a splendid speaker]788-a splendid speaker ; but [I]0-i did n't come to [London]6-london to spend all [my]0-i days and nights with [him]3057-the count , any more than [you]785-you did . Besides , [I]0-i 'm engaged for to - night . '[0-i] ' Oh , are [you]785-you ? Well , [I]0-i think [I]0-i shall go . '[0-i] ' [You]785-you 'd better leave it alone . '[121-litvinoff] [He]121-litvinoff threw down [his]121-litvinoff pen and rose . The article on the Ethics of Revolution on which [he]121-litvinoff was engaged had made but small progress that afternoon . [He]121-litvinoff had felt ever since lunch that go out [he]121-litvinoff must sooner or later , and the prospect was dispiriting . [He]121-litvinoff glanced out of [his]121-litvinoff window as [he]121-litvinoff put on [his]121-litvinoff fur - lined coat . From the windows of [[Morley]118-morley 's Hotel]417-morley 's hotel the view on a fine day is about as cheerful as any that [London]6-london can present — though one may have [one]504-one 's private sentiments respecting the pepper - boxes which emphasise the bald ugliness of the National Gallery , and though one may sometimes wish that [the slave of the lamp]799-the slave of the lamp would bring [St George 's Hall]31-st george 's hall from [Liverpool]14-liverpool and drop it on [that splendid site]800-that splendid site . But this was not a fine day . It was a gloomy , damp , foggy , depressing , suicidal day . The fog had , with its usual adroitness , managed to hide the beauties of everything , and to magnify the uglinesses . [Nelson]166-nelson was absolutely invisible , and the lions looked like half - drowned cats . IT seemed a very long walk [home]303-home to [Alice Hatfield]134-alice , after that Sunday evening lecture . [She]134-alice felt almost as though [she]134-alice could never reach [[her]134-alice lodging]858-her lodging . It was such weary work to keep putting one tired foot before the other . And somehow [she]134-alice was so much more easily tired now than [she]134-alice used to be in [[her]134-alice Derbyshire home]859-her derbyshire home , where [she]134-alice had been used to breast [the steepest hills]860-the steepest hills without even a quickened breath . [She]134-alice wished [she]134-alice had not gone ; [she]134-alice had derived no pleasure from the evening , and had only gained a sharper heartache from the sight of a certain face , which had been , and was still for that matter , the dearest face in [the world]2867-the world to [her]134-alice . [She]134-alice felt re - awakened too in [her]134-alice a liking for a different life among different surroundings ; the life [she]134-alice had given up of [her]134-alice own free will three months ago . [She]134-alice had been much alone in that other life , it is true , and [her]134-alice thoughts had not made solitude sweet ; but [she]134-alice had seen [him]862-him sometimes , and now [she]134-alice was quite alone — always — save for [the few slight acquaintances [she]134-alice had made in [the house where [she]134-alice lived]3187-the house where she lived]863-the few slight acquaintances she had made in the house where she lived . In that other life , which now looked brighter than it had ever done when it was [hers]134-alice , [she]134-alice had been racked and tortured by [her]134-alice conscience , which had at last forced [her]134-alice to try and silence it by renouncing what [she]134-alice had sacrificed everything to gain , and by voluntarily adopting this strange , hard way of living . But now that that gloomy monitor was on [her]134-alice side , it failed to give that comfort and support which [one]504-one is taught to expect from [it]866-it . ' Be virtuous and [you]3261-you will be happy , '[867-a somewhat higher authority ( professor huxley] say the copy - books . [A somewhat higher authority ( [Professor Huxley]170-professor huxley]867-a somewhat higher authority ( professor huxley ) thinks otherwise . ' Virtue is undoubtedly beneficent , '[170-professor huxley] [he]170-professor huxley says , ' but [the man]3262-the man is to be envied to whom [her]3262-the man ways seem in any wise playful ; and though [she]3262-the man may not talk much about suffering and self - denial , [her]3262-the man silence on that topic may be accounted for on the principle ça va sans dire . [She]3262-the man is [an awful goddess , whose ministers are the furies , and whose highest reward is peace]3263-an awful goddess , whose ministers are the furies , and whose highest reward is peace . '[170-professor huxley] [Alice Hatfield]134-alice had n't read [Huxley]170-professor huxley , but if [she]134-alice had [she]134-alice would have agreed with [him]170-professor huxley in this ; and now it seemed as though the furies were driving [her]134-alice along [the streets]2969-the streets towards [that miserable home of [hers]134-alice , where , so far , no dove of peace had folded its wings]869-that miserable home of hers , where , so far , no dove of peace had folded its wings . It is given to all of [us]870-us , at one time or another , to repent — more or less — of the evil ; but [many of [us]870-us]871-many of us also know what it is to look back , with something like remorse , on what [we]870-us believe to have been the good . And good and evil , get so mixed up sometimes , when [we]870-us have often heard [the world]2867-the world 's ' right '[134-alice] skilfully controverted and made to seem wrong , by the tongue whose eloquence once made wrong seem to [us]870-us right . [Alice]134-alice had to collect all [her]134-alice energies to enable [her]134-alice to climb the steep dark stairs which led to [[her]134-alice room]2996-her room , and when [she]134-alice had gained [it]2996-her room at last , and had lighted [her]134-alice little benzoline lamp , [she]134-alice sank down on [her]134-alice chair bedstead , exhausted and breathless . What [a hateful room]874-a hateful room [it]2996-her room was ; how cold , and cheerless , and wretched . The few poor articles of furniture did not relieve its bareness in the least . There was no fire , of course , and [her]134-alice little lamp quite failed to light up the dark corners . There must be something wrong with that lamp — it was going out surely — [the room]2910-the room was growing so dark ; or was it [her]134-alice eyes from which the power of seeing was going ? [The room]2910-the room seemed to swim before [her]134-alice sight , and a feeling of deadly faintness came over [her]134-alice , a horrible sensation of going through the floor . [She]134-alice staggered to [her]134-alice feet and drank some water , which gave [her]134-alice strength to go unsteadily down to the floor below , and to knock at [the landlady]844-the landlady 's door . ' Oh , [I]844-the landlady am so ill — so ill ! [I]844-the landlady think [I]844-the landlady 'm[844-the landlady] dying , ' [she]134-alice said , holding out both hands as [the woman]3264-the woman appeared ; '[0-i] help [me]0-i . ' Then [she]134-alice knew no more . [Her]134-alice troubles , [her]134-alice tiredness , [her]134-alice regrets , [her]134-alice very self , all were swallowed up in the horror of great darkness that overwhelmed [her]134-alice . '[0-i] Here 's a nice set out , ' grumbled [Mrs Fludger]171-mrs fludger , as [[her]171-mrs fludger lodger]3265-her lodger fell at [her]171-mrs fludger feet ; '[0-i] as if [one]504-one had n't enough troubles o ' one 's own — what with [Jenny]172-miss jenny being out o '[0-i] work , and [the master on the booze]879-the master on the booze since Friday . '[172-miss jenny] If [she]880-she do n't soon come round [I]0-i 'll send [Joe]173-joe for [the doctor]2896-the doctor , ' said [the mother]3271-the mother . '[0-i] [You]173-joe never knows what may happen . ' Then [Mrs Fludger]171-mrs fludger dashed cold water in [the patient]3272-the patient 's face , slapped [her]367-the girl hands with a vigour that would have brought tears to [her]367-the girl eyes had [she]367-the girl been conscious , and made a horrible smell with the benzoline lamp and a pigeon 's feather hastily begged from [a lodger who had leanings ornithological]3273-a lodger who had leanings ornithological . ' [Joe Fludger]173-joe was not particularly pleased at being sent . [He]173-joe was busy just then shaking up a mangy kitten and a recently - acquired guinea - pig in a box , with a view of getting [them]3277-them to fight , which [they]3277-them showed no signs of doing , and [he]173-joe did not care to relinquish this enthralling pastime until [he]173-joe had compassed [his]173-joe end . [She]134-alice now had that certainty which is a spring of secret happiness to [so many women]893-so many women , to [some only a fresh care and anxiety]894-some only a fresh care and anxiety , and to some , alas ! the sign and token of social banishment — the warrant of disgrace and despair . [Doctor Moore]175-doctor moore spoke kindly , and with no note of censure in [his]175-doctor moore voice . [He]2896-the doctor had a naturally tender heart , and long years of practice in [a poor neighbourhood]895-a poor neighbourhood had developed [his]2896-the doctor sympathies , instead of blunting them , as , unfortunately , happens in too many cases . [He]2896-the doctor was [an old man]896-an old man now , and this was an old story to [him]2896-the doctor ; but [his]2896-the doctor eyes were still sharp enough to see that [the girl before [him]2896-the doctor]897-the girl before him did not belong to [that class of patients to whom such an announcement would have meant little more than a temporary inconvenience and a trifling subsequent expense]898-that class of patients to whom such an announcement would have meant little more than a temporary inconvenience and a trifling subsequent expense . [The landlady]844-the landlady accompanied [him]2896-the doctor [downstairs]834-downstairs in a halo of apology for having ' such like '[844-the landlady] in [[her]844-the landlady house]902-her house , and when [she]844-the landlady had lighted [him]2896-the doctor out [she]844-the landlady climbed once more , protesting , to [the attic]903-the attic , and having administered the brandy as prescribed , came away , after bidding [the girl]367-the girl ' good - night '[844-the landlady] not unkindly . Besides , there might be difficulties about rent , and even a want of money for the necessaries of life — and [Mrs Fludger]171-mrs fludger was afraid to trust [her]171-mrs fludger tender heart . Does it ? And for [Mrs Fludger]171-mrs fludger , who had to look sharp after every halfpenny , and who knew no higher morality than that taught in the precept , ' Take care of number one , '[171-mrs fludger] which to [her]171-mrs fludger meant the number nine , of whom [Miss Jenny]172-miss jenny was [the eldest]915-the eldest , there was more excuse than there is for [the theoretical philanthropists who wear purple and fine linen , and fare sumptuously every day]916-the theoretical philanthropists who wear purple and fine linen , and fare sumptuously every day . ' And so it happened that [her]171-mrs fludger worldly goods were taken away on a hand - barrow , [she]171-mrs fludger [herself]171-mrs fludger walking beside it — whither [Mrs Fludger]171-mrs fludger was careful not to inquire ; and [Dr Moore]174-dr moore , coming at noon , received the comforting intelligence that [the girl]367-the girl had gone [home]303-home to [[her]171-mrs fludger people]3294-her people ; for [Mrs Fludger]171-mrs fludger , like [so many others]3295-so many others , thought that [her]171-mrs fludger advice once given could not fail to be taken . IT was a bright , perfectly clear , moonlight night , one of those nights in which there seems to be no atmosphere , in which the smallest architectural details of [every building]3296-every building show with even a greater distinctness than in mid - sunshine . The great full moon and the vast unfathomable expanse overhead seemed to have cast a spell of their own peace over even [London]6-london 's unpeaceful heart . [The streets]2969-the streets were empty , for the night had worn itself away to the only hour at which [they]2969-the streets are really deserted . The clocks had just expressed [their]2969-the streets different views on the subject of two A.M. The night was so clear that [Alice Hatfield]134-alice , though [her]925-she eyes were smarting and aching , thought [she]925-she could see the hands on the big clock of [St Paul 's]35-st paul 's as [she]925-she came on to [Blackfriars '[110-god] Bridge]36-blackfriars ' bridge . [She]925-she walked slowly , and when [she]925-she reached [the second arch]926-the second arch [she]925-she stopped and leaned [her]925-she elbows on the parapet . How still the night was ! The tide was high , and had just started on its journey seawards ; it seemed to flow in one unbroken sheet save for the stir and fret that it made round the supports of [the bridge]927-the bridge . The lights along [the Embankment]601-the embankment , with their perfect reflections , might have seemed almost Venetian to [anyone inclined to take a more rose - coloured view of things]929-anyone inclined to take a more rose - coloured view of things than [she]925-she . To [her]925-she they only brought a maddening remembrance of the time when [she]925-she — not alone then — had first seen [them]930-them from the windows of [the Arundel Hotel]931-the arundel hotel . The noise of the water against [the bridge]927-the bridge was very like the sound of the waters rushing round the stones in [the Derbyshire streams]933-the derbyshire streams — only those waters had always made a song that was to be enjoyed , not understood — and this dark tide , as it broke against the stone , seemed to be whispering constantly some message to [her]925-she , which [she]925-she as constantly , but vainly , tried to catch . It made [her]925-she shiver . [She]925-she turned and leaned back against the parapet . The other side of [the bridge]927-the bridge was in the ruthless hands of [the paviors , who had literally left no stone unturned in order to produce that utter chaos in which the heart of the contractor]935-the paviors , who had literally left no stone unturned in order to produce that utter chaos in which the heart of the contractor delighteth . The large slabs of paving - stones , standing and lying about in all sorts of positions , made [the place]936-the place look — ugh!—like [a graveyard]937-a graveyard , and the displaced earth and heaps of sand looked like half - made graves , in which the spade and pick of [the sexton]938-the sexton had ceased to clink . There was a bright red spot of fire about a hundred yards from [her]925-she — [someone]399-someone was comfortable beside it , [she]925-she supposed — and somehow [she]925-she hated that patch of red light more than anything else in the whole picture . [Alice]134-alice had found [a fresh lodging]940-a fresh lodging easily enough , and this time [she]134-alice had adopted the badge of marital servitude , and had taken another name . [The new room]941-the new room struck [her]134-alice as cheerless and unwelcoming , and [her]134-alice poor possessions looked less friendly than they had done in [the old attic at [Spray 's Buildings]24-spray 's buildings]942-the old attic at spray 's buildings . [Her]134-alice bundle of work had been brought with the rest , but [she]134-alice seemed to have no heart to begin it , nor yet to get [herself]134-alice food , and [she]134-alice sat on there , hour after hour , till the sense of complete isolation grew too much for [her]134-alice . At [[Spray]168-spray 's Buildings]811-spray 's buildings [she]134-alice had had [no friends]944-no friends , and had valued [[her]134-alice few acquaintances]945-her few acquaintances but slightly , and [she]134-alice did not realise the amount of comfort that could be got out of a chance meeting with [Miss Fludger]172-miss jenny on the stairs until such meetings were things of the past . ' [I]134-alice will go out , '[134-alice] [she]134-alice had said , rising at last with a feeling that even in strange and unregarding faces there would be companionship of a kind . So [she]134-alice had left [[her]134-alice room]2996-her room and had wandered about , passing more than one spot hung thickly round with memories of [her]134-alice short day of sunshine . Then when night fell [she]134-alice felt that [she]134-alice could not go back to [that new inhospitable room of [hers]134-alice]947-that new inhospitable room of hers . [She]134-alice pictured [it]947-that new inhospitable room of hers dark , cheerless , and cold , shuddered as [she]134-alice thought of the broad streak of moonlight which would come through the uncurtained window , and lie on that bare floor . How dark the corners of [the room]2910-the room would be . So [she]134-alice wandered on , and [the people]407-the people grew scarcer and scarcer , and [she]134-alice grew fainter and fainter . [She]134-alice would have been glad of food now , but all [the shops]950-the shops were shut , and when [she]134-alice came to [[Blackfriars]37-blackfriars ' Bridge]3298-blackfriars ' bridge [she]134-alice was too tired to go any further . And as [she]134-alice stood and looked at [the river]3299-the river gleaming in the moonlight , the question came into [her]134-alice mind . '[134-alice] Need [she]951-she go further ? Was not this the fitting end for such as [she]951-she ? ' A spasm of madness caught [her]134-alice . What an easy way out of all [her]134-alice troubles ; what an obvious solution of all [her]134-alice difficulties ! [She]134-alice walked straight before [her]134-alice , stooping to pass under the protecting pole in the middle of [the road]3300-the road , falling once over a block of stone and cutting [her]134-alice hands , [she]134-alice thought . [She]134-alice climbed [the tomb - like stones]3301-the tomb - like stones , and in a moment was on [her]134-alice hands and knees partly on the parapet and partly on some stones that leaned against it . [She]134-alice looked over without changing [her]134-alice attitude for quite a minute . It made [her]134-alice giddy to look down . [She]134-alice could not stand up , as [she]134-alice had pictured [herself]134-alice doing when that madness first came upon [her]134-alice . [She]134-alice could drop over , though , and [she]134-alice would . Courage ! In another minute it would all be over . [She]134-alice had made a movement to turn [her]134-alice feet towards [the water]3302-the water , when [her]134-alice shoulders were caught by two hands , and [she]134-alice was lifted bodily back on to [the bridge]927-the bridge . '[951-she] [[You]952-you little fool]953-you little fool ! ' said [the owner of the hands]3304-the owner of the hands , which gave [her]134-alice a little shake before [they]3304-the owner of the hands loosened [their]3304-the owner of the hands hold of [her]134-alice . '[952-you] What do [you]952-you want to go drinking of that poison for ? It ai n't fit to drown a cat in , let alone [a human woman female]954-a human woman female . ' [Alice]134-alice 's face was in [her]134-alice hands . [She]134-alice had sunk down against the stones on which [she]134-alice had climbed before . [She]134-alice shivered . '[0-i] Oh , [I]0-i am so cold ! ' [she]134-alice said , almost in a whisper , without taking [her]134-alice hands away . The madness had died out of [her]134-alice completely . '[0-i] [You]952-you 'd have been colder if it had n't been for [me]0-i ; and oh , the taste in [your]952-you mouth would have been something dreadful . Come and have a drop of [my]0-i missus 's coffee , by [my]0-i fire ; it 's a deal sweeter than wot [you]952-you was after . [The Government]38-the government ought to take it up , ' [he]0-i said , sententiously , but whether [he]0-i meant [the river]3299-the river , the coffee , or the fire , [he]0-i did not explain . [He]0-i helped [her]134-alice to rise , took [her]134-alice by the elbow in a sort of amateur - constable way , and led [her]134-alice over and round the snares and pitfalls which lay between [them]3306-them and that red eye which had seemed to watch [them]3306-them . It was a sort of openwork iron pot , full of hot coals , and a species of shelter was contrived round [it]3307-it by means of a judicious arrangement of paving stones and tarpaulin . When [he]0-i had made [her]134-alice sit down on an inverted basket placed in the warmest corner by the fire , [she]134-alice glanced at [him]0-i for the first time . [He]0-i was [a big , burly , black - bearded man]3308-a big , burly , black - bearded man ; [he]0-i had a kindly expression , and merry eyes , with a sort of cast in one of them which made it difficult to be sure which way [he]0-i was looking . '[0-i] Still cold ? ' [he]0-i asked , with one eye on [her]134-alice and the other apparently on the pole star . '[0-i] Have this coat ; [I]0-i 'm warm enough . [I]0-i had to hurry up so to catch [you]134-alice , [young woman]3309-young woman . '[0-i] [He]0-i threw a rough pea - jacket round [her]955-her as [she]955-her said , looking down , — ' How did [you]0-i catch [me]0-i ? Where did [you]0-i come from ? '[0-i] ' Where did [I]0-i come from ? Why , from [here]2895-here . Directly [I]0-i saw [you]134-alice cross [the road]3300-the road [I]0-i knew what was up . [I]0-i never would let [anyone]495-anyone go into that ditch if [I]0-i could help it . [It]3313-it ought to belong to [the Commissioners of Sewers]3314-the commissioners of sewers , '[0-i] [he]0-i ended , having apparently changed [his]0-i mind concerning the administrative functions of ' Government . '[0-i] ' [I]956-i 've come from [Gray 's Inn Road]39-gray 's inn road , '[956-i] [she]956-i said . ' How lucky , now . [I]956-i live that way . [He]0-i was [a man whose occupation caused [him]0-i to pass a good deal of [his]0-i time on [bridges]3318-bridges]3317-a man whose occupation caused him to pass a good deal of his time on bridges , and [he]0-i knew [the river]3299-the river and the smells thereof . '[956-i] No , ' said [Alice]134-alice , '[0-i] [I]0-i 'm not very hard up , and [I]0-i 'm[0-i] in work , too ; but [I]0-i moved into [a new place]958-a new place to - day , and [I]0-i felt too lonely to bother about dinner or anything , and [I]0-i expect going without made [me]0-i a bit wild and soft like . ' '[0-i] Have some of this , ' was [his]0-i answer , and soon [Alice]134-alice began to feel a returning sense of physical comfort steal through [her]134-alice , as [she]134-alice sat resting by the cheering fire , drinking the hot coffee from a tin mug , with a slice of bread and cheese on [her]134-alice knee , while [[her]134-alice companion]3320-her companion kept up a constant ripple of somewhat inconsequent talk , which was [his]0-i notion of '[0-i] making conversation ' for [[his]0-i guest]3321-his guest . [She]134-alice took [her]134-alice part in the dialogue with an ease which surprised [herself]134-alice . It seems very strange that [people]298-people should not be more affected than [they]298-people generally are by having been face to face with death . The fact is , that it is so impossible to realise subjectively what death is , that [people]298-people feel less awestruck at having been so near it than [they]298-people do at having been within an ace of having [their]298-people leg broken , or of being marked with small - pox . Perhaps this is why [so many men]3324-so many men sleep sound sleeps and eat hearty breakfasts just before execution . It was a long time since [anyone]495-anyone had thought it worth while to talk so much to [Alice]134-alice , and [she]134-alice felt so interested , and withal so comfortable , that it never occurred to [her]134-alice that this interlude of warmth and companionship must soon be over , and that then [she]134-alice would have to face [the desolate streets]3326-the desolate streets and [that cheerless room]3327-that cheerless room . Of seeking again the chill refuge from which [[her]134-alice new acquaintance]3328-her new acquaintance had saved [her]134-alice [she]134-alice certainly never thought . That madness was over . [He]960-the stranger wore a grey military cloak with a high collar , and a large soft felt hat . The brim was turned up in a rather unusual way in front , and leaving exposed as it did a broad , well - shaped forehead and piercing grey eyes , gave to [the whole face]962-the whole face a bold and daring look . ' AT the moment when [Mrs Fludger]171-mrs fludger 's sense of propriety was being outraged by what [she]171-mrs fludger termed , in a subsequent recital of [her]171-mrs fludger wrongs to [her]171-mrs fludger first - floor front , '[992-that shindy on the stairs] [that shindy on the stairs]992-that shindy on the stairs , ' [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley was lying on the sofa in [the sitting - room at [Morley 's Hotel]42-morley 's hotel]3368-the sitting - room at morley 's hotel , reading the novel that had taken the last season by storm , and pushed everything else out of sight on the bookstalls . [She]122-miss stanley had just come back to the world of solid furniture and characterless window curtains ; [her]122-miss stanley first waking thought was that some tea would be worth anything to [her]122-miss stanley just then — except the trouble of getting up to ring for it — and [she]122-miss stanley wished dreamily that [waiters]3373-waiters could know by intuition when [they]3373-waiters were wanted . '[889-ma'am] [she]889-ma'am said , opening [her]889-ma'am eyes very wide . ' What can [you]0-i mean ? Surely [you]0-i have n't quarrelled ? '[997-i] [He]997-i spoke in that particularly even and monotonous voice which , with [some people]998-some people , is always the token of suppressed agitation . ' '[0-i] Why , surely , [Mr Roland]107-roland 's done nothing wrong ? ' '[0-i] Yes , ' said [Richard]130-richard , looking straight at [her]139-clare for the first time that afternoon , '[0-i] [I]0-i shall lose [my]0-i living , and more , the hope of [my]0-i life ; but at anyrate , thank [God]110-god , [I]0-i keep [my]0-i honour , and [he]107-roland has lost even that . ' [Clare]139-clare returned [his]130-richard gaze steadily . '[0-i] [You]0-i have no right to say that , unless [you]0-i are quite , quite , quite sure , ' [she]139-clare said rather haughtily . [She]139-clare had no motive for that little speech , save a natural love for fair play , but [he]0-i read in it a desire to champion [[his]0-i brother]2917-his brother against [his]2917-his brother attack , and [he]0-i was goaded to the point of indiscretion . '[0-i] [I]0-i am so sure , ' [he]0-i answered bitterly , '[0-i] that sooner than touch hands in friendship with [him]107-roland again , [I]0-i am giving up all [my]0-i chances in life , and with [them]1005-them the hope of winning [you]1006-you . Do n't say anything , ' [he]0-i went on , seeing that [she]1006-you was about to speak . '[0-i] [I]0-i had no right to say that . [I]0-i did not mean to annoy [you]1006-you with any hint of [my]0-i vain devotion , but [I]0-i could n't help saying it . Consider it unsaid if [you]1006-you like , but do n't be vexed with [me]0-i . There is one thing [I]0-i must ask [you]1006-you . [I]0-i should be untrue to [my]0-i love for [you]1006-you if [I]0-i did not ask it . Do not let [[my]0-i brother]3376-my brother win what [his]3376-my brother fault forbids [me]0-i to try for . ' [She]1006-you rose . '[0-i] [I]0-i have given [you]1006-you no right to talk in that way , nor to ask [me]0-i any such promise , and [I]0-i will promise nothing since [I]0-i know nothing , ' [she]1006-you said , indignantly . '[0-i] Then at least it shall not be [my]0-i fault , ' said [Richard]130-richard with equal fire , '[0-i] if [you]1006-you do not know what [every woman [he]3376-my brother comes near]1008-every woman he comes near ought to know . [He]3376-my brother is not free to offer love to [any woman]1009-any woman . [He]3376-my brother owes all the love [he]3376-my brother is capable of to [a woman [he]3376-my brother has ruined and deserted]1010-a woman he has ruined and deserted . ' [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley looked at [him]130-richard coldly and contemptuously . [He]130-richard stood silent a moment , and in that moment felt the utter falseness of the step [he]130-richard had taken . [She]122-miss stanley turned slightly away from [him]130-richard , and [he]130-richard knew that there were no more words to be said on either side . '[3376-my brother] Good - bye , ' [he]130-richard said ; '[3376-my brother] [I]0-i shall not be at all likely to trouble [you]1006-you again . ' '[0-i] Good afternoon , ' [she]122-miss stanley said , without moving ; and [he]130-richard went out . Now , indeed , everything was over . [Clare]139-clare , left to [herself]139-clare , sank down again in [her]139-clare low chair , and knitted [her]139-clare brows in annoyed meditation . Quarrels , separations , and crushing impertinent people with '[0-i] dynamic glances ' were all very well in novels , but in real life it was much nicer to have things go smoothly . [She]122-miss stanley could not quite foresee all the complications that this quarrel might lead to , but [she]122-miss stanley knew that it would make a great difference at [Firth Vale]11-firth vale . [Aspinshaw]105-aspinshaw would be duller than ever . Would [Roland]107-roland come this evening ? Could what [Dick]106-dick had said be true ? If it was , [she]122-miss stanley thought , [he]106-dick had no right to say it to [her]122-miss stanley ; and it was mean of [him]106-dick to say it to [anyone behind [[his]106-dick brother]2917-his brother 's back]3382-anyone behind his brother 's back . [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff would be sure to come , at anyrate . '[1011-he] Let 's hope [he]1011-he 'll be entertaining , ' [she]122-miss stanley said to [herself]122-miss stanley . [Roland]107-roland was thoroughly unhinged by the events of the afternoon , which to [him]107-roland had been so utterly unexpected , and were so completely unexplained . [He]107-roland felt sure that [their]1021-our quarrel hinged on a mistake , but what that mistake was , or what its subject was , [he]107-roland was at a loss to conjecture . [Clare]139-clare was listless and distraite . [She]139-clare was intensely annoyed by the remembrance of that little episode with [Richard]130-richard , and , though [she]139-clare told [herself]139-clare that [she]139-clare did not believe a word [he]2894-your brother had said , [she]139-clare found it hard to forget it and to treat [Roland]107-roland as usual . [She]139-clare had not had a chance of telling [[her]139-clare father]391-her father anything about [Richard]130-richard , for [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff had been punctual , and [Mr Stanley]119-mr stanley had come back from [the City]3372-the city late , and cross as well as late ; and [the old gentleman]2966-the old gentleman 's continued references to [the absentee]3398-the absentee , and [his]2894-your brother regrets for the '[2894-your brother] sudden business ' which had prevented [him]2894-your brother from being present , made matters several degrees more uncomfortable than they would otherwise have been . [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff had [his]121-litvinoff own reasons for not feeling very joyous on this occasion , but [he]121-litvinoff had not had three years of wandering in exile among all sorts and conditions of [men]466-men for nothing , and [he]121-litvinoff was able to put [his]121-litvinoff own personal feelings on one side , and to do what was exacted by the proprieties . [No one]494-no one could have told from [his]121-litvinoff manner that [he]121-litvinoff had a care in [the world]2867-the world . More than this , [he]121-litvinoff succeeded after a while in inspiring [the others]3402-the others with some of [his]121-litvinoff own powers of self - repression ; and though [they]3402-the others did not perhaps feel more festive , [they]3402-the others made a successful effort to seem so , in order to be not out of harmony with what seemed to [them]3402-the others to be [his]121-litvinoff gaiety and light - heartedness . '[121-litvinoff] THE only good thing about life is that it 's interesting , but it 's quite possible to have too much interest at once , and then it begins to be irritating and depressing , and the best sedative is tobacco , and the best stimulant is whisky . ' So said [the Count]3057-the count when [he]3057-the count returned to [[his]3057-the count room]3391-his room , and [he]3057-the count accordingly acted on [his]3057-the count convictions . But both whisky and tobacco seemed to fail of the effect expected of [them]3448-them . '[1038-the millowner] So , [these sons of [the millowner]1038-the millowner]1037-these sons of the millowner — [these playfellows of childhood]1039-these playfellows of childhood , [these friends of innocence]1040-these friends of innocence — are [men]466-men , not ugly , [not fools]1042-not fools , and not better than [[their]1037-these sons of the millowner fellows]723-their fellows . [This Richard]130-richard is apparently so much interested as to go nearly mad about [her]1044-her disappearance ; and as for [Roland]107-roland , there must have been pretty strong grounds before [[his]107-roland brother]2917-his brother would have started that charming scene on the staircase . [I]0-i wonder if conscience had as much to do with [her]1044-her conduct as [I]0-i believed . '[391-her father] To [Mr Stanley]119-mr stanley 's idea it was quite as safe to send [a daughter]1056-a daughter alone to [the National Gallery]46-the national gallery as to send [her]1056-a daughter to [church]649-church on a week day .
