' With which [she]1062-she smoothed [his]119-mr stanley hair , arranged [his]119-mr stanley tie , kissed [him]119-mr stanley on both cheeks , and watched [him]119-mr stanley out of sight from the window . Then [she]1062-she went and wrapped [herself]1062-she in a good deal of brown fur , and walked quickly across [the square]3460-the square to the hideous casket in which [the nation]3461-the nation cherishes its gems of art . [She]1062-she was wandering from one picture to another in a desultory sort of way , and thinking , it must be confessed , more of [her]1062-she own affairs than of the paintings , when [she]1062-she almost ran against [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , who was standing , [his]121-litvinoff hat off and [his]121-litvinoff hands behind [him]121-litvinoff , in rapt contemplation of the Martyrdom of [Saint Somebody]185-saint somebody . [He]121-litvinoff turned and bowed , with an air of pleased surprise . [She]1062-she had never seen [him]121-litvinoff look so little English — so very foreign . '[119-mr stanley] Ah ! this is good fortune , ' [he]121-litvinoff said ; '[1062-she] [[your]1063-your father]2900-your father is with [you]1063-your ? ' '[2900-your father] No , ' said [Clare]139-clare . '[2900-your father] [Papa]361-papa does n't care about pictures , except pictures of dead fish and game , and horses and fat cattle ; and [I]0-i do n't care about [the City]3372-the city — at least , not the parts of [it]3372-the city that [he]361-papa goes to — and this is [a sort of paddock where [I]0-i am allowed to run loose when [he]361-papa is away]1067-a sort of paddock where i am allowed to run loose when he is away . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i often spend an hour [here]2895-here ; [I]0-i find pictures help [one]504-one to think . How do [you]0-i like this [Claude]186-claude ? ' Then the conversation was all picture for a while , and at last [they]3462-they sat down on one of the few seats provided by the munificence of [a thoughtful Administration for such lovers of art as care to stay in [the Gallery]2948-the gallery]3463-a thoughtful administration for such lovers of art as care to stay in the gallery long enough to get tired . [They]3462-they were silent for a little while . '[0-i] Are [you]0-i not well , [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley ? ' [he]0-i said presently . '[122-miss stanley] Oh , dear [me]0-i , yes ; [I]0-i 'm very well . Do [I]122-miss stanley look ill ? '[122-miss stanley] [she]122-miss stanley asked quite frankly , looking at [him]0-i with [her]122-miss stanley eyebrows raised . ' Ah , no ; [you]0-i look — '[0-i] [he]0-i hesitated , ' as [you]0-i always do , '[0-i] [he]0-i ended , as though that was not what [he]0-i would have liked to say . ' Why do [you]0-i ask , then ? '[0-i] ' Because [I]0-i fancied last night that [you]0-i were in some kind of pain , and [I]0-i have been uneasy ever since about it . '[0-i] ' Last night ? [You]0-i 're[0-i] very kind : there was n't the least ground for [your]0-i uneasiness . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i was not [the only one who thought so]1070-the only one who thought so . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i am afraid the evening must have been very dull , then , if it gave [two people]1071-two people that impression . ' '[187-dulness] Oh , [dulness]187-dulness was out of the question to [me]0-i , ' [he]0-i said , with an eloquent look . '[187-dulness] But [I]0-i suppose [we]1072-we could n't expect [Mr Roland]107-roland to be very cheerful , under the circumstances . ' '[187-dulness] What circumstances ? ' questioned [Clare]139-clare , who was beginning to feel rather uncomfortable . '[107-roland] [He]107-roland has had what [I]0-i believe in [England]15-england is termed a " row " with [[his]107-roland brother]2917-his brother . ' '[0-i] How do [you]0-i know ? ' [she]139-clare asked , quickly . '[0-i] Oh , [I]0-i beg [your]0-i pardon . ' '[0-i] Never do that ; but , indeed , had [you]0-i not asked [me]0-i , [I]0-i was going to tell [you]0-i , for [I]0-i am in a difficulty . Although [I]0-i know [your]0-i language well , [I]0-i do not so well know [your]0-i social customs . Shall [we]1074-we see [Mr Richard]130-richard again , do [you]0-i think ? ' The question was put so innocently , and [the Count]3057-the count ap peared so really perplexed , that [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley stifled the evasive answer that first occurred to [her]122-miss stanley , and said simply , — '[0-i] No , [I]0-i do n't . ' '[0-i] Then a great part of [my]0-i difficulty vanishes . [I]0-i am ashamed to trouble [you]0-i about [my]0-i dilemmas ; but [I]0-i have been wondering whether [I]0-i ought to know [them]1075-them both , since [they]1075-them have so quarrelled , or whether it is not incumbent on [me]0-i to take one side or the other . ' '[0-i] If [you]0-i take sides at all , ' said [Clare]139-clare , '[0-i] [you]0-i should take the side [you]0-i think right . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i am here amongst [Englishmen]518-englishmen . Being in [Rome]48-rome [I]0-i must do as [Rome]48-rome does , and [I]0-i do not know what is right and wrong to [English people]1077-english people . ' '[0-i] Right is right all [the world]2867-the world over , ' said [Clare]139-clare , adding , as a saving clause , '[0-i] if [you]0-i can only see which is right . But [you]0-i are not [the only one who is in a dilemma]1079-the only one who is in a dilemma . ' Then , driven by an irresistible desire to know how the quarrel struck [him]0-i , [she]139-clare asked [him]0-i directly , — '[0-i] Which do [you]0-i think is in the wrong ? ' '[0-i] There are some things which [brothers]1000-brothers might pardon in each other , but which to [other men]733-other men would be unpardonable . ' '[0-i] Do [you]0-i think , then , that [Roland Ferrier]107-roland has done anything unpardonable ? ' [She]139-clare had felt intensely annoyed at the turn the conversation had taken , but since it had taken this turn , [she]139-clare was determined to learn as much from it as possible . '[0-i] [I]0-i do n't think [he]107-roland has done anything [the world]2867-the world would not pardon , and [we]1083-we must remember that the greater part of the fault lies in [his]107-roland bringing up . ' [He]0-i said this with a delicate air of chivalrously making the best of a bad cause . '[107-roland] If [the world]2867-the world pardons the unpardonable , ' said [Clare]139-clare , feeling that [she]139-clare was skating on very thin ice , and not quite knowing how to get back to [the bank]3466-the bank again , '[107-roland] so much the worse for [the world]2867-the world . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i knew [you]0-i would say that . ' '[0-i] And , ' [she]139-clare went on , forgetting how little [she]139-clare had told [[her]139-clare companion]3320-her companion , '[0-i] if [I]0-i could only be sure that all [Richard]130-richard said was true , [I]0-i would accept [no one]494-no one 's ruling but [my]0-i own on such a question . ' [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's eyes gave one little flash at the admission contained in this speech , but [he]121-litvinoff said quite quietly , — '[130-richard] Well , [no one]494-no one can possibly know . [I]0-i presume [he]130-richard must at least believe it . ' '[130-richard] Yes , [he]130-richard certainly does . This quarrel , as [you]0-i perhaps know , means ruin to [them]1088-they both . ' '[188-ruin] [Ruin]188-ruin ! ' [he]121-litvinoff cried ; '[188-ruin] then it must not go on . ' '[188-ruin] [You]0-i are very good to take such an interest in [the Ferriers]142-the ferriers . ' '[0-i] Ah , ' [he]121-litvinoff said sadly , '[0-i] [I]0-i have known ruin , and it is hard if [the innocent one]1089-the innocent one suffers with [the guilty]1090-the guilty . ' [He]121-litvinoff looked about as little like [a ruined man]3468-a ruined man as it was possible to be . [His]121-litvinoff dress was perfect , though it had a certain foreign air that was not to be traced to that too great prominence of shirt collar and prodigality of cuff , that shininess of hat and boot , that exuberant floridity of necktie , which are the signet of the flâneur of [the boulevards]3469-the boulevards . Above all , [his]121-litvinoff nails were unexceptionable . '[1088-they] [[Their]1088-they father]1091-their father left it in [his]1091-their father will , ' said [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley , bluntly , glad to get away from the subject of [Roland]107-roland 's possible lâches , '[1088-they] that if [they]1088-they quarrelled [they]1088-they lost all [their]1088-they money . ' '[1091-their father] [They]1088-they were ever given to quarrelling , then ? ' asked [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff . '[1091-their father] No , [I]0-i do n't think so ; but [Mr Ferrier]107-roland was old and very funny . ' '[107-roland] [He]107-roland seems to have been prophetic in this instance ; or perhaps [he]107-roland knew what [they]1088-they were likely to quarrel about . ' [Clare]139-clare stroked [her]139-clare muff with [her]139-clare kid - gloved hand , and wondered whether [the late Mr Ferrier]107-roland had thought [they]1088-they were likely to quarrel about [her]139-clare . '[107-roland] This affair of [the unfortunate girl [Alice Hatfield]134-alice]1092-the unfortunate girl alice hatfield — ' [he]0-i was beginning , when [Clare]139-clare rose . '[134-alice] It is quite time [I]0-i went back , ' [she]139-clare said chillingly , and [she]139-clare turned and walked out . [He]0-i followed [her]139-clare humbly . When [they]1088-they had passed down [the steps]3470-the steps [he]0-i said , — '[0-i] [I]0-i have offended [you]0-i , but [you]0-i must forgive [me]0-i . [I]0-i am ignorant of English customs . [You]0-i had talked to [me]0-i of the misdeed , and it did not seem to be wrong to name [the victim]1093-the victim . [I]0-i ought to have recognised the gulf which separates the personal from the impersonal . ' There was a suspicion of irony in [his]0-i voice , and [she]139-clare did not answer , only quickened [her]139-clare pace a little . '[0-i] Forgive [me]0-i , ' [he]0-i said , in a tone low , and one more earnest than any [she]139-clare had yet heard [him]0-i use . '[0-i] [You]0-i must forgive [me]0-i . [I]0-i would not offend [you]0-i for all [the world]2867-the world , not to gain every end [I]0-i have ever fought for , to realise every hope [I]0-i have ever cherished . ' [She]139-clare turned and looked right into [his]0-i eyes , and in them read nothing but perfect honesty and sincerity . '[0-i] [I]0-i have nothing whatever to forgive , [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , ' [she]139-clare said . '[121-litvinoff] Pray , let [us]1095-us change the subject ; ' but all the ice was gone from [her]139-clare voice , and [he]0-i at once plunged into a diatribe against the carelessness of [omnibus drivers]3471-omnibus drivers . [He]0-i said good - bye to [her]139-clare outside [the hotel]2993-the hotel . At the top of the steps [she]139-clare turned and looked after [him]0-i , and was not a little vexed with [herself]139-clare for having done so , for [he]0-i was looking after [her]139-clare with an expression in [his]0-i eyes which said , to [her]139-clare at least , — '[121-litvinoff] Whatever the ends [I]0-i have fought for , or the hopes [I]0-i have cherished , may have been in the past , the object of [my]0-i every dream and aspiration is now [yourself]1096-yourself , [Clare Stanley]139-clare . ' A FAIR MORNING 'S[139-clare] WORK . [PETROVITCH]179-petrovitch waited at the corner for some moments , but as [his]179-petrovitch protégée did not return , [he]179-petrovitch concluded that [she]139-clare had found [the house]291-the house door open , and would be all right , so [he]179-petrovitch turned [his]179-petrovitch face west . The new feeling that had possessed [him]179-petrovitch at the sound of [Alice]134-alice 's surname had , while [he]179-petrovitch waited , only shown itself in a restless movement of [his]179-petrovitch hand over [his]179-petrovitch beard ; but now it found vent in the swinging pace at which [he]179-petrovitch walked . [He]179-petrovitch slackened it now and again , to glance with a frown at the heaps of dirty rags that filled the corners of doorways and the embrasures of walls , and hid human flesh and blood : the flesh and blood of [[your]1096-yourself brothers]1098-your brothers and [sisters]1099-sisters , [[my]0-i esteemed Royal Commissioners]1100-my esteemed royal commissioners . These door - steps and archways and out - of - the - way corners are not , of course , to be included in an investigation into [the homes of [the poor]1102-the poor]1101-the homes of the poor ; but perhaps they might be if [these royal , noble , and eminent brothers]1103-these royal , noble , and eminent brothers realised that these are [the only homes of [a large proportion of [the poor]1102-the poor]1105-a large proportion of the poor]1104-the only homes of a large proportion of the poor . [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch only stopped once , and that was before a door - step on which something gleamed brightly , and caught [his]179-petrovitch attention . There was [a group there of the usual type]1107-a group there of the usual type — [a man]2882-a man and [woman]345-woman , and [a child]484-a child , [a little girl , from whose eyes the gleam came]1111-a little girl , from whose eyes the gleam came . [She]484-a child was sitting up , [her]484-a child elbow on [her]484-a child knee and [her]484-a child chin on [her]484-a child hand ; [a wizened , stunted child of some eight or nine years]1112-a wizened , stunted child of some eight or nine years , with tangled dark hair that fell over [her]484-a child face , and through which [her]484-a child eyes were staring wide and vacant at the clear sky . As [he]179-petrovitch stopped [she]484-a child transferred the gaze to [him]179-petrovitch , but it was still a gaze void of hope and expectation . [He]179-petrovitch did not speak to [her]484-a child , but patted [her]484-a child shoulder , dropped some coppers and a bar of chocolate in [her]484-a child lap , and hurried on , with a muttered curse which [the child]1113-the child did not hear . [He]179-petrovitch stopped no more till [he]179-petrovitch reached [a tall house in [a quiet street near [Portland Road Station]49-portland road station]1115-a quiet street near portland road station]1114-a tall house in a quiet street near portland road station . [He]179-petrovitch let [himself]179-petrovitch in with a key , and softly mounted the stairs to [the second floor]1116-the second floor . [The room]2910-the room [he]179-petrovitch entered was large , and looked bare until one noticed the shelves on shelves of well - bound , well - kept books , the pigeon - holes full of manuscripts , the brackets supporting good busts and statuettes , the one or two choice prints , the antique writing - table and chairs . There were no curtains to the window , and there was no carpet to the floor ; but there was a reading - lamp of uncommon design , with a green shade . It was the luxury of literary asceticism . [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch turned up the lamp and rekindled [his]179-petrovitch fire . Then [he]179-petrovitch went into [the adjoining room]1118-the adjoining room , from which presently came the sound of splashing water , followed by hard breathing , as of one wrestling with a rough towel . It was a ghastly hour for tubbing , and [many an Englishman who plumes [himself]179-petrovitch on taking a bath at eight or nine in the morning would have shuddered at the idea of thus taking one four or five hours earlier]1119-many an englishman who plumes himself on taking a bath at eight or nine in the morning would have shuddered at the idea of thus taking one four or five hours earlier ; but it seemed to agree with [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , for [he]179-petrovitch came back to the fireside glowing , and seeming to have washed from [his]179-petrovitch face the look of mingled weariness and anger which [he]179-petrovitch had brought in with [him]179-petrovitch . [His]179-petrovitch hand hovered a moment along the line of a certain bookshelf , then [he]179-petrovitch picked out a book , and for the next three hours read steadily , only pausing to make notes . At seven o'clock [he]179-petrovitch shut [his]179-petrovitch book gently , replaced it carefully on its shelf , very deftly and quickly prepared [his]179-petrovitch breakfast , and , having eaten it , put on [his]179-petrovitch hat and a black coat and went out again . Now , for the first time , [he]179-petrovitch thought over [his]179-petrovitch night 's adventures , for during the time [he]179-petrovitch had spent in [[his]179-petrovitch room]3391-his room [he]179-petrovitch had not allowed [himself]179-petrovitch to think of them . [He]179-petrovitch had the capacity of dismissing utterly from [his]179-petrovitch mind anything about which [he]179-petrovitch did not want to think . It was time enough to think when [he]179-petrovitch could act , and [he]179-petrovitch had known that [he]179-petrovitch could not act till the morning . Now , two minutes ' thought decided the course [his]179-petrovitch action should take . By half - past eight o'clock [he]179-petrovitch had knocked at the door of [15 Spray 's Buildings]24-spray 's buildings , and had been directed to [the room of [Mrs Fludger]171-mrs fludger]3473-the room of mrs fludger . [That lady]3222-that lady was surrounded by the family linen — some just as it had been discarded by [the family]3475-the family , some in the wash - tub , and some hanging on lines slung across [the room]2910-the room at a convenient height for dabbing itself wetly in the faces of [possible visitors]3477-possible visitors . [The room]2910-the room appeared to be furnished chastely and simply with the tub and lines before mentioned , and nothing else whatever ; for the remainder of the furniture had been heaped in one corner , in order that the washing might not be impeded , and was not noticeable at the first glance . [Mrs Fludger]171-mrs fludger had [her]171-mrs fludger arms bared for toil . [She]171-mrs fludger wore a dress with no appreciable waist and no distinctive colour . A woollen shawl wound [her]171-mrs fludger figure in its embrace , a black bonnet of no particular shape , and of antique appearance , was on the extreme back of [her]171-mrs fludger head , where it was supported , by no visible agency , in defiance of the laws of gravitation . '[1124-the lord] Now then , [[my]0-i good man]1121-my good man , ' [she]171-mrs fludger began , in answer to [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch 's tap at the open door , '[1124-the lord] [we]1122-we do n't want no Scripture reading [here]2895-here . Thank [the Lord]1124-the lord , [I]0-i knows [my]0-i Bible duty , and does it , which was n't [I]0-i up this very morning afore five , which is more than [you]1121-my good man can say , [I]0-i 'll go bail . '[1121-my good man] ' But [I]1121-my good man do n't want to Bible read , '[1121-my good man] said [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , as [she]1121-my good man ended with a snap of [her]1121-my good man teeth , and recommenced the action of ' soaping in , '[1121-my good man] which [her]1121-my good man vigorous speech had suspended . ' [I]1121-my good man only wish to ask [you]1121-my good man of a [Mrs Litvinoff]180-litvinoff ? '[1121-my good man] ' Do n't know the name . '[1121-my good man] ' Oh , [her]3479-the young woman who left here yesterday morning ! '[1121-my good man] ' [I]1126-you hope [she]171-mrs fludger did no wrong here , that [you]171-mrs fludger are not angry with [her]171-mrs fludger , '[1126-you] said [he]1126-you , as though feeling [Mrs Fludger]171-mrs fludger 's displeasure to be the severest punishment of misdoing . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i have a quite special reason , ' [he]0-i said , '[0-i] for wishing to befriend [her]171-mrs fludger . ' '[1126-you] Oh , [Lord]1127-lord bless [the men]1128-the men ! [She]171-mrs fludger was here two months or more , and not a soul ever come a - nigh [her]171-mrs fludger , and now , afore [she]171-mrs fludger 's been gone two days , here 's [half a dozen gentlemen]1130-half a dozen gentlemen comes after [her]171-mrs fludger . Why , only yesterday [two young swells]3481-two young swells was a'most a - comin '[1126-you] to blows over [her]171-mrs fludger outside this very door , a - makin ' a perfick inharmonium o '[1126-you] [[my]0-i stairs]1131-my stairs , to say nothing o ' [the gent]3482-the gent as went a - makin '[1126-you] inquiries o ' the ground - floor front , as was quite the improper person to imply to , not being responsible , and knowin '[1126-you] nothing about [the lodgers]818-the lodgers . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i am exceedingly sorry to give [you]1126-you any further trouble , [madam]3251-madam , but , as [I]0-i know [you]1126-you are the only person who can inform [me]0-i , [I]0-i must ask [you]1126-you why [this young woman]3334-this young woman left . '[179-petrovitch] [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch thanked [her]1126-you , and asked the address of [the lucky doctor whom [Fate]189-fate had spared these inflictions]1137-the lucky doctor whom fate had spared these inflictions . ' Thank [you]171-mrs fludger very much , '[179-petrovitch] [he]179-petrovitch said ; ' good - bye , '[179-petrovitch] and held out [his]179-petrovitch hand as though [he]179-petrovitch had known [her]1126-you for years . This was partly because [he]179-petrovitch thought it was the English thing to do in parting with [one 's equals]1138-one 's equals , and partly because [he]179-petrovitch went enough among [poor people]1139-poor people to know that [their]1139-poor people troubles are not made lighter by an assumption of superiority on the part of [[their]1139-poor people visitors]1140-their visitors . It was a matter of course with [him]179-petrovitch , but [Mrs Fludger]171-mrs fludger was particularly gratified . [She]171-mrs fludger gave [him]179-petrovitch [her]171-mrs fludger damp hand , and returned [his]179-petrovitch shake with heartiness . ' Well , now , '[171-mrs fludger] [she]171-mrs fludger said , ' if [I]171-mrs fludger 've been a bit short , [you]179-petrovitch must set it down to the washin '[171-mrs fludger] , and [I]0-i could n't get it out o ' [my]171-mrs fludger head that [you]179-petrovitch was [one of the religious sort]3485-one of the religious sort . '[171-mrs fludger] An opinion in which [[her]171-mrs fludger hearer]1141-her hearer concurred . [Dr Moore]174-dr moore was not surprised at the inquiries with which [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch called upon [him]179-petrovitch ten minutes later . Now for the last and most interesting . ' But when [he]0-i reached [[Mrs Litvinoff]180-litvinoff 's room]3516-mrs litvinoff 's room [he]0-i found [her]1184-her out . But [the room]2910-the room was empty . [He]0-i hesitated a moment , and then entered . It wanted a few minutes to noon ; [he]0-i would wait till the appointed time , and while [he]0-i waited [he]0-i wondered , as [he]0-i had been wondering all the morning , why [she]1184-her had taken this name of [Litvinoff]180-litvinoff . Was it simply because [Litvinoff]180-litvinoff had been the first name that had come into [her]1184-her head , or for some deeper or more important reason ? [The room]2910-the room was very neat , and did not offer much entertainment to the eye or employment to the mind ; but there were four or five books on the mantelpiece , and [he]0-i was drawn towards them by a natural attraction . It was one of [his]0-i habits always to take up a book , if one was within reach . ' It was characteristic of [the man who spoke that [he]3057-the count should be able to make an appeal which would move [this girl]3522-this girl , who had not known [him]3057-the count twenty - four hours , to tell [him]3057-the count all that [she]3522-this girl had felt it to be impossible to tell [[her]3522-this girl foster - brother]3523-her foster - brother]3521-the man who spoke that he should be able to make an appeal which would move this girl , who had not known him twenty - four hours , to tell him all that she had felt it to be impossible to tell her foster - brother , [Richard Ferrier]130-richard . For [she]3522-this girl did tell [him]3057-the count . The substance of [her]3522-this girl story was this : [She]3522-this girl had been staying with [an aunt who kept [a small hotel in [Liverpool]14-liverpool]3525-a small hotel in liverpool , when [she]3522-this girl had met [Litvinoff]180-litvinoff , and had seen a great deal of [him]3057-the count]3524-an aunt who kept a small hotel in liverpool , when she had met litvinoff , and had seen a great deal of him . [He]3057-the count had seemed to [her]3522-this girl to be different from [all the other men [she]3522-this girl had ever seen]3526-all the other men she had ever seen , and though [she]3522-this girl could not help being pleased by [his]3057-the count admiration , [she]3522-this girl had felt that the difference in [their]3527-their station was such that [she]3522-this girl could not properly fill the position of [[his]3057-the count wife]522-his wife . [His]3057-the count grave and respectful manner and the perfect deference with which [he]3057-the count always treated [her]3522-this girl had made it impossible for [her]3522-this girl to suppose that [his]3057-the count wish was other than to make [her]3522-this girl [[his]3057-the count wife]522-his wife . So , though all [her]3522-this girl inclinations would have kept [her]3522-this girl in [Liverpool]14-liverpool , [she]3522-this girl had , after a severe struggle with [herself]3522-this girl , shortened [her]3522-this girl visit , and returned to [Derbyshire]12-derbyshire without bidding [him]3057-the count good - bye . [He]3057-the count had followed [her]3522-this girl , and one evening when [she]3522-this girl was walking alone [she]3522-this girl had met [him]3057-the count . Of course , there had been explanations . [He]3057-the count had implored [her]3522-this girl not to send [him]3057-the count away — to let [him]3057-the count be always as happy as [he]3057-the count had been that month at [Liverpool]14-liverpool . [He]3057-the count met [her]3522-this girl objections as to the difference in [their]3530-their position by telling [her]3522-this girl that [he]3057-the count was [an outcast]3531-an outcast and [an exile]3230-an exile , and had no position . Would [she]3522-this girl not make [his]3057-the count hard life a little easier to [him]3057-the count ? At every word [he]3057-the count said [she]3522-this girl felt [her]3522-this girl resolutions melting away ; but [[her]3522-this girl parents]3533-her parents , would [they]3533-her parents ever consent to [her]3522-this girl marriage with [one who held such opinions as [his]3057-the count]3534-one who held such opinions as his ? Then [he]3057-the count had told [her]3522-this girl gravely and tenderly that [he]3057-the count was at war with [society]3007-society and with most of [its]3007-society conventions , and that for [him]3057-the count to marry in the ordinary sense of the word would be to compromise and deny every principle on which [his]3057-the count life was founded . The true marriage , [he]3057-the count had maintained , was fidelity , and mutual love was more binding than could be a ceremony in which one of [the performers]3536-the performers did not believe . [He]3057-the count loved [her]3522-this girl [he]3057-the count had said , far too dearly to wish to deceive [her]3522-this girl in the smallest degree about [his]3057-the count sentiments , and so [he]3057-the count felt bound to tell [her]3522-this girl that to [him]3057-the count a legal marriage would be for ever impossible . In spite of that , would [she]3522-this girl not be noble enough to trust [her]3522-this girl life entirely to [him]3057-the count , and be [[his]3057-the count wife]522-his wife ? This had been so completely unexpected as to be a great shock to [her]3522-this girl , and [she]3522-this girl had felt at once that , however [she]3522-this girl might decide , it would be out of the question to tell or ask [[her]3522-this girl parents]3533-her parents about it . [Her]3522-this girl choice lay between [them]3533-her parents and [[her]3522-this girl lover]3539-her lover . [We]3540-we know how [she]3522-this girl chose . Of [her]3522-this girl time of happiness [she]3522-this girl said very little , but [[her]3522-this girl hearer]1141-her hearer gathered that , though [Litvinoff]180-litvinoff had left [her]3522-this girl much alone , [she]3522-this girl had had no reason to doubt that [he]3057-the count still cared for [her]3522-this girl . But the influence of [her]3522-this girl early training , though it had sunk into abeyance in the hour of strong temptation , had slowly and surely reasserted itself as the months went by . [She]3522-this girl had striven still to believe that [she]3522-this girl was acting rightly , but at last it became impossible to [her]3522-this girl to persuade [herself]3522-this girl that [she]3522-this girl had any right to be [a law unto [herself]3522-this girl]3542-a law unto herself . So at last [she]3522-this girl had left [[her]3522-this girl lover]3539-her lover , with no farewell but a letter , in which [she]3522-this girl had tried to tell [him]3539-her lover how it was . [She]3522-this girl had felt a pleasure in the hardness of the life that followed — had vaguely felt it to be in some sort an expiation of [her]3522-this girl wickedness . '[1200-you] [You]1200-you see , ' [she]3522-this girl ended , '[1200-you] if [I]0-i had believed as [he]1200-you did , perhaps [I]0-i should have been right to act as [I]0-i did ; but [I]0-i believed in all the things that [he]1200-you denies , and so [I]0-i was wrong to dare to take [his]1200-you views of good and bad for [me]0-i , while all the time [I]0-i kept [my]0-i own old thoughts of what was really good and bad . [I]0-i ca n't explain [myself]0-i well , but [you]1200-you see what [I]0-i mean — don't [you]1200-you ? ' '[1200-you] Yes , ' answered [Petrovitch]190-petrovitch , rising ; '[1200-you] [I]0-i see that another life has been sacrificed upon the altar of an abstraction . If it gives [you]1200-you happiness to give [yourself]1200-you pain , at anyrate [I]0-i should think [your]1200-you wickedness , as [you]1200-you call it , was expiated now . Has [he]1200-you never tried to find [you]1200-you out ? ' '[1200-you] [He]1200-you may have tried , ' said [Alice]134-alice , '[1200-you] but [he]1200-you has not succeeded . ' '[1200-you] Would [you]1200-you not go back to [him]1200-you — now that [you]1200-you have another life than [your]1200-you own to think of ? ' [Alice]134-alice darted a quick glance at [him]1200-you , and turned very white . '[1200-you] No , unless that happened which never can happen — if [his]1200-you belief changed . But [I]0-i can not go on talking like this ; it is torture to [me]0-i — and to what end ? ' '[0-i] [I]0-i told [you]1200-you — for [his]1200-you good and [yours]1200-you . However , to business . And [this room]1202-this room — [you]1200-you do not like it ? The day had been at its beginning so wild , so bitter , so full of horrible possibilities ; this was a peaceful — almost a happy — ending to it . [Alice]134-alice felt the change keenly , and there was gratitude to [Petrovitch]190-petrovitch in every word [she]134-alice spoke to [the mother]3271-the mother , every smile [she]134-alice gave to [the little ones]1218-the little ones . ON the morning after that which [he]190-petrovitch had spent in the study of Art , [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff was busily engaged in turning out the pockets of coats , and ' making hay '[121-litvinoff] of the contents of portmanteaus , conducting a vigorous search for something or other , and singing softly to [himself]190-petrovitch the while , — ' Oh , '[190-petrovitch] tis love , ' tis love , '[190-petrovitch] tis love , that makes [the world]2867-the world go round;Every day beneath [his]190-petrovitch sway [fools old and young]1220-fools old and young are found . '[3057-the count] [He]130-richard lingered in [the hall]1285-the hall to make [himself]130-richard a cigarette , half expecting [Richard]130-richard to follow [him]130-richard , but as [he]130-richard did not , strolled slowly away into [the street]557-the street . [Richard]130-richard remained standing in [the coffee - room]3572-the coffee - room with one hand on the table by which the conversation had taken place . [He]130-richard felt indignantly injured by [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's interference , and in the first moments of passion felt sure that [his]130-richard interference had not been disinterested . But as [he]130-richard grew calmer , and was able to think the matter out quietly , [he]130-richard could not suggest to [himself]130-richard any possible reason for [the Count]3057-the count 's wishing to adjust the quarrel between [himself]130-richard and [Roland]107-roland , except the one [he]130-richard had given . Yet , even if [the Russian]153-russian had been merely filling the rôle of ' [friend of humanity]3591-friend of humanity , '[106-dick] [Dick]106-dick felt glad that [he]106-dick had shown resentment . [One]504-one might overlook intermeddling which had its rise in an overpowering interest in [one]504-one 's own personality ; but when [one]504-one was included merely in a vast aggregate like humanity , the compliment which might have been as salt to over - officiousness did not exist , and the conduct of [the Count]3057-the count became simply offensive . ' But why should [I]130-richard expect anything better from [him]3057-the count , after [his]3057-the count conduct to [that poor child]3592-that poor child ? '[130-richard] Then [he]130-richard thought of all [he]130-richard fancied [he]130-richard had discovered about [Alice]134-alice , and all the little things that had aggravated the quarrel with [Roland]107-roland . All the substance of the quarrel would not , perhaps , seem insurmountable if it were written here in detail , but to [Richard]130-richard and [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother these things appeared in far other proportions . The mutual jealousy and distrust that had been growing up between [them]1298-them in the past months was as so much dry tinder ready to catch fire at any spark of a pretext for anger which either might have lighted on . And this case of [Alice]134-alice was something more than a trifling pretext . [Richard]130-richard [himself]130-richard was neither [an angel]1299-an angel nor [a monk]1300-a monk , but at least [he]130-richard played the game of life according to the rules . And , consequently , [he]130-richard felt towards [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother much as [an old écarté player]1302-an old écarté player might towards [a man who kept kings up [his]1303-a man who kept kings up his sleeve sleeve]1303-a man who kept kings up his sleeve . The same roof should not cover them again . [The majority of [the ladies]767-the ladies]1358-the majority of the ladies gave a business - like aspect to the evening by severely retaining [their]1358-the majority of the ladies outdoor garments . ' [Clare]139-clare , [[my]201-mrs quaid love]3602-my love , '[201-mrs quaid] [she]201-mrs quaid said , ' [you]139-clare must let [me]201-mrs quaid introduce [dear Mr Petrovitch]179-petrovitch to [you]139-clare . '[201-mrs quaid] [Clare]139-clare knew by experience that all [[her]139-clare hostess 's male friends]1365-her hostess 's male friends were ' dear , '[1366-her female ones] and [[her]139-clare female ones]1366-her female ones ' sweet , '[1366-her female ones] for at least three weeks after [their]1367-us first introduction , but when [she]139-clare turned to receive [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch 's bow , it did strike [her]139-clare that the epithet was more than usually incongruous . [He]179-petrovitch was about [the last person]1368-the last person , [she]139-clare thought , to whom terms of indiscriminate endearment could be applied . After the Continental manner , [he]179-petrovitch had put on evening dress . The wide shirt - front showed off the splendid breadth of a chest that would not have disgraced [a Life Guardsman in uniform]1369-a life guardsman in uniform . [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley , as [she]122-miss stanley looked at [him]179-petrovitch , admitted to [herself]122-miss stanley that on [some people]998-some people the claw - hammer coat was not without its æsthetic attraction . As [the people]407-the people settled down into chairs [he]179-petrovitch took a seat be side [her]122-miss stanley , but in such a position that [she]122-miss stanley could see [his]179-petrovitch face without turning [her]122-miss stanley own . Then , after a few business preliminaries , [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch began to speak . [He]179-petrovitch did not read , as had been announced , but spoke from notes , with a little hesitation , caused , perhaps , by [his]179-petrovitch speaking in a foreign language . To [most of [[his]179-petrovitch hearers]705-his hearers]1372-most of his hearers what [he]179-petrovitch had to say was well - known , no doubt ; but to [Clare]139-clare all [he]179-petrovitch said came as a revelation . [She]139-clare had come to be amused , to criticise , to ' make fun , '[139-clare] perhaps ; but what [she]139-clare heard from [this man beside [her]139-clare]1374-this man beside her was not in the least amusing or funny . It seemed to [her]139-clare more like the gospel of a new religion . [She]139-clare listened intently , and after a while , unconsciously influenced by the interest and light in [her]139-clare face , [he]179-petrovitch began to feel less and less as though [he]179-petrovitch were talking to [the room]2910-the room , and more and more as though [he]179-petrovitch were speaking solely to [the girl beside [him]179-petrovitch]1376-the girl beside him . If [he]179-petrovitch saw comprehension in [her]139-clare eyes , [he]179-petrovitch did not trouble to explain a point further ; if [he]179-petrovitch saw a question there , [he]179-petrovitch answered it ; a doubt , [he]179-petrovitch solved it . Some eyes are easy to read , and [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch was [a master of that art]1377-a master of that art . [The girl]367-the girl was [no fool]1379-no fool , and though the whole theory of [Socialism]206-socialism was new to [her]367-the girl , [she]367-the girl was able to follow the rigorous train of logic with which [he]179-petrovitch led up to [his]179-petrovitch conclusions . [He]179-petrovitch attacked all the stock ideas which [she]367-the girl had been brought up to respect . It somehow did not seem like blasphemy . [He]179-petrovitch flung scorn and derision on the social ideals which [she]367-the girl had heard lauded from [her]367-the girl cradle . Some things which [she]367-the girl had been taught to consider admirable and desirable , grew , as [he]179-petrovitch spoke of them , to seem mean and paltry . Life , as [she]367-the girl listened , took new meanings , and became of deeper significance . Even the affairs of every day , the chance stories of misery , and the ' painful '[179-petrovitch] paragraphs of the newspapers , which [she]367-the girl felt , and shuddered as [she]367-the girl felt , had hitherto seemed only occasions for the sprinkling of a little Radical rose - water — little stings of passing horror , which heightened rather than detracted from the pleasures of existence — seemed now to be worth considering in some other light . This was not the first time that [Clare]139-clare 's heart had been stirred and [her]367-the girl sympathies quickened by a spoken discourse . More than once [she]367-the girl remembered having left the doors of [parish church]1380-parish church or [cathedral]1381-cathedral in a tumult of emotion when [some specially earnest and eloquent preacher]1382-some specially earnest and eloquent preacher had succeeded in casting a new and fierce light into the inmost depths of [her]367-the girl soul ; but , [she]367-the girl remembered , those feelings had been transient , and strong though the new convictions and resolutions had been when [she]367-the girl left [the sacred portals]1383-the sacred portals , the small things of life — the duties of [school]1384-school , the light worries of [home]303-home , the social bagatelles , things trivial and tenuous enough in themselves — had soon settled down upon [her]367-the girl like a thick atmosphere , and by [their]1386-their aggregate weight had crushed , not out of existence , but back to [her]367-the girl soul 's remoter recesses , the new - born life . As [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch finished speaking , and , folding up [his]179-petrovitch notes , thanked [[his]179-petrovitch hearers]705-his hearers for [their]705-his hearers patience and attention , [she]367-the girl wondered to [herself]367-the girl , so quick is thought , whether what had happened before would not happen again , and whether by this time to - morrow [her]367-the girl mind would not be running with its accustomed smoothness in its accustomed channels . [She]367-the girl hoped no ; [she]367-the girl feared yes . But somehow something seemed to tell [her]367-the girl that in these past experiences [her]367-the girl emotions only had been affected , but that this time [her]367-the girl reason also had been forced into life and action , and it would be harder to chloroform that , [she]367-the girl thought . For some minutes after [he]179-petrovitch had ceased [she]367-the girl was so preoccupied with these thoughts that [she]367-the girl hardly noticed the sharp fire of questions which was levelled at [him]179-petrovitch from visitors in different parts of [the room]2910-the room . When [she]367-the girl did begin to listen to [them]1389-them , it was only to wonder how [people]298-people could so have misunderstood what seemed to [her]367-the girl so clear . There was [one lady in particular]1391-one lady in particular who asked inconsequent questions in such a feebly deliberate manner , dropping [her]1391-one lady in particular words out as though they were some precious elixir of which it was not well to give out much at a time , that [Clare]139-clare felt an insane desire to shake [her]1391-one lady in particular words out of [her]139-clare , and at the same time a little sense into [her]139-clare . [The genial young stockbroker]1392-the genial young stockbroker wanted to know whether the best part of [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch 's scheme was not included in the present Radical programme , but [his]179-petrovitch suggestion was received with disapprobation by [the large majority]1393-the large majority , and [he]179-petrovitch hastily withdrew into obscurity . It struck [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley that all the questions and remarks were on side issues , and left untouched the main contentions . When [the chairman of the evening]1394-the chairman of the evening announced that the discussion was at an end , [everybody]3079-everybody rose and began to talk at once — in most cases not about the paper . Perhaps [they]3079-everybody were all glad to get away from the larger questions of life 's possibilities , and to return to the trivial personalities which form the chief interest of most of [our]1396-our lives . ' [You]122-miss stanley are interested in these questions , [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley ? ' '[179-petrovitch] Ah ! so it may seem to [you]1401-you who have known [me]0-i only three months , but [I]0-i have known [myself]0-i more than a score of years , and [I]0-i know that [I]0-i am full of [them]1402-them . Come [home]303-home with [me]0-i and have a smoke , and [we]1404-we 'll talk about something else . ' '[1404-we] And how have [you]179-petrovitch liked it , [[my]0-i dearest]1405-my dearest [Clare]139-clare ? Have [you]179-petrovitch been terribly bored — or puzzled perhaps — since [you]179-petrovitch are not used to these discussions ? ' '[0-i] [I]0-i have never been more interested than [I]0-i was by [Mr Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , ' said [Clare]139-clare , with perfect truth . '[179-petrovitch] Ah , yes , ' said [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid enthusiastically ; '[179-petrovitch] so sweet , is n't [he]179-petrovitch ? ' [Clare]139-clare did not answer , but as [she]139-clare drove [home]303-home it occurred to [her]139-clare that the principal ingredient in [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch 's character was not exactly sugar . THERE are [people]298-people , [we]3609-we are told , on whom the rapid action of railway travelling acts as a soothing influence ; but to [the majority of [us]3609-we]3610-the majority of us , when suffering from any loss or grief , a long train journey is simply maddening . The rattling of the windows , the vibration of [the carriage]398-the carriage , the banging of doors and shouting of [porters]3612-porters at [the stations]3613-the stations , the prolonged and ear - piercing shriek of the whistle , occurring at such moments as to convince the thinking mind that it is not let off with any good intention or to serve any useful purpose , but simply to gratify the torturing instinct of [the engine - driver]3614-the engine - driver at the expense of [the passengers]3615-the passengers '[179-petrovitch] nerves and tempers — all these only aggravate any trouble which may be part of one 's invisible luggage . For all these together are not enough to distract [one]504-one from the contemplation of [one]504-one 's special skeleton , and each is in itself enough to keep [one]504-one from contemplating it with any good result . And as for seeing the bright side of one 's troubles , that is quite impossible when one is moving at the rate of fifty miles an hour ; the only wonder is that [more people]1409-more people are not overcome by the peculiarly dismal aspect which one 's position assumes under these circumstances , and that [we]1410-we do n't hear of more suicides in [railway carriages]1411-railway carriages . The three o'clock [Midland express]1412-midland express was tearing through [the quiet country]1413-the quiet country . A faint mist lay over [the fields]1414-the fields and hedges , faint , but still thick enough to hold its own against the pale yellow sunbeams that seemed striving to disperse it . [Richard Ferrier]130-richard , idly gazing at the flying hedges and gates and [squalid cottages]1415-squalid cottages , did not feel any less sad for the sadness of the outside world through which [he]130-richard was speeding [home]303-home . [He]130-richard had spent the previous evening in a vigorous search after [Alice]134-alice — a search which had been unsuccessful , even though [he]130-richard had offered [Mrs Fludger]171-mrs fludger the best inducement to frankness . It had needed that golden token to mitigate the wrath with which [she]171-mrs fludger had received [his]130-richard first question . [She]171-mrs fludger had , indeed , hinted , not darkly , in the first flush of indignation , at worse designs on [his]130-richard part than even Bible - reading ; but gold itself , though it had softened [her]171-mrs fludger asperity , had been powerless to extort from [her]171-mrs fludger any information of the slightest value . Having tried all [he]130-richard knew , and failed , to discover any trace of what [he]130-richard sought , [Richard]130-richard had given up the search . [He]130-richard had met [Roland]107-roland once on [the hotel staircase]1417-the hotel staircase . [They]1418-they had passed [each other]2934-each other like [strangers]1420-strangers . As [the train]1421-the train rushed on , [he]130-richard went over and over again all the circumstances of [his]130-richard quarrel with [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother . A fire of hate burned in [him]130-richard fiercely , a stern and deep indignation surged in [his]130-richard heart , and blinded [his]130-richard eyes to any possible palliation of [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother 's conduct . This state of mind was the outcome of months of heart soreness and suppressed bitterness of spirit,—months in which [he]130-richard had vainly tried to disguise from [himself]130-richard that if [Clare Stanley]139-clare did incline to one more than the other , it was [Roland]107-roland who was the favourite . During that month of [Roland]107-roland 's unexplained holiday [Richard]130-richard had fancied [he]130-richard made some progress in [her]139-clare good graces , but when [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother came back again [she]139-clare had turned on [him]130-richard just the same smiles and glances that had bewildered [Dick]106-dick . And from that time it had seemed to [him]130-richard that [Roland]107-roland was gradually elbowing [him]130-richard out . [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley had a taste for poetry , and [Roland]107-roland read poetry extremely well . [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley called [herself]122-miss stanley [a Radical]1425-a radical , and [Roland]107-roland had been a shining light on that side in [a small debating society at [Cambridge]2-cambridge]1426-a small debating society at cambridge . [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley liked to chatter about Art , and [Roland]107-roland always had a stock of the latest Art prattle at the tip of [his]107-roland tongue . [Roland]107-roland had grown fond of solitary walks , and in these was constantly meeting [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley ' by accident'—'accident '[122-miss stanley] which [Richard]130-richard could not always bring [himself]130-richard to believe in . It was to be noticed , by the way , that in the walks of [both these young men]1427-both these young men all roads led , not to [Rome]48-rome , but past [Aspinshaw]105-aspinshaw . [Richard]130-richard had borne all this , sustaining [himself]130-richard with a hope that [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley did not really feel interested so much in [Roland]107-roland as in the tastes [he]107-roland affected . [He]130-richard had still hoped that [she]122-miss stanley might come to care for him,—for [the man who loved [her]122-miss stanley]1428-the man who loved her with such a passionate intensity . It is so hard , so very hard , to believe that the love that is everything to [us]1429-us is absolutely nothing to [the beloved]461-the beloved . [Men]466-men have even dreamed that [their]466-men passion could warm marble to life . How much easier to fancy that it can stir a heart to love . But the sting in the pain [he]130-richard had suffered while [[his]130-richard lady]1432-his lady smiled on [Roland]107-roland had been a half unselfish fear that these smiles of hers were being bestowed on [a man unworthy of them]1433-a man unworthy of them . Now that [he]130-richard believed this unworthiness to be proved , all the latent doubts , distrusts , suspicions [he]130-richard had kept down ' sprang full statured in an hour , '[1434-them] and with [them]1434-them sprang a hatred of [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother , so fierce as to frighten [himself]130-richard ; for however [he]130-richard might seek to deceive [himself]130-richard about it , [he]130-richard knew in [his]130-richard inmost heart that it was less as a heartless profligate than as [a possibly successful rival]1436-a possibly successful rival that [he]130-richard had learned to hate [him]2917-his brother . But [he]130-richard knew that now this rivalry could not be successful . [His]130-richard great love for [her]1432-his lady prevented [his]130-richard seeing the realities that underlay the superficial side of [her]1432-his lady character , so that [he]130-richard actually believed [her]1432-his lady to be [the last woman in [the world]2867-the world]1437-the last woman in the world [one could dare to ask to share poverty]1439-one could dare to ask to share poverty . [He]130-richard knew that [his]130-richard own chance , such as it had been , was lost ; but [he]130-richard knew , too , that [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother 's chance was also at an end . This did not make [him]130-richard less determined that the quarrel should be à outrance . ' Cutting off [one]504-one 's nose to spite [one]504-one 's face '[504-one] is such a wildly irrational act that [one]504-one would never expect [any reasonable being]1442-any reasonable being to be guilty of it , and yet hundreds of [people]298-people do it every day . [Dick]106-dick was doing it now , practically , though [he]106-dick kept reminding [himself]106-dick that this was really the only honourable course open to [him]106-dick , and that [he]106-dick was influenced mainly by irreproachable motives . It was nearly eight o'clock when [his]106-dick journey ended at [Thornsett Edge]1-thornsett edge . [He]106-dick went straight into [the dining - room]1444-the dining - room , where [Miss Ferrier]111-miss ferrier sat filling in the groundwork of some canvas slippers , which [she]111-miss ferrier hastily pushed out of sight when [she]111-miss ferrier saw [him]106-dick . It was one of [her]111-miss ferrier habits , kept up since the days when [they]1445-they were [children]1446-children , to make some present for each of [the brothers]356-the brothers every year , and give it to [them]1445-they at Christmas as a ' surprise . '[106-dick] ' [[My]106-dick dear]362-my dear [Dick]106-dick , how ill [you]106-dick look ! Why did n't [you]106-dick write ? Have [you]106-dick had any dinner ? [Richard]130-richard went quickly away under the arching interlaced boughs of the garden trees . When [he]130-richard reached [the road]3300-the road [he]130-richard did not turn [his]130-richard face towards [Thornsett Edge]1-thornsett edge , but went up [the hill]1476-the hill that lay at the back of [the house]291-the house . Across [the fields]1414-the fields , where no track was visible , but where [he]130-richard could have found [his]130-richard way blindfold , through [narrow lanes with stone walls]1479-narrow lanes with stone walls , past more than [one farmstead]1480-one farmstead , now settled down into the restfulness of night , always upwards [he]130-richard went , until [he]130-richard reached [the little church that crowned [the hill]1476-the hill]1481-the little church that crowned the hill and kept watch over [the dead that crowded under its shadow]1483-the dead that crowded under its shadow . [The young man]2891-the young man passed into [the graveyard]1485-the graveyard and made [his]2891-the young man way to a very white stone , that showed strikingly among the dun - coloured monuments about [it]1485-the graveyard . Light fleecy clouds were being blown over the face of the waning moon , and alternations of weird shadows , and still weirder lights , fell on the tombstones and on [the grey , weather - beaten little church]1486-the grey , weather - beaten little church . [Richard]130-richard rested [his]130-richard hand on [[[his]130-richard father]2890-his father 's gravestone]1488-his father 's gravestone with a caressing touch . [The old man]297-the old man 's words rang in [his]297-the old man ears,—'It has been a long life ; [I]0-i should like to lie quiet at last . ' '[297-the old man] Thank [God]110-god , ' said [Richard]130-richard . [He]297-the old man lies quiet and beyond the reach of it all . ' [He]130-richard stooped and kissed the stone , almost as though it had been the face of [him]130-richard who lay beneath it . [THE train]1421-the train which brought [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff from [London]6-london was punctual to the minute , but the trap which was to take [him]297-the old man to [Thornsett Edge]1-thornsett edge was not , and [he]297-the old man was lounging discontentedly among [his]297-the old man rugs and luggage at [the melancholy little station of [Firth Vale]11-firth vale]3645-the melancholy little station of firth vale . When [Roland]107-roland had left [London]6-london , some weeks before , [he]107-roland had parted from [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff with the understanding that [he]107-roland was to spend Christmas with [him]121-litvinoff at [Thornsett Edge]1-thornsett edge . [Young Ferrier]214-young ferrier had felt that [the Count]3057-the count would be a thousand times better company than [his]214-young ferrier own thoughts , and [he]214-young ferrier preferred asking [him]3057-the count to inviting any of [[his]214-young ferrier college friends]3647-his college friends , from whom [Richard]130-richard 's absence would provoke comment , and to whom it would have to be explained . For [Richard]130-richard had gone away , leaving no address save that of [a solicitor in [London]6-london]3648-a solicitor in london , and [he]130-richard had written to [the trustees]3640-the trustees , and steps were being taken for closing [the mill]2936-the mill . [Roland]107-roland would rather have been anywhere than near [the property [he]107-roland was so soon to lose]3651-the property he was so soon to lose , but [Gates]114-gates urged [him]107-roland to stay at [Thornsett]30-thornsett till the New Year , and with [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff as [[his]114-gates guest]3321-his guest [he]114-gates hoped to keep ghosts of old times at bay as successfully in [[his]114-gates old home]3653-his old home as [he]114-gates could hope to do anywhere else . [And Litvinoff]121-litvinoff had accepted the invitation with fervour , for [the Stanleys]146-the stanleys were back at [Aspinshaw]105-aspinshaw . The day [he]114-gates had pitched on for [his]114-gates journey was a bitterly cold one in the middle of December , and [the waiting - room at [Firth Vale]11-firth vale]3654-the waiting - room at firth vale had no big fires , soft carpets , and luxurious lounges . [It]3654-the waiting - room at firth vale had nothing but a bench , a table , a Bible , a Prayer - book , and a large stone jug of cold water . [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff was got up quite after the English manner , in a light , long travelling ulster with a hood , and a tourist hat of the same stuff ; but in spite of [his]121-litvinoff precautions against weather [he]121-litvinoff was very cold , and not a little cross at [his]121-litvinoff prolonged waiting . [He]121-litvinoff was just debating whether it would not be better to walk , and trust [his]121-litvinoff traps to the mercy of chance , when [the station]3655-the station shivered and shuddered as the '[297-the old man] local ' came slowly and heavily in . As it stopped , [a stout woman , of about forty - five]3656-a stout woman , of about forty - five , with the usual number of blue bandboxes , bundles in handkerchiefs , and brown baskets disposed about [her]3656-a stout woman , of about forty - five person , came hurrying down the stone steps , accompanied by [a hard - featured , grizzled man some years older]3657-a hard - featured , grizzled man some years older . [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff watched [their]3658-their descent with a smile , but as [they]3658-their reached the bottom step [his]121-litvinoff face grew suddenly serious . [He]121-litvinoff turned sharply , and , passing into [the little waiting - room]3659-the little waiting - room , became deeply absorbed in the '[0-i] Scripture roll ' which hung opposite the door , until [the train]1421-the train had glided out of [the station]3655-the station . [He]121-litvinoff saw without turning [his]121-litvinoff head that only [the woman]3264-the woman had gone . [The man]3262-the man remained on [the platform]3664-the platform , gazing after the retreating line of carriages till [he]3262-the man started and turned round at [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's voice . '[3262-the man] [He]0-i spoke shortly ; but [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff had a reason for wishing to talk to [the man]3262-the man , and so was content to ignore a curtness of manner which at any other time [he]0-i would have been the first to resent . [The workman]1511-the workman stopped short , and looked at [the gentleman]1512-the gentleman from head to feet . [His]1511-the workman gaze was calmly returned . '[3262-the man] [The man]3262-the man was interested in spite of [himself]3262-the man , and [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff forthwith plunged into an account of the flight across [the frontier]1514-the frontier on that most exciting night of all [his]121-litvinoff life . [[His]121-litvinoff listener]1515-his listener had not heard many exciting stories — they are not rife in [Firth Vale]11-firth vale — and to this story the fact that it was told by [the chief actor]1516-the chief actor lent an unusual interest . [The Count]121-litvinoff was [a good story - teller]1517-a good story - teller , and the way in which [he]121-litvinoff told [his]121-litvinoff tale left room for no doubt of its truth . ' Ah'm glad [you]3262-the man gave [them]3677-them the slip , '[1518-the listener] [he]1518-the listener said ; ' the devils ! ' The tone of the words , and the words themselves , told [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff that [the man]3262-the man 's icy distrust of [him]3262-the man had melted in the warmth of admiring sympathy . '[107-roland] [It]1525-it was [a very pretty house]1526-a very pretty house , and somehow managed to escape , even at this dreary season , such dreariness as hung over [Thornsett Edge]1-thornsett edge , though [it]1525-it was built of the same grey stone , and had the same moorland background . There was a good deal of ivy about [it]1525-it , and [the grounds]1527-the grounds were less regular and more full of evergreens and shrubs than [[the Ferriers]1528-the ferriers ' garden]3699-the ferriers ' garden . As [the two young men]3417-the two young men walked up [the private road]3701-the private road [they]3417-the two young men heard from the rear of [the house]291-the house a confused barking of dogs , and above the noise [a girl]3064-a girl 's clear voice , raised in vain endeavour to still the joyful tumult . '[218-clare] [La belle Clare]218-clare , ' [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff spoke softly , raising [his]121-litvinoff hat as though [he]121-litvinoff saw [her]3064-a girl , and quickening [his]121-litvinoff pace a little . ' '[218-clare] By all means , ' said [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , and [they]1529-we turned into [the stable - yard]3704-the stable - yard , passing down by the laurel hedge that alone divided [it]3704-the stable - yard from [the garden]292-the garden . '[218-clare] By [God]110-god ! what 's that ? ' cried [the Count]3057-the count , suddenly stopping ; and then [both men]1461-both men sprang through the hedge . No time to go round now , for there had been the sharp report of a gun , [a woman]554-a woman 's shriek , and a heavy fall . IT was Sunday afternoon . The rather festive look of [[Petrovitch]179-petrovitch 's room]3709-petrovitch 's room , in which [he]179-petrovitch now sat alone , was not , however , due to any desire to specialise the day . [He]179-petrovitch had simply made [[his]179-petrovitch home]3710-his home as cheerful as possible because [he]179-petrovitch was about to entertain [guests]3711-guests . [His]179-petrovitch table was spread with a snowy cloth , and with the preparations for a tea of a distinctly convivial character . There was jam , and more than one kind of cake ; and [the room]2910-the room was further brightened by bunches of chrysanthemums . Chairs were drawn round the fire in an inviting - looking circle . The least cheerful object in [the room]2910-the room was [the owner of it , who sat in [his]3714-the owner of it , who sat in his usual chair between the fire and the writing - table usual chair between the fire and the writing - table]3714-the owner of it , who sat in his usual chair between the fire and the writing - table . [He]3714-the owner of it , who sat in his usual chair between the fire and the writing - table looked pale and weary , for the frosty weather had strongly renewed the pain in a wound in [his]179-petrovitch breast — an old wound , and a wound that had just missed being a deadly one . Contrary to [his]179-petrovitch usual custom , [he]179-petrovitch was neither reading nor writing . The pipe [he]179-petrovitch had been smoking had gone out , and [his]179-petrovitch thoughts were far back in the past , among the memories which had re - awakened with that aching in [his]179-petrovitch breast . [His]179-petrovitch thoughts went further back than the date of that wound,—went back to the days before [he]179-petrovitch had lost [friends]2905-friends , [home]303-home , and [country]3717-country . [He]179-petrovitch saw again in fancy the brilliant gaiety of the winters in [St Petersburg]27-st petersburg , [he]179-petrovitch heard again the exquisite music of the concerts and the opera,—the balls where [Majesty itself]3718-majesty itself had deigned to be present , with anxious brow and uneasy , restless eyes . [His]179-petrovitch memory dwelt longest on a certain torchlight fête on [the Neva]57-the neva , when the ice had been a yard thick , and when [the élite]3719-the élite had been shut off from [the common herd]3720-the common herd by walls made of blocks of solid ice , between which fir trees were planted ; when coloured lamps and Chinese lanterns had thrown indescribable magic over [the crowd of bright military uniforms]3721-the crowd of bright military uniforms and the exquisite toilettes of [lovely women who had never in all [their]3722-lovely women who had never in all their lives been troubled by any thought of what their dresses cost lives been troubled by any thought of what [their]3722-lovely women who had never in all their lives been troubled by any thought of what their dresses cost dresses cost]3722-lovely women who had never in all their lives been troubled by any thought of what their dresses cost . And even at this distance [he]179-petrovitch could not think without half a pang of [a certain fair - faced girl , with golden hair , who , in [her]3723-a certain fair - faced girl , with golden hair , who , in her sapphire velvet and swansdown , had been the star of that fête to his boyish eyes sapphire velvet and swansdown , had been the star of that fête to [his]179-petrovitch boyish eyes]3723-a certain fair - faced girl , with golden hair , who , in her sapphire velvet and swansdown , had been the star of that fête to his boyish eyes . And [she]3723-a certain fair - faced girl , with golden hair , who , in her sapphire velvet and swansdown , had been the star of that fête to his boyish eyes had been kind to [him]179-petrovitch on this the last evening [he]179-petrovitch had spent near [her]3723-a certain fair - faced girl , with golden hair , who , in her sapphire velvet and swansdown , had been the star of that fête to his boyish eyes before [his]179-petrovitch new faiths and duties had separated [him]179-petrovitch from [her]3723-a certain fair - faced girl , with golden hair , who , in her sapphire velvet and swansdown , had been the star of that fête to his boyish eyes for ever . That was the first loss [his]179-petrovitch creed had cost [him]179-petrovitch . [He]179-petrovitch wondered what would be the last — life itself perhaps . Then [he]179-petrovitch fell to thinking how these beliefs of [his]179-petrovitch had grown up . How the reading of a certain book — an English book — had done for [his]179-petrovitch mind what a successful operation for cataract does for [one nearly blind]3724-one nearly blind — had shown [him]179-petrovitch the facts of life , no longer half hidden in a mist of falsity , but in all their naked truth and ugliness . How for a time [he]179-petrovitch had closed [his]179-petrovitch eyes again and had tried hard to live on in the life of luxury , beauty , love , and ( now [he]179-petrovitch knew ) selfishness which had been [his]179-petrovitch by '[110-god] right of birth . ' [He]179-petrovitch remembered the night when , belated miles from [[his]179-petrovitch home]3710-his home , and overtaken by a snowstorm , [he]179-petrovitch had sought refuge in [[a peasant]3726-a peasant 's hut]3727-a peasant 's hut , how [he]179-petrovitch had talked to [[his]179-petrovitch hosts]3728-his hosts , how one visit had led to many , and how what [he]179-petrovitch had learned from [these miserable serfs]3729-these miserable serfs had forbidden [him]179-petrovitch to forget or to set aside the teaching of [the great author whose book]3730-the great author whose book had first set [him]179-petrovitch thinking . [He]179-petrovitch remembered that time , perhaps the happiest in [his]179-petrovitch life , when [he]179-petrovitch first began to write — when the ideas which had so long been seething in [his]179-petrovitch brain had found literary expression . [He]179-petrovitch remembered the joy with which [he]179-petrovitch had corrected [his]179-petrovitch first proof , the pride with which [he]179-petrovitch read [his]179-petrovitch first article in a magazine . So thoroughly back in the old time was [he]179-petrovitch that [he]179-petrovitch had stretched out [his]179-petrovitch hand towards this very magazine , which stood bound on a bookshelf , when a heavy foot sounded on the stairs , and a moment after a knock at the door heralded the entrance of [Mr Toomey]177-toomey , whom [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch came forward to greet with an almost courtly welcome . '[110-god] But [[your]1531-you wife]1532-your wife , ' [he]0-i said ; '[110-god] can [she]1532-your wife not come ? [I]0-i trust all is well with [her]1532-your wife ? ' '[1532-your wife] All 's well with [her]1532-your wife , and thanking [you]1531-you for the question ; but all 's not well with [that young woman o ' yours]3731-that young woman o ' yours . '[1532-your wife] ' [I]179-petrovitch am very sorry , '[179-petrovitch] said [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , ' but [I]179-petrovitch am sure poor [Mrs Litvinoff]180-litvinoff could not be in better hands than those of [[your]179-petrovitch good , kind wife]3740-your good , kind wife . '[179-petrovitch] It was noticeable that [he]179-petrovitch never spoke of [Alice]134-alice save as [Mrs Litvinoff]180-litvinoff . ' And do [you]318-sir really like reading — those sort of books , [I]177-toomey mean , '[177-toomey] pointing to [Hegel]219-hegel 's ' Logic , '[177-toomey] which lay open on the table . ' [I]177-toomey like doing better than reading , but [one]504-one must read much to be able to do little in the line of work [I]177-toomey am on at present . '[177-toomey] ' [Your]179-petrovitch line of work , '[177-toomey] said [Toomey]177-toomey , glancing admiringly at [[his]177-toomey host]3411-his host , ' is a thing as [I]177-toomey never can get to understand . How it 's done , [I]177-toomey mean . Now , paving is straightforward . When [you]179-petrovitch 've got a paving - stone [you]179-petrovitch know what it is [you]179-petrovitch 've got , and how far it 'll go , but words is such shifty things , and how [you]179-petrovitch manage to make ['em]3744-'em[177-toomey] fit into each other so as to make ['em]3744-'em mean what [you]179-petrovitch mean is what gets over [me]177-toomey . '[177-toomey] ' Perhaps [I]177-toomey do n't always make [them]3745-them mean what [I]177-toomey mean . How are [you]220-pewtress ? Now [we]3747-we 're[177-toomey] all here but [Mr Vernon]221-vernon . ' '[221-vernon] [He]221-vernon 's coming [upstairs]3520-upstairs now , ' said [Pewtress]220-pewtress , [the stone - mason with the intellectual forehead]3748-the stone - mason with the intellectual forehead , who had been at [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid 's at the last meeting of [the Cleon]202-the cleon . [Mr Hirsch]222-hirsch seemed to be in more genial mood than [he]222-hirsch had been in any of those brief conversations which [we]3747-we hitherto had occasion to report . [He]222-hirsch had shaved [himself]222-hirsch — [he]222-hirsch even appeared to have combed [his]222-hirsch hair — and [he]222-hirsch shook hands with [Toomey]177-toomey quite warmly and cordially . [The host]3749-the host had gone half - way down the stairs to meet [[his]3749-the host fourth guest]3750-his fourth guest — [a lame boy]3751-a lame boy , whose crutches made it not easy for [him]3751-a lame boy to mount to the height of [[Petrovitch]179-petrovitch 's nest]3752-petrovitch 's nest . [He]3749-the host now returned with [him]3751-a lame boy on [his]3749-the host arm — and after a general introduction of [him]3749-the host to [the others]3402-the others [they]3402-the others all sat down to tea . [Eustace Vernon]223-vernon was [a lad of about eighteen , with a pale , highbred - looking face — a rather shy but pleasant manner]3754-a lad of about eighteen , with a pale , highbred - looking face — a rather shy but pleasant manner . [He]223-vernon was [an enthusiastic admirer of [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch]3755-an enthusiastic admirer of petrovitch , and since [his]223-vernon first acquaintance with [the Socialist]3756-the socialist had made a point of being present at all the meetings on social subjects that [he]223-vernon could get to hear of , and could find time to attend . For even the wild enthusiasm of [the revolutionary in [his]223-vernon teens]3757-the revolutionary in his teens will not go the length of working a Buddhist miracle and enabling [the youthful devotee]3758-the youthful devotee to be at more than one meeting at the same time . [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch was amused and a little touched by [the lad]3759-the lad 's undisguised homage — and knowing [himself]1535-his to be responsible for the inflammation of [the young man]2891-the young man 's mind , felt bound to keep watch lest [he]1535-his should get into trouble before [his]1535-his newly - kindled fire had had time to burn itself down into steadiness . As the meal went on it was noticeable that [Vernon]223-vernon 's love of liberty was not inconsistent with a child - like devotion to strawberry jam . [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch might have kept a school of instruction for the benefit of [those who are always making such desperate efforts to '[221-vernon] annihilate class distinctions'—efforts]3761-those who are always making such desperate efforts to ' annihilate class distinctions'—efforts which usually take place on Saturday afternoons , and are mostly the dismallest of failures . Under [his]1535-his influence [[his]1535-his four guests]1536-his four guests — born in [different parts of [the world]2867-the world]1537-different parts of the world , and drawn from different social grades — talked together with the ease of [club acquaintances]1539-club acquaintances . ' [I]179-petrovitch had hoped , '[179-petrovitch] said [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch by - and - by , ' to have had [a lady]437-a lady here to pour tea out for [you]3759-the lad , but fate has been unpropitious ; [Mrs Toomey]191-mrs toomey was not able to come . '[179-petrovitch] ' [I]222-hirsch regret [her]437-a lady , '[222-hirsch] said [Hirsch]222-hirsch . ' It always does [me]222-hirsch much pleasure to meet [[our]3763-our good friend 's good wife]3764-our good friend 's good wife . '[222-hirsch] [Toomey]191-mrs toomey looked flattered , but a little uncomfortable under this tribute . ' [She]437-a lady would have liked to come , '[179-petrovitch] said [he]179-petrovitch , trying to look straight at [the other]305-the other , but only succeeding in fixing one eye on [the Austrian]3564-the austrian , while the other searched the depths of the jam pot with an obstinacy which made [Vernon]223-vernon , who had the same in hand , simmer with warm awkwardness . '[223-vernon] ' So far as [I]179-petrovitch know [Michael Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , [he]121-litvinoff has never done more than [his]121-litvinoff clear duty . ' Oh , yes ; [he]121-litvinoff 'll talk , '[222-hirsch] said [Hirsch]222-hirsch discontentedly , and took a large bite of bread and butter . ' [You]223-vernon are quite right , [Mr Vernon]221-vernon , '[179-petrovitch] said [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch . '[191-mrs toomey] During the year or so that [I]0-i was in [the fortress of [Petro - Paolovski]228-petro - paolovski]1552-the fortress of petro - paolovski [I]0-i never encouraged the slightest hopes of escape , for in the first place [I]0-i , for a long time , suffered from a bad gunshot wound , and , secondly , because it is known only too well among [us]1547-us that escape from [Petro - Paolovski]228-petro - paolovski is impossible . When , for some unknown reason , [the Government]38-the government sent [me]0-i to [Tieff]227-tieff , [my]0-i health was improved , and so were [my]0-i chances of getting away , and from the moment [I]0-i entered [the prison]1553-the prison doors [I]0-i never lost an opportunity of making and maturing a plan of escape . Escaping from [a Russian prison]1554-a russian prison is not quite such a desperate business for one of [us]1547-us as it would be for one of [you]1555-you , for [you]1555-you would be like [a blind man in [a strange house]1557-a strange house]1556-a blind man in a strange house ; but those of [us]1547-us who are judged to be [the most likely subjects for arrest]1558-the most likely subjects for arrest make it a rule to have the plan of [every prison]1559-every prison and fortress at [our]1547-us finger - tips . ' '[1555-you] What a marvellous organisation [yours]1555-you is , ' said [the stone - mason]3777-the stone - mason , more as an excuse for escaping a moment from the martyrdom of [the unaccustomed cigarette]3778-the unaccustomed cigarette than by way of saying anything original . '[1555-you] Yes , the war is fairly well organised on both sides , ' [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch replied ; '[1555-you] but at present [they]1560-them have the big battalions . ' '[1555-you] But [your]1555-you plans , ' struck in [Vernon]221-vernon , impatient of the interruption . '[1555-you] Yes . Well , [my]0-i knowledge of [Tieff]227-tieff told [me]0-i that there was one way , and one way only , of leaving it , and that was by the way [I]0-i had come in — by the front gate , and to get to the front gate one had to cross [the courtyard]1561-the courtyard , and between [[my]0-i cell]1562-my cell and [the courtyard]1561-the courtyard lay obstacles too many to be calculated and dangers too great to be faced . ' '[1555-you] And [you]1555-you at once began to calculate them and to face [them]1560-them , ' cried [Vernon]221-vernon admiringly . '[1555-you] Rather to elude [them]1560-them , ' [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch went on , ignoring [the boy]3779-the boy 's compliment .
