Now the thing that had given [me]0-i most hope when [I]0-i heard [I]0-i was coming to [Tieff]227-tieff was that [I]0-i happened to know that [the resident doctor of [the prison]1553-the prison]1564-the resident doctor of the prison was , not exactly one of [us]1566-us , but [one who sympathised with [us]1566-us secretly]1567-one who sympathised with us secretly — there are [many such , who are unwilling to take an active part in the struggle]1568-many such , who are unwilling to take an active part in the struggle , but who , short of that , help [us]1566-us in many ways — for instance , with money , and especially by hiding [those of [us]1566-us who happen to be " wanted]1569-those of us who happen to be " wanted . " [We]1566-us call [them]1560-them [the Ukrivatelli]229-the ukrivatelli — [the concealers]1570-the concealers . ' '[1570-the concealers] [I]0-i hope there 's lots of [them]1560-them sort , [sir]318-sir , ' said [Toomey]191-mrs toomey , surreptitiously abandoning [his]0-i cigarette in favour of the more familiar but slightly stronger smelling '[318-sir] cutty . ' '[318-sir] But do n't [they]1560-them get [theirselves]1560-them into trouble ? ' '[1560-them] Yes , if [they]1560-them are found out , ' answered [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch ; '[1560-them] but [they]1560-them seldom are . [They]1560-them are [a very large class]1572-a very large class , and are often men whose official rank or social position places [them]1560-them beyond suspicion . [My]0-i wound still needed attention , and [I]0-i soon managed to convey to [the doctor]2896-the doctor a suggestion that daily exercise in [a prison courtyard]1574-a prison courtyard was a first - rate specific for gunshot wounds . [He]2896-the doctor seemed to think so too , and before the end of the week [I]0-i was told that [I]0-i should have to walk every day for an hour in the only place where a walk of a dozen consecutive yards was possible — in [the courtyard]1561-the courtyard . ' '[2896-the doctor] It was no use getting into [the courtyard]1561-the courtyard unless [I]0-i had some prospect of getting out of it , and straight into [some perfectly safe refuge]1577-some perfectly safe refuge . This was a matter that took some weeks to arrange , and during that time [I]0-i never turned [my]0-i eyes to the gate . [The doctor]2896-the doctor , though [he]2896-the doctor was willing to help [me]0-i , was not willing to risk [his]2896-the doctor own safety by carrying too many letters , and a whole code of signals had to be arranged . Luck seldom favours the right side ; but [I]0-i think [I]0-i was certainly lucky , for just when [I]0-i began to take [my]0-i daily exercise [the right wing of [the prison]1553-the prison]1579-the right wing of the prison had to be repaired , and consequently the gates of [the courtyard]1561-the courtyard were open all day for the carts of building materials , etc . , which had to come in and out . This must have seemed tolerably safe to [the authorities]1582-the authorities , as [I]0-i was [the only prisoner who " took exercise , "]1583-the only prisoner who " took exercise , " and there were [two sentries to whom was allotted]1584-two sentries to whom was allotted the pleasing duty of watching [me]0-i . [They]1584-two sentries to whom was allotted had a pretty easy time of it for these three weeks , for [I]0-i used to crawl up and down [the yard]1585-the yard in a feeble and dejected sort of way , as though [I]0-i had hardly the strength to put one foot before the other . [I]0-i always leaned on a stick , and did [my]0-i best to appear to be at [my]0-i last gasp . [I]0-i was well - nigh tired of waiting , so often [my]0-i escape seemed almost close at hand , and then something happened , and all [our]1586-our plans had to be made over again . Innumerable ideas were suggested , but abandoned for one reason or another . At last it was definitely settled that at a certain signal [I]0-i was to make for the gate and rush out — that [a carriage]1587-a carriage was to be waiting just outside , and that [one or two of [[our]1586-our friends]1589-our friends]1588-one or two of our friends were to be there promiscuously , to give false information in judicious doses , as it might be called for . The gate was almost exactly in the middle of [the courtyard]1561-the courtyard , and the beat of [sentry No . 1]1591-sentry no . 1 was from the gate to the end of [the yard]1585-the yard and back , and that of sentry No . 2 from the other end of [the yard]1585-the yard to the gate and back — thus the face of one of [them]1584-two sentries to whom was allotted was always towards the gate . At length the day came when [I]0-i might expect the signal — this was to be nothing more dramatic and startling than the smallest piece of paper that could well be seen — stuck on the shaft of one of [the builder]1594-the builder 's carts . Cart after cart went by , [my]0-i hour was nearly up , and [I]0-i began to feel pretty sure that either the signal was not to be given that morning , or else that it had been given and [I]0-i had missed seeing it . This last alternative was becoming a maddening certainty , when yet [another cart]1595-another cart came crawling in , and on the shaft , luckily on the side to which [my]0-i walk had now brought [me]0-i , was lightly stuck a little piece of white paper . Once more luck was [[my]0-i friend]1506-my friend , for [the sentry on the same side of the gate]1597-the sentry on the same side of the gate as [myself]0-i was marching from the gate , and between [me]0-i and [the one walking towards the gate]1598-the one walking towards the gate was [the cart]1599-the cart . Had [any one not in the secret]1600-any one not in the secret been watching [me]0-i from one of the prison windows at that moment [he]1600-any one not in the secret would certainly have thought that [I]0-i was the subject of a miraculous cure , for in what seemed to [me]0-i about half - a - dozen bounds [I]0-i was at the side of [the cart]1599-the cart , out of the gate , and in one of two carriages which were passing at the time . ' '[1604-the two sentries] And what steps did [the authorities]1582-the authorities take ? ' asked [Pewtress]220-pewtress , in the perfectly unexcited and matter - of - fact tone of [a School Board inspector]3780-a school board inspector . '[1604-the two sentries] Well , ' said [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , laughing a little , '[1604-the two sentries] [I]0-i was not there at the time , but [[my]0-i friends]1236-my friends told [me]0-i that what followed was well worth seeing . A few seconds after [my]0-i disappearance [the two sentries]1604-the two sentries and [the whole of the guard from [the guard - room inside [the prison]1553-the prison]1606-the guard - room inside the prison]1605-the whole of the guard from the guard - room inside the prison came swarming into [the street]557-the street , and there was a most delightful hue - and - cry and clamour . ' '[0-i] But where did [the other carriage]1619-the other carriage take [you]0-i ? ' [The Austrian]3564-the austrian was beginning to protest that nothing had ever happened to [him]222-hirsch , when a rustle of silk on the stairs outside silenced [him]222-hirsch , and [the men]1128-the men all looked at [each other]2934-each other inquiringly in the moment that elapsed before the door was opened and disclosed the velvet bonnet and abundant flounces of [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid . '[179-petrovitch] ' It 's very good of [you]179-petrovitch to honour [me]179-petrovitch with a call , '[179-petrovitch] said [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , wondering intensely what had brought [her]1642-her [there]2994-there . ' [We]1640-we have been to see [some friends at [Regent 's Park]59-regent 's park]3790-some friends at regent 's park , and [we]1640-we are going on to dine with [the Pagets—(you]234-the pagets—(you know [the Pagets]235-the pagets , [Mr Petrovitch]179-petrovitch ? No ! [You]179-petrovitch 'll excuse an informal invitation , [I]179-petrovitch know . '[179-petrovitch] ' [You]179-petrovitch are very kind , '[179-petrovitch] said [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , wondering whether [he]179-petrovitch could find any means of evading an acceptance . ' [I]179-petrovitch had hoped to have had [[your]179-petrovitch fellow - countryman]3793-your fellow - countryman , [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , there to meet [you]179-petrovitch ; but [I]179-petrovitch hear [he]121-litvinoff has just gone to [Derbyshire]12-derbyshire ; so unfortunate . '[179-petrovitch] asked [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , amused . ' Because [your]201-mrs quaid lives are so constantly in danger . '[179-petrovitch] ' There 's not much danger in [Derbyshire]12-derbyshire , '[222-hirsch] broke in [Hirsch]222-hirsch , in spite of [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch 's restraining eye . There is so much that wants doing [here]2895-here . [We]3804-we want [good , brave workers]3805-good , brave workers to strive to bridge over the terrible gulf between the classes . '[201-mrs quaid] [Toomey]191-mrs toomey , suddenly recalled to a sense of the ' gulf'—which [he]233-mr quaid had quite lost sight of under the influence of [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch 's tact — felt a painfully renewed consciousness of [his]233-mr quaid boots , [his]233-mr quaid hands , and [his]233-mr quaid Sunday clothes . [Vernon]221-vernon , who knew [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid , and delighted to '[179-petrovitch] draw ' [her]201-mrs quaid , would not for [the world]2867-the world have missed such an opportunity of amusing [himself]221-vernon and [[his]221-vernon friends]771-his friends . By a skilful question or two [he]221-vernon led [the lady]3443-the lady on to [her]3443-the lady favourite subject — that of education . [She]3443-the lady could discuss this question with eloquence , and at any length ; but no matter how [her]3443-the lady discussions began , they always ended by placing [her]3443-the lady and [[her]3443-the lady hearers]3809-her hearers in a difficulty . [She]3443-the lady was quite clear that before [we]3810-we could educate [[our]3810-we children]3811-our children [we]3810-we must be educated [ourselves]3810-we , which , on the face of it , seemed reasonable ; but , then , who was there to educate [us]3810-we ? To that question no answer could ever be found ; and in the meantime , what was to become of [the rising generation]3812-the rising generation ? [She]3443-the lady had nearly reached this point when [[her]3443-the lady husband]1245-her husband , who had been present before when [she]3443-the lady trotted round [this circle of argument , and for whom the repetition of the performance had no charms]3814-this circle of argument , and for whom the repetition of the performance had no charms , brought the conversation back to [the world of possibilities]3815-the world of possibilities by renewing the invitation for [Tuesday]237-tuesday , which [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , after a little hesitation , accepted . ' '[1648-you] No , ' said [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch slowly . '[1648-you] No ; that is not to be . ' THANK [God]110-god ! '[121-litvinoff] was [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's inward ejaculation , as , followed by [Roland]107-roland , [he]121-litvinoff sprang through the laurel bushes into the gravel path that skirted [the lawn]1649-the lawn . For what [he]121-litvinoff saw was not what [he]121-litvinoff had feared to see . [Clare]218-clare was safe . [She]218-clare was standing on the last of the stone steps that led down from [the verandah]1650-the verandah , [her]218-clare hands clasped over [her]218-clare eyes , as if to shut out some intolerable sight . '[218-clare] But [Mrs Stanley]216-mrs stanley needed no telling . '[107-roland] Then , as it suddenly occurred to [him]107-roland that this might possibly be considered personal , [he]107-roland went on in [his]107-roland most approved didactic manner,—'Since death is inevitable , how lucky [we]1676-they ought to think it that [so few people]1677-so few people have anything to live for . [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff could , perhaps , have succeeded with a desperate effort in raising the cloud of gloom that hung over [them]3853-them both , but it did not seem to [him]121-litvinoff that the game was quite worth the candle , and [he]121-litvinoff let it alone . Under the circumstances there could be no shooting , and none of such social entertainments as would certainly otherwise have enlivened [his]121-litvinoff visit , and the prospect of [his]121-litvinoff first Christmas in [an English country - house]3854-an english country - house looked very bleak . ' [He]0-i puffed at [his]0-i cigar in silence a few minutes , then [he]0-i spoke aloud again , '[1693-my crushed young host] And so that was [John Hatfield]135-john hatfield , and [he]135-john hatfield is [one of [us]1696-us]1695-one of us — or [half one of [us]1696-us]1697-half one of us . [By Jove]125-jove ! that makes [me]0-i feel [a cursed traitor]1698-a cursed traitor — that merits death . Well , [I]0-i 'm not afraid of that , anyhow , nor of anything that may come after . [I]0-i 've got memories enough to make a hell of [my]0-i own [here]2895-here , and death would be the end of them , at any rate , not the beginning . And yet [one]504-one must live , [I]0-i suppose , though [I]0-i do n't feel so sure of that to - night . [Poor little girl]3859-poor little girl — [dear little girl]3860-dear little girl ! [The real heiress]3862-the real heiress is pretty and charming , and [a lady]437-a lady , '[0-i] with a rather bitter laugh , ' and [she]3862-the real heiress is beginning to have " views ; " but somehow [I]0-i ca n't get [you]3860-dear little girl out of [my]0-i head to - night . '[0-i] [He]0-i moved [his]0-i hand to and fro before [his]0-i eyes , as though to clear away the smoke . Then [he]0-i rose . ' Curses on conscience — curses on principle ! '[0-i] [he]0-i said ; ' [I]0-i must see if sleep will do it ; '[0-i] and [he]0-i went to bed . During the next few days there was nothing to do except to call at [Aspinshaw]105-aspinshaw every day and ask after [Mrs]1699-mrs and [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley . This was an obvious duty , but as an occupation it was not engrossing . On the second day , [young Ferrier]107-roland offered to ' show [[his]107-roland guest]3321-his guest over '[121-litvinoff] [the mill]2936-the mill , and [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , always glad of a new experience , joyfully consented . [The mill]2936-the mill was charmingly situated in [a little hollow in [the hills]1703-the hills]1702-a little hollow in the hills , with [a big reservoir above [it]2936-the mill and [a little stream below]1705-a little stream below]1704-a big reservoir above it and a little stream below . On one side was [a wood , where a good many hollies kept up the impression of greenness]1706-a wood , where a good many hollies kept up the impression of greenness , though all the other trees were sere and brown . On the other side was a very steep incline which shot up almost like a high wall , and was bare and rugged and rocky , and from the top some rude steps cut out of [the grey rock]1707-the grey rock led down to [the mill]2936-the mill . While the workings of the machinery were being explained , and the various processes exhibited , it did not escape [the Count]3057-the count 's observation that [the men]1128-the men looked particularly discontented , and that there was none of that deferential submission in [their]1128-the men manner to [Roland]107-roland which [he]3057-the count had been accustomed to see in the manner of [workmen]1711-workmen towards [[their]1128-the men masters]1712-their masters . ' [They]1128-the men looked uncommonly disagreeable . [[My]121-litvinoff friend]1506-my friend [John Hatfield]135-john hatfield does n't appear to be the only one who is dissatisfied with the munificent two pounds a week . '[121-litvinoff] ' [John Hatfield]135-john hatfield ! What a memory [you]121-litvinoff have for names . ' '[1128-the men] Oh , beautiful system ! ' said [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff ; '[1128-the men] splendid organisation of industry ! ' That evening [John Hatfield]135-john hatfield was sitting on the oak settle by [[his]135-john hatfield hearth]3890-his hearth , [[his]135-john hatfield wife]522-his wife with [her]522-his wife knitting in the substantial rocking - chair opposite . The interior was cosy and bright enough . A high wooden screen protected [the inmates]3892-the inmates from any cold air that might else have come through the door , which opened straight from [the house - place]3893-the house - place into [the street]557-the street . A short red curtain hung in front of the long low window , that was nearly as wide as [the room]2910-the room [itself]2910-the room . There was a chintz flounce to the chimney - piece , and a bright round table , on three legs , in the middle of [the room]2910-the room . There was a good deal of shining brass about , and a few pieces of old china . But the poor age much more rapidly than the rich . Significant reflection . [CLARE STANLEY]139-clare was [the mistress of Aspinshaw]1753-the mistress of aspinshaw , and of a good deal of bricks and mortar , stocks and shares , and Three per Cent . Consols besides . [Mrs Stanley]216-mrs stanley was comfortably provided for , but it was [[Clare]139-clare who was to profit by the hard work , the self - denial and forethought of [some three generations of [Stanleys]146-the stanleys]1755-some three generations of stanleys , or , as some might think , of [their]1755-some three generations of stanleys greed , [their]1755-some three generations of stanleys grasping , and [their]1755-some three generations of stanleys over - reaching of [[their]1755-some three generations of stanleys less crafty fellow - men]1756-their less crafty fellow - men]1754-clare who was to profit by the hard work , the self - denial and forethought of some three generations of stanleys , or , as some might think , of their greed , their grasping , and their over - reaching of their less crafty fellow - men . The will that had laid the burden of wealth upon [her]139-clare , at an age when [most young women of [her]139-clare class]1757-most young women of her class are engaged in constant differences with [[their]1757-most young women of her class parents]1758-their parents and [guardians]1759-guardians on the subject of pin - money , had been the one act of eccentricity of [Mr Stanley]119-mr stanley 's whole life . For some days [her]139-clare grief for [[her]139-clare father]391-her father 's loss had been too absorbing to permit of [her]139-clare thinking of much else besides , but on this first day of the new year [she]139-clare felt more able to think , and as [she]139-clare sat alone by the drawing - room fire [she]139-clare began for the first time to realise [her]139-clare position . About one thing [she]139-clare had made up [her]139-clare mind ; [she]139-clare must leave [this horrible house]1761-this horrible house , where the shadow had fallen on [her]139-clare which [she]139-clare felt just then could never be lifted again . Between [Clare]139-clare and [[her]139-clare father 's second wife]1762-her father 's second wife there had always been perfectly cordial relations , but [they]1763-they were not bound together by any ties of love . [Mrs Stanley]216-mrs stanley had always done [her]216-mrs stanley duty to [[her]216-mrs stanley husband]1245-her husband and [[his]1245-her husband child]1765-his child , but [hers]1766-hers was a cold nature , and not one which had drawn out [Clare]139-clare 's heart towards itself . [She]216-mrs stanley was now going to stay with [[her]216-mrs stanley own relatives]1767-her own relatives , and was perfectly willing to take [[her]216-mrs stanley step - daughter]1768-her step - daughter with [her]216-mrs stanley ; but [the girl]367-the girl decided , without much need for reflection , that there would be many things better than to be buried alive in [a Yorkshire village]1770-a yorkshire village , with [no one]494-no one more congenial to talk to than [Mrs Stanley]216-mrs stanley or [[Mrs Stanley]216-mrs stanley 's relations]1772-mrs stanley 's relations , whom [Clare]139-clare had been wo nt to term ' [the fossils]3905-the fossils . '[139-clare] An unposted letter lay on the little table at [her]139-clare elbow , in which [she]139-clare had accepted an invitation to spend an indefinite time with [the Quaids]244-the quaids . [She]139-clare thought that in [London]6-london , away from the associations of the recent past , [she]139-clare would be better able to plan out the course of [her]139-clare future life . [She]139-clare knew that that course would now be a very different one from what it would have been had [she]139-clare had the planning of it three months ago , before [she]139-clare met [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff or spent that evening at [the Cleon]202-the cleon . [She]139-clare was sorrowfully glad that [[her]139-clare father]391-her father 's will was what it was , for [she]139-clare was conscious in a vague sort of way that wealth meant power , and [she]139-clare was determined that in [her]139-clare hands it should mean power to do good and to make [others]658-others happy . [Her]139-clare plans went no further than this at present , and [she]139-clare knew that even to carry this out [she]139-clare would need teaching and help and counsel from [those who had more experience of [the world]2867-the world and its needs than [she]139-clare had]1775-those who had more experience of the world and its needs than she had . It was , perhaps , this thought that had mainly influenced [her]139-clare in [her]139-clare acceptance of [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid 's very kind and cordial invitation , for [Marlborough Villa]69-marlborough villa was not [the most unlikely place in [the world]2867-the world]1777-the most unlikely place in the world at which to meet [some one who had just that which [she]139-clare lacked]1779-some one who had just that which she lacked . There [she]139-clare had first been forced to think ; perhaps there [she]139-clare would first be taught how to act . Why does [one]504-one never learn at school the things [one]504-one needs when [one]504-one leaves [it]1782-it ? ' How much there is to know — how much there is for [me]139-clare to learn , '[139-clare] [she]139-clare said to [herself]139-clare , with a little sigh , leaning forward and gazing into the glowing fire , resting [her]139-clare elbow on [her]139-clare knee and [her]139-clare cheek on [her]139-clare clasped hands . ' [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff looked intensely surprised , as though that had been almost impossible . '[0-i] [I]0-i think [I]0-i told [you]1785-one who would as soon go to siberia as not while he was about it about [her]1786-a lady who is madly anxious to know you , ' [she]139-clare continued ; '[0-i] [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid , who belongs to [the Cleon]202-the cleon , [you]1785-one who would as soon go to siberia as not while he was about it know , where [I]0-i heard all about [Socialism]206-socialism , [you]1785-one who would as soon go to siberia as not while he was about it remember ? ' '[206-socialism] Oh , yes , [I]0-i remember , ' said [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , which was true . [He]0-i did . ' Ah , no , [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff had certainly not heard that . '[0-i] And then , [you]1785-one who would as soon go to siberia as not while he was about it see , ' [she]122-miss stanley went on , knitting [her]122-miss stanley brows under the stress of the difficulty [she]122-miss stanley found in putting [her]122-miss stanley thoughts into words , '[0-i] the question is , what am [I]0-i to do with it ? A little time ago [I]0-i should have found it easy enough to do with it what [every one else]1790-every one else does ; but [I]0-i have been thinking a great deal — a very great deal lately — ever since [I]0-i heard [Mr Petrovitch]179-petrovitch ; and now [I]0-i feel the responsibility of it so much more than [I]0-i should have done before . ' [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff thought to [himself]121-litvinoff that that was the sort of responsibility [he]121-litvinoff was admirably adapted to share . [He]121-litvinoff merely looked sympathetic , and [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley went on . '[0-i] And then [I]0-i feel sure money may be a fearful curse if [one]504-one does n't use it properly . Of course , [I]0-i ca n't disguise from [myself]0-i that this money was made in the usual way , and that [others]658-others have lost all that [[my]0-i father]3241-my father and [[his]3241-my father father]2890-his father have gained , and [I]0-i wish [I]0-i could think of some way in which it might give as much happiness as it would have done had it been left in the hands of [the workers who toiled to produce it]1795-the workers who toiled to produce it . [You]1796-you are one who should be able to advise [me]0-i . What shall [I]0-i do ? ' [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's hair almost stood on end . This was getting [his]121-litvinoff own coin back with a vengeance . '[362-my dear] [[My]0-i dear]362-my dear [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley , ' [he]0-i said gravely , '[362-my dear] if [I]0-i were to advise [you]122-miss stanley in the only way which seems possible to [me]0-i now , [[your]122-miss stanley friends]3352-your friends would all look upon [me]0-i as [[your]122-miss stanley worst enemy]1799-your worst enemy — as [an adventurer]1800-an adventurer , as [a rogue]1801-a rogue . Whereas [I]0-i desire to be looked on as [[your]122-miss stanley faithful friend]1802-your faithful friend and servant — as [the man who , more than all others , would go through fire and water to do [you]122-miss stanley the slightest service]1803-the man who , more than all others , would go through fire and water to do you the slightest service . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i should hardly have thought [you]122-miss stanley would have cared what [[my]0-i friends]1236-my friends or [anybody else]1805-anybody else thought of [you]122-miss stanley , ' was [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley 's only reply to this fervid declaration . '[122-miss stanley] Under most circumstances , ' said [the Count]3057-the count , with a little wave of [his]3057-the count hand , '[0-i] [I]0-i do care for nothing and for [nobody]1806-nobody ; [but'—he]0-i went on , with a slight tremor in [his]0-i voice—'rather than incur the dislike of [any one whom [you]122-miss stanley respect and love]1807-any one whom you respect and love , [I]0-i would abjure every principle , and sacrifice every cause . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i asked for advice , ' said [Clare]139-clare , not seeing [her]139-clare way to a more direct answer . '[0-i] [I]0-i know [you]122-miss stanley did , ' [he]0-i spoke rapidly , dropping into a foreign accent ; '[0-i] and [I]0-i — [I]0-i can not give it [you]122-miss stanley , [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley . Let [me]0-i tell [you]122-miss stanley one thing . [You]122-miss stanley know — [you]122-miss stanley have heard , [you]122-miss stanley have read — how in [Russia]26-russia , when money is wanted for [our]1808-our cause , it is the duty of some of [us]1808-our to get it — to persuade it out of [those who have]1809-those who have . That has often been [my]0-i duty , and [I]0-i have never failed . [I]0-i have taken , over and over again , all , all from those as young as [you]122-miss stanley , and have left [them]1809-those who have with nothing . [I]0-i have had to raise enthusiasm by every means , to urge to self - sacrifice , and then to take unsparingly . There are [men]466-men now , [[my]0-i friends]1236-my friends , who , if [they]1236-my friends knew that [you]122-miss stanley — rich , young , enthusiastic — had asked [me]0-i for advice , and that [I]0-i had refused to give it , would say , " [Michael Litvinoff]121-litvinoff has become [traitor]1812-traitor , " and would kill [me]0-i like a rat . But , ' [he]0-i went on , rising and stretching out [his]0-i clenched fist , '[0-i] did [I]0-i know that [a legion of such men]1813-a legion of such men were outside that door , armed and waiting for [me]0-i , and hearing every word [I]0-i speak , [I]0-i would still say that for no cause in [the world]2867-the world must [you]122-miss stanley make sacrifices or must [you]122-miss stanley suffer ; and [I]0-i would still say that [I]0-i would serve [you]122-miss stanley before all causes . ' '[121-litvinoff] [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , [I]0-i can hear no more of this . Please talk of something else . ' [Clare]139-clare did not gainsay it , and [he]0-i left [the room]2910-the room . [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff was marching back to [Thornsett]30-thornsett with a very elate step , and a good deal of military swagger , and [Clare]139-clare had resumed [her]139-clare thinking — [she]139-clare was thinking of [him]121-litvinoff , and [he]121-litvinoff was thinking of [her]139-clare . '[141-mrs hatfield] spoke [Mrs Hatfield]141-mrs hatfield , a little plaintively , as [[her]141-mrs hatfield husband]1245-her husband rose and took down [his]1245-her husband hat from its peg , ten days after [Thornsett Mill]13-thornsett mill had been closed . '[1822-tha] And [he]1822-tha went out , slamming the door behind [him]1822-tha , and [[his]1822-tha wife]522-his wife took up [her]522-his wife knitting with a sigh . [She]522-his wife could rarely follow [[her]522-his wife husband]1245-her husband in [his]1822-tha reasonings , but troubles are not the less hard to bear because [we]1830-we do n't clearly see [their]1831-their causes . [They]1831-their had saved a little money , but that would soon be gone , and then there would be nothing before [them]1831-their but ' [the house]291-the house . '[1834-a sailor] Both [[their]1831-their sons]1832-their sons were away — [one]504-one [a sailor]1834-a sailor , and the other in [a warehouse in [Liverpool]14-liverpool]1835-a warehouse in liverpool — but [neither]1836-neither was earning enough to be able to help [[their]1832-their sons parents]1758-their parents . Vaguely [she]522-his wife hoped that [[her]522-his wife husband]1245-her husband might take it into [his]1822-tha head to go to [London]6-london for work . An idea is prevalent in [the provinces]1839-the provinces that in [London]6-london there is work for [every one]1840-every one , and besides , [Alice]134-alice had written from [London]6-london , and there would be a chance of finding [[her]134-alice poor lost child]1841-her poor lost child and bringing [her]1841-her poor lost child back . The sudden closing of [the mill]2936-the mill made affairs indeed terribly serious for [most of [the men in [Thornsett]30-thornsett]1844-the men in thornsett]1843-most of the men in thornsett . It was in the middle of winter , when journeying was not pleasant , nor work easy to get ; and though [the ' hands '[1845-the ' hands ' employed in the mill] employed in [the mill]2936-the mill]1845-the ' hands ' employed in the mill had been told that it would close , very , [very few among [them]1845-the ' hands ' employed in the mill]1847-very few among them had made any effort to secure other work before the time for closing came . Perhaps it had seemed to [them]1843-most of the men in thornsett that the closing of [the mill]2936-the mill was one of those calamities too terrible to happen . But it had happened , and after ten days of idleness [the men]1128-the men were beginning to see clearly what it would mean to [them]1128-the men . For there was no other work to be got within anything like easy reach of [the village]3667-the village ; and even if work could be obtained somewhere else , [the little community]1851-the little community must be broken up , and [each family]1852-each family must separate [itself]1852-each family from [friends]2905-friends and [neighbours]1854-neighbours and [relatives]1855-relatives in order to journey thither . This alone is thought a terrible calamity for [middle - class men]1856-middle - class men and [women]3217-women , but it is the least of the troubles which are always hanging over the heads of [the workers]2870-the workers . The exodus that must shortly take place had not yet begun , but [every one]1840-every one knew that it could not now be long delayed ; and [Potters]3024-potters and [the few other tradespeople]1861-the few other tradespeople being , of course , involved in the general distress , could no longer give credit . This had never been withheld in slack times , when [the shopkeepers]1862-the shopkeepers knew that [good ones]1863-good ones were certain to come in which the scores would be wiped off or reduced very considerably ; but now there was no chance of things growing brighter again , and even the small accounts then owing were not very likely ever to be paid . During the past ten days , as [the men]1128-the men 's money was being spent , and as the want of work gave [them]1128-the men more time to reason on the causes of [their]1128-the men trouble , a strong feeling of resentment had been growing up among [them]1128-the men against [the two young masters , who had held , as it were]1865-the two young masters , who had held , as it were , the happiness , the comfort , perhaps the lives , of all [these men]3868-these men in [their]1865-the two young masters , who had held , as it were hands , and had thrown all to the dogs rather than humble [their]1865-the two young masters , who had held , as it were own insensate pride and abate [their]1865-the two young masters , who had held , as it were own insensate obstinacy . This feeling had found vent , not only in the scowls and black looks on which [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff had commented , but in certain faint groans and hisses with which [Roland]107-roland had been greeted on more than one occasion when [he]107-roland passed down [the village street]1867-the village street . What right had [these two , on whose forbearance and good fellowship]1868-these two , on whose forbearance and good fellowship hung the fate of [all these families]1869-all these families , to go quarrelling with [each other]2934-each other ? ' It 's a '[1128-the men] [their]1128-the men darn'd selfishness , ' [Murdoch]128-murdoch was saying , just as [Hatfield]134-alice kicked open the door of [the tap - room at [the Spotted Cow]3933-the spotted cow]3932-the tap - room at the spotted cow , and passed in . '[1128-the men] What 's the odds to [them]1128-the men if [we]1871-we clem or if [we]1871-we dunna't ? ' '[1128-the men] It 's [my]0-i belief , ' said [Potters]131-potters bitterly , '[0-i] as [they]1128-the men done it to show [their]1128-the men independence . ' '[1128-the men] [They]1128-the men might have hit on a cheaper way , ' growled [Hatfield]134-alice , as [Murdoch]128-murdoch and [Sigley]129-sigley made room for [him]128-murdoch to sit between [them]1128-the men . '[1128-the men] Cheaper ! why , what 's cheaper nor [our]1871-we flesh and blood ? ' asked [Murdoch]128-murdoch , with a snarl . '[1128-the men] [They]1128-the men can afford to chuck a little o ' that away . [They]1128-the men can get more of it when [they]1128-the men want it easy enow . '[134-alice] ' Ay , that 's it , [lad]2907-lad , '[134-alice] said [Hatfield]134-alice . ' It 's the flesh and blood o '[134-alice] some o ' [us]1871-we that 's here still , and more o '[1128-the men] [us]1871-we that 's dead and gone , that 's made the bit o ' money [they]1128-the men 'll live on for the rest o '[134-alice] [their]1128-the men days . ' '[134-alice] Well , [I]0-i do n't quite see that , ' muttered [Sigley]129-sigley , with [his]129-sigley usual meekness . '[0-i] [They]1128-the men 've always paid fair wages . ' '[1128-the men] Yes , ' answered [Hatfield]134-alice . '[1128-the men] [Ah]1872-ah never said [they]1128-the men took it for nothing . [They]1128-the men paid for it right enow , but [they]1128-the men bought it cheap , [lad]2907-lad — [they]1128-the men bought it cheap , and [they]1128-the men sold [it]1874-it at a good profit . [We]1871-we 've nowt but [our]1871-we flesh and blood to sell , and now [we]1871-we mun carry it to another market . ' '[2907-lad] If [you]2907-lad mean [your]2907-lad work , ' put in [the landlord]3006-the landlord , '[2907-lad] [I]0-i do n't see as [you]2907-lad ought to talk [i]0-i ' that way . ' [They]1128-the men paid [us]1871-we what [we]1871-we was forced to take . '[134-alice] ' Thou'dst always some sense [i]119-mr stanley '[119-mr stanley] [tha]1875-tha head , [John]119-mr stanley , ' broke in [old Murdoch]128-murdoch approvingly . '[119-mr stanley] [Tha]1875-tha was na here when .... D'ye mind , [Bolt]127-bolt , the night after t'owd [master]1876-master 's burying , [tha]1875-tha made [the lads]3925-the lads drink [t ' young masters]3936-t ' young masters '[127-bolt] health ? Ask [them]3925-the lads to drink it now ! ' The murmur of ironical assent which went round [the room]2910-the room showed that [Murdoch]128-murdoch had expressed the sense of the meeting . [He]128-murdoch had been rising in importance daily , ever since the announcement of [the mill]2936-the mill 's closing . [He]128-murdoch had always been [the prophet of calamity]3939-the prophet of calamity , and now that [his]128-murdoch worst prophecies had been more than fulfilled [he]128-murdoch was looked upon as little less than inspired . '[127-bolt] Well , ' said [Bolt]127-bolt deprecatingly , '[127-bolt] who could ha ' foreseen things turning out [i]127-bolt '[127-bolt] this way ? And as for asking [them]3925-the lads to drink [their]3925-the lads healths , why [they]3925-the lads ai n't [[their]3925-the lads masters]1712-their masters now . So where 's the use ? ' '[127-bolt] It do seem hard , it do , ' murmured [Sigley]129-sigley , who went to [chapel]655-chapel regularly , '[127-bolt] when [a man have saved up a bit to have it all swept away in a rushing , mighty wind]1879-a man have saved up a bit to have it all swept away in a rushing , mighty wind , and [us]1880-we left , like [Pharaoh]247-pharaoh 's lean kine , to make bricks without straw . The whole creation groaneth ! ... ' '[127-bolt] Well , do n't groan here , ' interrupted [Murdoch]128-murdoch grimly ; '[127-bolt] tha'd best do tha groanin ' wi '[127-bolt] the rest o ' creation at [t '[127-bolt] chapel]3941-t ' chapel ; and well mayst [tha]1881-tha groan [there]2994-there if [tha]1881-tha hears tell o ' cows makin '[1881-tha] bricks . ' '[3925-the lads] [Them]3925-the lads as do n't believe in the Bible , ' said [Sigley]129-sigley impressively , giving voice to a very popular belief , '[3925-the lads] ca n't look for a blessing . ' '[3925-the lads] Nor yet [them]3925-the lads as does , it seems . ' '[3925-the lads] What [ah]1881-tha was going to say was this — as [we]1880-we should take comfort , thinking as [we]1880-we ai n't [the only ones]1883-the only ones . ' '[3262-the man] Comfort , tha loon!—that 's the hell of it ! Damn [the man]3262-the man , says [I]0-i , as can find comfort [i]0-i ' t '[1885-he] thought o ' [other men]733-other men 's misery ! '[1885-he] It was [Hatfield]134-alice who spoke , and as [he]1885-he spoke [he]1885-he brought [his]1885-he fist down on the table with a bang that made the glasses ring . ' How tha does take on , [John]127-bolt , '[127-bolt] said [Bolt]127-bolt . ' What [Sigley]129-sigley meant was only as it shows [you]127-bolt ai n't to blame , seeing as [so many others]3295-so many others is in the same fix . '[127-bolt] [Sigley]129-sigley did not confirm this interpretation . [He]129-sigley only shook [his]129-sigley head , with the air of [one who had meant something much more pious and profound]1886-one who had meant something much more pious and profound . ' [You]1887-you 're[129-sigley] wrong again , ' said [Hatfield]134-alice loudly . [He]1885-he had risen and faced [the room]2910-the room , which was now pretty full . While this talk had been going on , [men]466-men had dropped in by twos and threes , and all that had been said had been listened to with profound attention . '[129-sigley] [You]1887-you 're wrong again ! It is [our]3946-us faults , and the faults of [all like [us]3946-us]3947-all like us . [[Our]3946-us fathers]3948-our fathers might have altered it . [We]3946-us might alter it now if [we]3946-us had but the spunk to take it in hand ; and , if [we]3946-us do n't , [them]466-men as comes after [us]3946-us will , and'll curse [us]3946-us for leaving [them]466-men the work to do . Did n't none o '[129-sigley] [ye]1888-ye ever hear tell o ' the elephant that lets [himself]1889-he be led and mastered by one [he]1889-he could smash with a shake o '[1889-he] [his]1889-he poll ? And why ? Because , the books tell [us]1890-we , [he]1889-he doesna know [his]1889-he own strength . But [he]1889-he doesna fare so bad as [we]1890-we . [He]1889-he gets well fed and well looked after because it costs summat to replace [him]1889-he , and [we]1890-we lets [oursels]1890-we be led and drove and starved , when it suits ['em]3949-'em , by a set as [we]1890-we could chase out o '[127-bolt] [the world]2867-the world to - morrow if [we]1890-we but stood together and acted like [men]466-men . ' A thrill of excited sympathy ran through [the room]2910-the room as [old Murdoch]128-murdoch shouted , — '[0-i] Right again ! That 's it , [John]127-bolt ; tha 's got it ! A score thousand o ' [your]127-bolt pattern and there 'd be an end to [men]466-men being turned out o '[0-i] [[their]466-men homes]1893-their homes to clem [i]0-i ' midwinter because [two young devils]3952-two young devils both wants [the same lass]3953-the same lass ! '[0-i] ' It 's all very well , [Hatfield]134-alice , '[131-potters] said [Potters]131-potters sourly ; ' but tha 's one face for [us]1890-we and another face for [t '[131-potters] gentlefolk]3954-t ' gentlefolk . That warn't [no working man]1894-no working man as [I]0-i 've see comin ' out o '[0-i] [[your]127-bolt house]3348-your house time and again this last three week . ' '[1896-he] No , [he]1896-he ai n't . '[1896-he] ' Whatever [he]1896-he 's got in [him]1896-he , [he]1896-he seems pretty thick with [young Roland Ferrier]107-roland , '[1897-a man who had not spoken before] said [a man who had not spoken before]1897-a man who had not spoken before . ' [He]1896-he did [his]1896-he best to stop [their]1898-their quarrelling , '[1897-a man who had not spoken before] [Hatfield]134-alice answered hotly ; ' because [he]1896-he knew what it would be for [all o '[1898-their] [us]1898-their]3955-all o ' us ; and [he]1896-he 's been chased out o ' [[his]1896-he own country]3956-his own country and lost nearly all [his]1896-he brass for standing up for [the likes o ']3957-the likes o '[1898-their] [we]1898-their . '[1896-he] ' [He]1896-he 's [a true friend o '[1896-he] working men]3960-a true friend o ' working men , [he]1896-he is , if [he]1896-he is [a Count]605-a count . ' [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , it will be seen , had not lost [his]121-litvinoff opportunities while [he]121-litvinoff had been at [Thornsett]30-thornsett , for nearly [every man present]3961-every man present had something to say in [his]121-litvinoff favour . Has any of [you]1904-you spoke to [him]1896-he ? Has [any one of [you]1904-you]1905-any one of you put it straight to [him]1896-he — this is the way of it , and this and this ? '[1904-you] ' [Old heads]3967-old heads is worth most , arter all , '[127-bolt] said [John Bolt]127-bolt , who was of a hopeful nature and turned to the new idea as a relief from [his]127-bolt former visions of empty benches and deserted bar,—of a time when there would be nothing to chalk up but [his]127-bolt own losses , and when adulterated beer would seem what it was , a drug in the market . ' Why should n't some of [you]1904-you do as [he]1896-he says , and go and see [him]1896-he and speak [him]1896-he reasonable ? '[248-clayton] A great difference of opinion arose at once on the new idea , but nearly all were in [their]1907-their hearts glad to try a new chance , and at last [old Clayton]248-clayton , from whom the suggestion had come , said , — ' Well , [sithee]3968-sithee , if any of [you]1904-you lads'll come wi '[248-clayton] [me]0-i , dang [me]0-i if [I]0-i 'll not go this very night — this very minute . ' '[248-clayton] [You]1908-we 'd better all go , ' advised [Potters]131-potters ; '[1908-we] it would be more telling like . '[129-sigley] If two or three o ' [ye]1908-we was to go round and tell [the other lads]3969-the other lads what 's towards , [they]3969-the other lads 'd come too , and [we]1908-we 'd have one more try at getting things righted here , afore [we]1908-we all turns different ways and never sees [each other]2934-each other 's faces again . '[129-sigley] No sooner said than done . [Men]466-men are ready at all times to follow [any one who will act , or even to act themselves if prompted with sufficient energy]1911-any one who will act , or even to act themselves if prompted with sufficient energy . '[134-alice] [He]1919-he and [Murdoch]128-murdoch stood at the door with Bolt and Potters , and [a few more who , not having been employed in [the mill]2936-the mill , were considered not to have any place in [the deputation]1922-the deputation]1920-a few more who , not having been employed in the mill , were considered not to have any place in the deputation . [They]1923-they watched [the crowd]392-the crowd out of sight up [the steep street]1925-the steep street , and [the women]1926-the women turned out to watch [[their]1926-the women men]1927-their men go by . It was a clear , frosty night , and bitterly cold , but [most of [the women]1926-the women]1928-most of the women rolled [their]1928-most of the women bare arms in [their]1928-most of the women aprons and stood talking in little knots after the procession had passed out of sight . [They]1926-the women were more hopeful than [[their]1926-the women husbands]1930-their husbands , for [women]3217-women are naturally more trusting than [men]466-men and believe more in the possibility of altering facts by emotional influences . To [Murdoch]128-murdoch and [Hatfield]134-alice , in spite of [their]1923-they assumption of indifference , the time seemed very long as it went by and brought [them]1923-they no news of [[their]1923-they comrades]1933-their comrades . After half an hour [Bill]128-murdoch suggested that [they]1923-they should stroll up [the hill]1476-the hill to meet [the others]3402-the others and learn how it fared with [them]1923-they . IF [the frequenters of [the Spotted Cow]63-spotted cow]1936-the frequenters of the spotted cow had only known , this was about the most unpropitious moment for obtaining a hearing for [their]1923-they petition . A hearing was all [they]1923-they could possibly obtain for it , but that [they]1923-they did not know either . [[Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's host]1937-litvinoff 's host had not found [him]121-litvinoff as great a comfort as [he]121-litvinoff had expected . For one thing , [the Count]3057-the count 's almost universal sympathy seemed unaccountably to stop short at [Roland Ferrier]107-roland . [The young man]2891-the young man felt that [he]2891-the young man had been terribly ill - used and naturally expected [every one else]1790-every one else to see things in the same light , and it was ' riling '[2891-the young man] to find all the sympathy of [[his]2891-the young man guest]3321-his guest turned , not towards [him]2891-the young man , but towards [[his]2891-the young man workmen]1942-his workmen , which did not seem reasonable ; for , as [Roland]107-roland said , [they]1942-his workmen could get other work , but where was [he]2891-the young man to get [another mill]1943-another mill ? Then [he]2891-the young man did not like a certain change which [he]2891-the young man noticed in the other 's tone when [he]2891-the young man spoke of [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley . [He]2891-the young man had sympathy enough for [her]122-miss stanley , goodness knows — a trifle too much [Roland]107-roland sometimes thought . For [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff to be [a bore]1944-a bore was impossible ; but still it did happen rather often that [he]121-litvinoff would bring forward political economy of the most startling pattern when [the other]305-the other wanted to talk literature , or art , or personal grievances . On this particular night [Roland]107-roland had been led , much against [his]107-roland will , into a discussion of the nature which [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff so much affected , and [he]107-roland had to admit to [himself]107-roland that , as usual , [he]107-roland had much the worst of it . ' It 's all very well , '[2891-the young man] [he]2891-the young man said ( [people]298-people always say , ' It 's all very well , '[2891-the young man] when [they]298-people can find no other answer to an argument ) ; ' it 's all very well , and that sort of thing may do for [Russia]26-russia , but [you]26-russia will never get an economic or any other revolution here — Why what the deuce is all that row ? '[2891-the young man] ' That row '[2891-the young man] was a tramping of many feet on the gravel , and a hum of voices just outside the window . [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , who was sitting nearer the window , rose and looked through the laths of the venetian blinds . ' Well , [[my]2891-the young man dear]362-my dear [Ferrier]107-roland , '[2891-the young man] [he]2891-the young man said , turning round with a smile , ' it strikes [me]2891-the young man that there is a revolution in [England]15-england , and that it has begun at [Thornsett]30-thornsett . '[107-roland] ' Oh , just division of profits ! '[121-litvinoff] murmured [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff confidentially to the clock on the mantelpiece . '[107-roland] ' [We]1961-we hoped it '[107-roland] ud blow over . What 's the use of coming up like this in the middle of the night , interfering in [my]0-i private affairs ; for [I]0-i 'd have [you]121-litvinoff know [[my]0-i brother]3376-my brother and [I]0-i have a perfect right to close [the mill]2936-the mill or keep it open as [we]1961-we choose . '[121-litvinoff] ' No more riff - raff than [yourself]121-litvinoff ! '[1964-the youngest deputy] this from [the youngest deputy]1964-the youngest deputy . ' Hold tha noise , [Jim]250-jim ! '[248-clayton] said [old Clayton]248-clayton . ' [The other lads]3969-the other lads has come up , [sir]318-sir , because [they]1965-they thought there mout be some good news , and [they]1965-they 'd like to hear ['em]3990-'em[248-clayton] as soon as mout be . ' '[318-sir] Well , well , [sir]318-sir , ' said [Clayton]248-clayton , '[318-sir] [we]1967-we did n't mean no harm . [I]0-i 'll tell ['em]318-sir what [you]318-sir say .
