'[107-roland] Good - night , [[my]0-i friends]1236-my friends ! ' [he]0-i said . '[107-roland] Keep [your]1236-my friends tempers . This unfortunate business is [no one]494-no one 's fault . It 's the fault of the system [we]1967-we all live under . ' The door closed upon [the last man]3995-the last man . [Roland]107-roland turned angrily on [[his]0-i guest]3321-his guest . '[0-i] [I]0-i ca n't imagine , ' [he]0-i said , with asperity , '[0-i] how [a man who is so sensible about most things can take the part of [these unreasonable idiots]1971-these unreasonable idiots]1970-a man who is so sensible about most things can take the part of these unreasonable idiots ! ' '[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]362-my dear [Ferrier]107-roland , ' relighting the cigar which had gone out in the excitement of the moment , '[107-roland] of course [I]0-i 've the very greatest sympathy with [you]107-roland in this painful business , and [I]0-i know how little it is [your]107-roland fault , but now , as always , [I]0-i 'm on the side of [the workers]2870-the workers , and [you]107-roland know [I]1974-the deputies never disguise [my]1974-the deputies views . '[1974-the deputies] ' So it appears , '[107-roland] [Roland]107-roland was beginning , when the murmur of voices outside gave place to a single voice — that of [one of [the deputies]1974-the deputies , who seemed to be speaking to [the men]1128-the men]1973-one of the deputies , who seemed to be speaking to the men . [Ferrier]107-roland and [[his]107-roland guest]3321-his guest could hear the shuffling of many feet on the gravel as [the men]1128-the men crowded round [the speaker]718-the speaker . When [he]107-roland stopped there was a tumult of hissing and yelling and groaning — a noise as of a very Pandemonium let loose . [Roland]107-roland turned to [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff . ' [I]107-roland hope [you]121-litvinoff 're[107-roland] proud of [[your]121-litvinoff precious protégés]1979-your precious protégés ? ' [he]107-roland said , and at the same moment a voice outside cried , — '[121-litvinoff] Let 's smash the cursed walls in ! ' [Old Clayton]248-clayton 's voice sounded thin and shrill above the uproar . '[121-litvinoff] Do n't be [fools]1980-fools , [lads]455-lads ! Come away ! Let [un]1982-un alone ! Come [home]303-home ! [We]1984-we 'll do no good here . ' [The men]1128-the men seemed to hesitate a minute , and then to obey , reluctantly moving towards the gate . '[1128-the men] [They]1128-the men have gone without doing anything very serious , [you]107-roland see , ' said [the Count]3057-the count ; but even as [he]3057-the count spoke a big stone , thrown by some strong hand , came crashing through the window , and rolled , muddy and grey , on to the edge of the soft fur hearthrug . '[1128-the men] Damn ! ' cried [Roland]107-roland furiously , '[0-i] [I]0-i 'll have [the fellow who did that]1985-the fellow who did that , anyway . ' [He]107-roland made a dash for the door , but [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff caught [him]107-roland by the shoulders , and there was a struggle , silent and brief , which ended in [Roland]107-roland 's standing still , and looking at [the other]305-the other savagely . '[1985-the fellow who did that] Stay where [you]107-roland are , for [God]110-god 's sake ! ' shouted [the Count]3057-the count ; '[1128-the men] [they]1128-the men 've only done [you]107-roland five shillings ' worth of damage now , but [they]1128-the men 'll perhaps add murder to it if [you]107-roland go outside . Do be reasonable , [Ferrier]107-roland . There , [they]1128-the men 've gone now ; and if [you]107-roland went out [you]107-roland could n't identify [the man who did it]4002-the man who did it . '[107-roland] [Roland]107-roland turned away , and flung [himself]107-roland sulkily into a chair by the fire . ' [I]107-roland suppose [you]121-litvinoff 're[107-roland] right , ' [he]0-i said ; '[107-roland] but [I]0-i shall be deuced glad to be out of the whole thing . ' It was perhaps as well for [Roland]107-roland 's self - esteem and peace of mind that [he]107-roland did not hear the strictures that were passed upon [him]107-roland by [the men]1128-the men as [they]1128-the men returned towards [the village]3667-the village . [Hope]251-hope deferred maketh the heart sick , but when [a new - born hope]4005-a new - born hope is killed , and killed cruelly and suddenly , there comes sometimes something more terrible than heart - sickness and more dangerous . The moon had flung aside the slight mist which had covered [her]4006-her face earlier in the evening , and now shone full on [the valley]4007-the valley , towards which [the crowd]392-the crowd were making [their]392-the crowd way . As [they]1128-the men turned the corner which brought [them]1128-the men in sight of [the mill whose doors none of [them]1128-the men]4009-the mill whose doors none of them were to pass again , a burst of curses and oaths broke from [the men]1128-the men and fell on the still air , violating and outraging the peace and beauty of the night . At this moment [Hatfield]134-alice and [Murdoch]128-murdoch , walking together from [the village]3667-the village to meet [them]1128-the men , came up and were promptly informed of the result of the interview . '[0-i] Ay , ay , [lads]455-lads ! ' said [old Murdoch]128-murdoch . '[455-lads] What did [Ah]1987-ah tell [ye]455-lads ? as [Ah]1987-ah thowt . ' Then looking down at [the mill]2936-the mill [he]128-murdoch pointed towards [it]2936-the mill , and went on in a loud voice , '[1987-ah] [Ye]455-lads shall best have another try now . Go down and beg o ' t '[1987-ah] door - posts o ' t '[1987-ah] owd mill to take [ye]455-lads on again . [Ye'll]455-lads be as likely to get a good hearing fro ' [them]1128-the men as [ye]455-lads were fro '[1987-ah] t ' young puppy up yonder ; and [they]1128-the men 'll not be laughing at [ye]455-lads as soon as [yer]455-lads turned , anyway . '[1987-ah] This last suggestion had the effect that [Murdoch]128-murdoch probably wished it to have . At once a dozen voices were raised for going back to [Thornsett Edge]1-thornsett edge , and not leaving a pane of glass in the window - sashes . [The man who had thrown the stone before at once]1988-the man who had thrown the stone before at once became [a small hero]1989-a small hero , and met with numerous offers of assistance in going back and completing the work [he]1988-the man who had thrown the stone before at once had begun . Not [a few of [the men]1128-the men]1990-a few of the men were excited by drink as well as by rage , having taken considerably more than was good for [them]1990-a few of the men before [they]1990-a few of the men started on the forlorn hope , and the excitement of [these men]3868-these men communicated itself by those mysterious means which only manifest themselves on these occasions to [the men who were sober]1993-the men who were sober . [Roland Ferrier]107-roland 's words , passing from mouth to mouth , had been added to and altered so much that in the prevailing state of mind [each man]3994-each man felt that [he]3994-each man personally had been insulted and outraged by [the man of whom [he]3994-each man had asked the small favour of being allowed to continue to work until the winter - tide had passed]1995-the man of whom he had asked the small favour of being allowed to continue to work until the winter - tide had passed . The idea of returning and wrecking [[the Ferriers]142-the ferriers ' house]4013-the ferriers ' house became every moment more and more popular , and [the crowd]392-the crowd had actually faced round and begun that swaying movement which in an undisciplined body always , for a moment or two , precedes a start , when [Hatfield]134-alice spoke out at the top of [his]107-roland voice , — '[3994-each man] See here , ' [he]107-roland said . '[3994-each man] In a few weeks now [we]1996-we shall all be gone to different parts , some on [us]1996-we to " [the house]291-the house . " Most like , when that 's done , when [we]1996-we 're tramping [the country]3175-the country far an '[3994-each man] wide , and seeking the work [we]1996-we 're turned out of [here]2895-here , [they]1998-they two'—pointing towards [Thornsett Edge—''ll]64-thornsett edge—''ll get tired o '[1998-they] goin' without [their]1998-they brass so long , maybe , an ' '[1998-they] ill make up the quarrel , and come back and start [the mill]2936-the mill again , with a new lot o ' hands , to live [i]2002-a voice from the rear '[2002-a voice from the rear] [[our]1996-we homes]3982-our homes and eat the bread [we]1996-we 're done out off . '[2002-a voice from the rear] This new view of the case was received with a moment 's silence by [the hands]1949-the hands ; then [a voice from the rear]2002-a voice from the rear spoke out,—'Na , [na]2003-na , [they]1998-they ' ont , not if [I]2002-a voice from the rear can stop it ; let 's break t '[2002-a voice from the rear] ow'd [mill]1955-mill to bits , and give [the new hands]2005-the new hands the job to build it up again afore [they]2005-the new hands work it . ' This suggestion , probably because its adoption was a trifle less dangerous than wrecking [a house]3431-a house , [some of whose inmates]4018-some of whose inmates were [young men]3046-young men — possibly [young men with firearms]4020-young men with firearms — was received with almost unanimous applause . In less time than it takes to tell , a hundred pieces of the rock of which the Derbyshire walls are built had begun to rattle on the roof and smash the windows of [the mill]2936-the mill below , and two or three pairs of strong arms had torn away a huge boulder of grey stone which , held in its place by creepers and earth , overhung the descent , and had set it rolling down the steep decline . [It]4022-it bounded on to the slated roof of [the mill]2936-the mill , and with a great crash went right through [it]4022-it , leaving a large black gap . Then [the men]1128-the men set up a yell that made [the country]3175-the country round ring again . When it had died away [old Murdoch]128-murdoch , who was beside [himself]128-murdoch with excitement , shouted out , '[2002-a voice from the rear] Why waste [yer]2006-yer time [i]0-i ' chuckin '[1998-they] stones at [the danged place]2007-the danged place , [lads]455-lads ? Get down t ' hill and burn it to the ground . '[2009-the proposition] Another yell of approval greeted [the proposition]2009-the proposition , and in a few seconds [the hill - top]2010-the hill - top was deserted , and [the crowd]392-the crowd , swayed by an irresistible impulse , was scrambling down [the rocky decline]2012-the rocky decline and making for [the mill]2936-the mill . The shout that had been sent up when the hole had been knocked in the roof had reached the quick ears of [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff sitting smoking in silence opposite [[his]121-litvinoff host]3411-his host . [He]121-litvinoff got out of [his]121-litvinoff chair . ' [I]121-litvinoff have a bit of a headache to - night , '[121-litvinoff] [he]121-litvinoff said , ' [I]121-litvinoff do n't think arguing agrees with [me]121-litvinoff . [I]121-litvinoff 'll just go and take a turn across [the moor]4026-the moor . '[121-litvinoff] ' All right , '[107-roland] said [Roland]107-roland . ' [I]107-roland wo n't turn in till [you]121-litvinoff come back . '[107-roland] [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff sauntered out of [the room]2910-the room and across [the hall]1285-the hall , took a stout oak stick from [the hall - stand]2017-the hall - stand , and , opening the front - door , strolled leisurely down [the carriage drive]2018-the carriage drive . But directly [he]121-litvinoff was out in [the road]3300-the road [he]121-litvinoff pulled [his]121-litvinoff hat down tightly upon [his]121-litvinoff ears , vaulted a low stone wall and set off running in the direction of [the mill]2936-the mill as though a thousand devils were following at [his]121-litvinoff heels . FIRE ! TO run at full speed across [a Derbyshire moor]2021-a derbyshire moor by the uncertain light of a wintry moon is a feat not unattended with difficulty and danger , especially when [the runner]2022-the runner is not quite accustomed to the course ; but it would have taken greater pitfalls than [even those moors present]2023-even those moors present to have made [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff choose a longer and easier way . For when that shout had been borne to [him]121-litvinoff on the wind [he]121-litvinoff scented excitement and danger , and excitement and danger were to [him]121-litvinoff as the breath of life . [He]121-litvinoff was almost certain that [the men]1128-the men meant mischief , and [he]121-litvinoff intended to do [his]121-litvinoff best to prevent it . [His]121-litvinoff sympathies really were , as [he]121-litvinoff had told [Roland]107-roland , entirely with [them]1128-the men , and [he]121-litvinoff was genuinely anxious that [they]1128-the men should not add a criminal prosecution for riot to [their]1128-the men other troubles . At the same time [he]121-litvinoff looked forward with some pleasure to the scene in which [he]121-litvinoff was now hastening to take a part . [He]121-litvinoff had been in a fretful and irritable state of mind ever since [he]121-litvinoff had left [London]6-london , and [he]121-litvinoff cordially welcomed a row , and did not care much if in that row [he]121-litvinoff got a knock on the head that would put an end to [his]121-litvinoff visit and [his]121-litvinoff life at the same time . At any rate , the situation offered a chance of action , and it was action more than anything that [he]121-litvinoff had been longing for lately . As [he]121-litvinoff got nearer [the valley in which [the mill lay]2026-the mill lay]2025-the valley in which the mill lay [he]121-litvinoff was able to form a better idea of what was toward , for the shouts seemed to get louder and louder . [He]121-litvinoff quickened [his]121-litvinoff pace at the moment when [he]121-litvinoff reached [the brow of [the hill]1476-the hill]2027-the brow of the hill , from the foot of which all the noise and clamour arose , and paused , looking down ; a lurid flash of flame lighted up for an instant the semi - darkness before [him]121-litvinoff , and as suddenly died out again . ' Diable ! '[121-litvinoff] [he]121-litvinoff said . ' [I]121-litvinoff shall be too late for anything . [I]121-litvinoff have some power over [men]466-men , but [I]121-litvinoff am not a fire - engine — '[121-litvinoff] [He]121-litvinoff made the descent rather more cautiously , though not much less rapidly , than [he]121-litvinoff had done the rest of the journey , and pushed [his]121-litvinoff way through [the little wood]2029-the little wood to within a hundred yards or so of [the mill]2936-the mill . Then [he]121-litvinoff stopped , peering forward to ascertain the exact state of things before [he]121-litvinoff went on . [The mill]2936-the mill was not one of those square , many - windowed blocks which remind one of [[children]1446-children 's toy - houses]2033-children 's toy - houses , but [a group of irregular buildings of all sorts and sizes , built of grey stone and roofed with slate]2034-a group of irregular buildings of all sorts and sizes , built of grey stone and roofed with slate . There was [a paved yard]2035-a paved yard surrounded by [outhouses]724-outhouses , [some mere sheds of wood and thatch]2037-some mere sheds of wood and thatch , and it was round [the outhouse nearest to [the mill itself]2039-the mill itself]2038-the outhouse nearest to the mill itself that [the men]1128-the men were crowding . There was plenty of light now for [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff to discern every detail of the scene before [him]121-litvinoff , for [two sheds]2041-two sheds were on fire and burning merrily in the frosty air . The door of [a certain room where [he]121-litvinoff remembered to have seen quantities of cotton waste and inflammable rubbish , and which opened directly on to [the yard]1585-the yard]2042-a certain room where he remembered to have seen quantities of cotton waste and inflammable rubbish , and which opened directly on to the yard , had been battered in by [the men]1128-the men , and , the hinges having given way , hung crookedly by its strained , bent , but still strong , lock . [Some of [the men]1128-the men]2045-some of the men were hurrying to and fro between [this room]1202-this room and [the outbuilding]2048-the outbuilding , carrying armfuls of wood and straw , and [these men]3868-these men were for the most part silent . The shouting , of which there was a good deal , was done by [those who were doing nothing else]2050-those who were doing nothing else . [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff had not been [the only one to hear that first yell]2051-the only one to hear that first yell , and to interpret it as the note of something unusual , for dark heads were moving along [the brow of [the hill on the other side]2053-the hill on the other side]2052-the brow of the hill on the other side , and [dark figures]2054-dark figures were hurrying down the stone steps . The situation was obvious , and it was obvious too that no time was to be lost , for [the crowd]392-the crowd was becoming wilder and wilder , drunk with the strong wine of excitement as well as with the more habitual beer . Rioting , like everything else , grows by what it feeds on , and the higher the flames went the higher rose the cries that accompanied [them]2056-them . There is always something exciting about a fire — in the breaking loose of the tremendous force which [we]2057-we keep mostly as [[our]2057-we servant]2058-our servant . The fire was still small enough to be quenched if [its originators]2059-its originators so chose , but [they]2059-its originators saw well enough that soon it would be beyond [their]2059-its originators control , and would be [[their]2059-its originators master]2060-their master in the place where it had been [[their]2059-its originators slave]2061-their slave . And [they]2059-its originators , too , had broken from [their]2059-its originators old place to - night . [They]2059-its originators were no longer [the humble dependants of [a rich man]3842-a rich man]2062-the humble dependants of a rich man . [Their]2059-its originators hand was against [him]3842-a rich man , and against all [his]3842-a rich man class , and the new sense of independent , self - chosen action was intoxicating [them]2059-its originators all , and had driven far from [them]2059-its originators all thought of forbearance or of fear . For there was danger to [the men]1128-the men [themselves]1128-the men in this hell [they]1128-the men were making . [The out - buildings]2065-the out - buildings and [the mill]2936-the mill formed a square , and , once kindled , all would burn rapidly ; and , from the slight eminence where [he]3842-a rich man stood , [the onlooker , cool and free from the madness that surged in the brain of the actors]2067-the onlooker , cool and free from the madness that surged in the brain of the actors , could see plainly that [the incendiaries]2068-the incendiaries ran a very fair chance of being caught in [their]2068-the incendiaries own trap , and of perishing like rats in [a barn]2069-a barn . The big iron gates were closed immovably , and the only exit was by a narrow door . If once a panic began , and [the men]1128-the men lost [their]1128-the men heads in trying to pass this door , there might be a tragedy more terrible than [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff cared to contemplate . [He]121-litvinoff knew that if once the fire began in [the mill]2936-the mill [itself]2936-the mill there would be no chance of saving it , or anything else , and [he]121-litvinoff could see that [the men]1128-the men were beginning to drag burning fragments from [the out - buildings]2065-the out - buildings , and [he]121-litvinoff knew that [they]1128-the men would be dragged to [that room]2074-that room with the broken - in door . [He]121-litvinoff paused no longer . That door was the point d'appui of the defence , and for that door [he]121-litvinoff made . [He]121-litvinoff came rapidly down [the hill]1476-the hill and along the path that led to the little gate by which alone entrance to [the yard]1585-the yard could be effected . In the confusion of [hurrying figures]2077-hurrying figures [no one]494-no one noticed the one figure more which , in a few strides , crossed [the yard]1585-the yard and planted itself just inside that broken door . [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff glanced behind [him]121-litvinoff and by the lurid glare of the burning timber opposite [he]121-litvinoff could see the pile of straw and faggots in [the room]2910-the room ready for the horrible bonfire . Just inside the lintel of the door something lay on the floor , gleaming redly in the firelight . [He]121-litvinoff picked it up ; it was a light , bright , long - handled steel hatchet . ' Aha , '[121-litvinoff] [he]121-litvinoff said ; ' this is a gift from [the gods]423-the gods ! '[121-litvinoff] As [he]121-litvinoff faced [the yard]1585-the yard , a great noise of mingled cheers and shouts went up from [the crowd]392-the crowd . It was not because [they]1128-the men had seen [[their]1128-the men solitary opponent]2083-their solitary opponent , but because the attack on what [they]1128-the men thought [the undefended mill]2084-the undefended mill was about to begin in earnest . [All the active members of the riot]2085-all the active members of the riot were making for the door , headed by [half - a - dozen stalwart fellows dragging blazing timbers]2086-half - a - dozen stalwart fellows dragging blazing timbers . ' Stop ! '[121-litvinoff] shouted [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , in a voice that rang above the confused shouting of [the crowd like a trumpet call]2087-the crowd like a trumpet call . And stop [they]1128-the men did — and for quite twenty seconds held [their]1128-the men tongues , to boot . Then arose a storm of indignation and derision when [they]1128-the men saw that [only one man stood in the way]2088-only one man stood in the way . [They]1128-the men could not see who [he]2088-only one man stood in the way was , and [they]1128-the men cared little . [The leaders]2089-the leaders made a forward movement , when — ' Stop ! '[121-litvinoff] [he]121-litvinoff cried again , and [his]121-litvinoff tones rose clear above the yells of [the rioters]2090-the rioters , and were heard by [timorous listeners on [the hillside]2092-the hillside]2091-timorous listeners on the hillside . ' Stop , and clear out of this as quick as [you]2088-only one man stood in the way can get ! Get to [[your]2088-only one man stood in the way homes]4029-your homes , [[you]2088-only one man stood in the way fools]4030-you fools ! '[121-litvinoff] ' Clear out [yourself]2088-only one man stood in the way , '[2093-a ringleader] said [a ringleader]2093-a ringleader , ' or [we]2089-the leaders 'll clear [you]2088-only one man stood in the way out ! '[2093-a ringleader] But the forward movement had stopped . [A parley]2094-a parley had begun , and [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff always felt that a chance of speaking meant for [him]121-litvinoff a chance of winning . ' Put out that fire , and get back to [[your]2088-only one man stood in the way homes]4029-your homes ! '[121-litvinoff] [he]121-litvinoff cried . ' [I]121-litvinoff 've come down here to save [you]2088-only one man stood in the way from penal servitude , and [I]121-litvinoff mean to do it . Not [a man of [you]2088-only one man stood in the way]4032-a man of you gets inside this door ! '[121-litvinoff] By this time all [the crowd]392-the crowd had come up , and formed a semicircle in front of [him]121-litvinoff , about fifteen yards off . [They]392-the crowd could see [his]121-litvinoff face better than [he]121-litvinoff could see [theirs]392-the crowd , for the light of the flames behind [them]392-the crowd fell full upon [him]121-litvinoff . [He]121-litvinoff was deadly pale , but [he]121-litvinoff looked deadly determined too . There was a dangerous gleam in [his]121-litvinoff eyes , and a gleam still more dangerous from the bright blade of the axe which [he]121-litvinoff had swung up on to [his]121-litvinoff shoulder . Standing on the raised step of the door [he]121-litvinoff looked tall and strong and bold . Already the effect of this lion in the path made itself felt , for a faint cheer went up from the outside edge of [the crowd]392-the crowd , and a voice cried , — ' [He]121-litvinoff 's right . Let un be , [lads]455-lads — let un be , and go [yer]455-lads ways [home]303-home . '[392-the crowd] ' All those of [you]455-lads who 've got any sense left turn round and put out that fire . The work [you]455-lads 've done to - night already is worth ten years in prison . '[392-the crowd] ' Then let 's finish [our]4035-our work , [lads]455-lads , and earn [our]4035-our wages ! Ten years '[392-the crowd] good feedin 's better nor a month 's clemmin ' , '[2097-a burly young fellow of some six feet] shouted [a burly young fellow of some six feet]2097-a burly young fellow of some six feet . ' Well said , [Isaac Potts]252-isaac ! '[2098-more than one] cried [more than one]2098-more than one . ' Dang [his]252-isaac cheek ! Heave [him]252-isaac out of it ! '[2099-some half - dozen] And [some half - dozen]2099-some half - dozen rushed forward to suit the action to the word , foremost among [them]2099-some half - dozen [Isaac Potts]252-isaac . In the position [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff had taken up , it was impossible for [more than one man]2100-more than one man to attack [him]121-litvinoff at a time . As [the young mill hand]2101-the young mill hand , armed with a piece of wood still smouldering redly , sprang to lead the attack , [a woman]554-a woman 's voice — [[his]121-litvinoff sweetheart's]2103-his sweetheart's — sounded shrilly from behind [the crowd]392-the crowd , — ' Keep back , [Isaac]252-isaac — keep back ; [he]121-litvinoff 'll brain [thee]252-isaac for sure ! '[554-a woman] The warning was unheeded , or , if [the young man]2891-the young man heard it , it only urged [him]2891-the young man on . [He]2891-the young man stopped an instant , hurled the wood at [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's head , and sprang forward to follow up [his]2891-the young man missile . The aim was not a good one . The brand only hit the door lintel , struck out a shower of sparks , and fell across the step . It was an unlucky miss for [Isaac]252-isaac . [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff planted one foot firmly , and gave [his]121-litvinoff axe a swing . It came down crashing through collar - bone and shoulder blade , and almost severing the arm from the body . [Isaac]252-isaac staggered back upon [the men behind [him]252-isaac]2106-the men behind him , covering [them]2106-the men behind him with blood as [he]252-isaac fell . There was a silence of a moment , which seemed long . [The crowd]392-the crowd drew a deep breath . All the devil in [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's nature was roused now . ' Come on , [[you]2106-the men behind him madmen]4037-you madmen ! '[121-litvinoff] [he]121-litvinoff cried , as [he]121-litvinoff recovered [himself]121-litvinoff and brought [his]121-litvinoff axe to the shoulder again . ' Come on ! Get into [this room]1202-this room now if [you]2106-the men behind him can ! '[121-litvinoff] But the general ambition to get into [that room]2074-that room was a little damped somehow , and [the few who had been close on [Isaac]252-isaac 's heels]2109-the few who had been close on isaac 's heels fell back , and left [him]252-isaac alone , [all but one man , who stood glaring into [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's eyes]2110-all but one man , who stood glaring into litvinoff 's eyes . [He]121-litvinoff held a heavy iron bar in [his]121-litvinoff hand . ' Back [you]121-litvinoff go , or down [you]121-litvinoff go ! '[121-litvinoff] shouted [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , making a step towards [him]121-litvinoff , and giving the axe a swing in the air . [The man]3262-the man did not wait for the blow . [He]3262-the man retreated , and joined [the crowd]392-the crowd just as [the girl who had shrieked that warning]2113-the girl who had shrieked that warning tore [her]2113-the girl who had shrieked that warning way through to the place where [[her]2113-the girl who had shrieked that warning lover]3539-her lover was lying , and bent over [him]3539-her lover . [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff brought [his]121-litvinoff weapon to [his]121-litvinoff side . Then [he]121-litvinoff said quietly , — ' [I]121-litvinoff told [you]121-litvinoff none of [you]121-litvinoff should get into [this room]1202-this room , and none of [you]121-litvinoff shall , by [God]110-god ! if [I]121-litvinoff have to treat twenty of [you]121-litvinoff to the same fare as [this poor fellow]4040-this poor fellow . If [you]121-litvinoff 're[121-litvinoff] [sane men]2115-sane men , pick [him]3539-her lover up and see to [him]3539-her lover , and perhaps nothing worse may come to [you]2115-sane men after all . Remember that [every man who does not help to put that fire]2116-every man who does not help to put that fire out breaks the law . For [Heaven]242-heaven 's sake be [reasonable men]2117-reasonable men . There are [some here who know [me]0-i]2118-some here who know me . Do [you]2115-sane men think [I]0-i care for [this cursed mill]2119-this cursed mill ? [I]0-i came down here to save [you]2115-sane men . Help [me]0-i to do it . ' [The moderate party]4041-the moderate party was a good deal stronger by this time ; the axe had been a first - rate argument . '[318-sir] Well done , [sir]318-sir ! ' '[318-sir] Quite right , [sir]318-sir ! ' '[318-sir] Hear , hear ! ' went up from [the crowd]392-the crowd , and [two or three men]4043-two or three men came forward . [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff resumed [his]121-litvinoff defensive attitude , but [they]4043-two or three men were not for attack . [They]4043-two or three men busied [themselves]4043-two or three men with [[their]4043-two or three men wounded friend]4044-their wounded friend . '[318-sir] Is [John Hatfield]135-john hatfield [there]2994-there ? ' called [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , seeing that [he]0-i had prevailed . '[135-john hatfield] [I]0-i want [him]135-john hatfield . [Hatfield]135-john hatfield , ca n't [you]135-john hatfield manage to get a dozen of [[your]135-john hatfield friends]3352-your friends to put out that fire ? The best thing [you]135-john hatfield can do is to knock down the sheds on each side , and then it will burn itself out and do no harm . ' '[2124-we] [We]2124-we will , [sir]318-sir , ' [Hatfield]135-john hatfield answered . '[318-sir] [You]318-sir 're right ; this has been a mad night 's work . '[318-sir] All danger of further riot was at an end . [The men who had been foremost in the work of destruction]2126-the men who had been foremost in the work of destruction had made off as quickly as possible , and [those who were left]2127-those who were left worked zealously under [Hatfield]135-john hatfield 's orders . [The wounded man]2128-the wounded man was carried off on a shutter to [the nearest cottage]2129-the nearest cottage . The fire was effectually put out with water from [the reservoir]2130-the reservoir . [The men]1128-the men loafed off in twos and threes , and darkness and quiet settled down once more on [Thornsett]126-thornsett . [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff and [Hatfield]135-john hatfield remained till [the last lingerer]2132-the last lingerer had left . Then [Hatfield]135-john hatfield said , — ' [Ah]4045-ah suppose this means the '[135-john hatfield] sizes for [a goodish few o ' [us]2124-we]4046-a goodish few o ' us . '[135-john hatfield] ' [I]121-litvinoff hope not , '[121-litvinoff] [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff answered ; ' [I]121-litvinoff 'll do [my]121-litvinoff best for [you]318-sir — that is , [I]121-litvinoff shall not know who was here to - night . But [I]121-litvinoff advise [you]318-sir to clear out as early as [you]318-sir can to - morrow , and , if [[your]318-sir friends who were in this business]4047-your friends who were in this business are wise , [they]4047-your friends who were in this business 'll do the same . '[121-litvinoff] [They]2133-they turned [their]2133-they back on [the mill]2936-the mill , and climbed [the hill]1476-the hill to [the cottage]2136-the cottage , where [the doctor who had been sent for]2137-the doctor who had been sent for was already busy with [[his]2137-the doctor who had been sent for patient]2138-his patient . BEFORE daybreak next morning [John Hatfield]135-john hatfield had taken [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's advice , and [he]135-john hatfield and [several others who had borne an active part in the night]2147-several others who had borne an active part in the night 's work had shaken the dust of [Thornsett]30-thornsett off [their]2146-their feet and taken [their]2146-their departure in various directions . Had [they]2146-their not been quite so precipitate [their]2146-their leave - taking might have been more dignified and less secret , for [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's confidence in [his]121-litvinoff own powers of diplomacy had been more than justified . When , somewhat to [his]3057-the count chagrin , [his]3057-the count eloquence failed to reconcile [Roland Ferrier]107-roland to the idea of taking no legal steps to punish [the intending incendiaries]2148-the intending incendiaries — for , in spite of the way in which [the Count]3057-the count had watered the story down , [Roland]107-roland had managed to get a pretty accurate idea of the truth — [he]107-roland made a hasty journey over to [Aspinshaw]105-aspinshaw . [He]107-roland found [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley in a state of great excitement about the events of the night before , of which [she]122-miss stanley had heard [a very much embroidered and highly - coloured version]2150-a very much embroidered and highly - coloured version . '[122-miss stanley] ' Saved so many lives last night ! '[121-litvinoff] repeated [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff . ' [They]4064-they must have been the lives of rats and mice , then . '[107-roland] And [he]107-roland gave [her]122-miss stanley a plain and unvarnished account of the whole story , from the interview of the deputation with [Roland]107-roland to [his]107-roland own visit to [the man [he]107-roland had cut down]2151-the man he had cut down . [He]107-roland had the very rare faculty of telling the exact truth in a particularly exciting way — any adventure in which [he]107-roland had been personally engaged [he]107-roland always told from some point of view not [his]107-roland own — so that [the hearer]2152-the hearer saw [him]107-roland playing [his]107-roland part in the scene rather than heard [the chief adventurer]2153-the chief adventurer recounting [his]107-roland adventures . As [he]107-roland skilfully put before [her]122-miss stanley the picture of [the one man]2154-the one man facing [the infuriated crowd]2155-the infuriated crowd , [he]107-roland could see [her]122-miss stanley eyes sparkle with sympathy , and could read interest and admiration in [her]122-miss stanley face . ' And so [you]107-roland were not hurt , after all ? '[122-miss stanley] [she]122-miss stanley said . ' [I]122-miss stanley am so glad . But what of [the men]1128-the men ? ' '[122-miss stanley] Ah ! ' [he]107-roland answered , meeting [her]122-miss stanley questioning glance with an earnest expression on [his]107-roland serious face . ' '[135-john hatfield] Oh , but [Hatfield]135-john hatfield — surely [he]135-john hatfield 'd not punish [him]135-john hatfield ? '[121-litvinoff] Two hours later [Clare Stanley]139-clare called at [Thornsett Edge]1-thornsett edge , and , after a brief conversation with [Roland]107-roland , passed on to [the village]3667-the village , having done the work [she]139-clare had set [herself]139-clare to do . But [she]139-clare had performed it successfully , and so it came about that [none of [the men]1128-the men]2165-none of the men were punished , and [that poor [Isaac]252-isaac , who was [a pensioner on [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley for a good many months]2168-a pensioner on miss stanley for a good many months]2167-that poor isaac , who was a pensioner on miss stanley for a good many months , was [the only one to suffer from that wild night 's work]2169-the only one to suffer from that wild night 's work . [Clare]139-clare felt a sense of elation when the disagreeable task was over . So [Mrs Stanley]216-mrs stanley went to [Yorkshire]67-yorkshire , and [Clare]139-clare to [London]6-london , and [Aspinshaw]105-aspinshaw was left desolate . [Thornsett Edge]126-thornsett was advertised as ' To let , '[126-thornsett] and [Roland]107-roland and [[his]107-roland aunt]2888-his aunt took up quiet housekeeping in [Chelsea]61-chelsea . [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , by way of practising the economy which was growing more and more necessary every day , took [rooms in [Maida Vale]68-maida vale]2177-rooms in maida vale . The mill hands dispersed far and wide , and [the mill]2936-the mill , [the heart of [Thornsett]30-thornsett]2179-the heart of thornsett , having ceased to beat , [the whole place]2180-the whole place seemed to be dead , and , presently , to decay . [No one]494-no one would live in [the village]3667-the village . [It]3667-the village was too far from any other work , and [the place]936-the place took upon itself a haunted , ghostly air — as if [forms in white]2184-forms in white might be expected to walk [[its]936-the place deserted streets]2185-its deserted streets at midnight , or to show [themselves]2184-forms in white through the broken , cobwebby panes of the windows which used to be so trim and bright and clean . It was a ghastly change for [the houses that , poor as [they]2186-the houses that , poor as they were were]2186-the houses that , poor as they were , had been , after all , [homes]2187-homes to [so many people]2188-so many people for so many years . When [Alice Hatfield]134-alice thought of [[her]134-alice old home]2189-her old home , [she]134-alice never thought of [it]2189-her old home but as [she]134-alice had last seen [it]2189-her old home — neat and cheerful with the plants in pots on the long window - ledge , and all the familiar furniture and household effects in [their]2186-the houses that , poor as they were old places . It was pain to think of [it]2189-her old home even like that . It would have been agony to [her]134-alice could [she]134-alice have seen [it]2189-her old home naked and bare , with [[its]2189-her old home well - known rooms]2190-its well - known rooms cold and empty , [its]2189-her old home hearths grey and fireless . And [she]134-alice thought of [[her]134-alice home]2191-her home a good deal during the weeks when [she]134-alice lay ill in [[Mrs Toomey]191-mrs toomey 's upper room]2192-mrs toomey 's upper room ; for the illness that had come upon [her]134-alice on that Sunday when [Mr Toomey]177-toomey had had tea with [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch had been a longer and more serious affair than [any one]3772-any one had fancied it would be . When [she]134-alice had first known that another life was bound up in [her]134-alice own , the knowledge had been almost maddening ; now , the terror , the misery , and the fatigue which [she]134-alice had undergone when first [she]134-alice knew it , had themselves put an end to what had caused [them]2194-them , and [Alice]134-alice was free from the fear of the responsibility which had seemed so terrible to [her]134-alice . But [she]134-alice was not glad . [She]134-alice was amazed at the contradiction in [her]134-alice own heart , but as [she]134-alice lay thinking of all the past — of what [she]134-alice thought was [her]134-alice own wrong - doing , and of [the home [she]134-alice had left]2195-the home she had left — it seemed to [her]134-alice that what was lost to [her]134-alice was the only thing that could have reconciled [her]134-alice to [her]134-alice life , with all its bitter memories . If only [[Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's child]2196-litvinoff 's child had lain on [her]134-alice arm — if [she]134-alice could have lived in the hope of seeing it smile into [her]134-alice eyes — it seemed to [her]134-alice that [she]134-alice would not have wanted to die so much . And with this inexplicable weakness [Mrs Toomey]191-mrs toomey , strange to say , seemed to sympathise . ' There 's no understanding [women]3217-women , '[191-mrs toomey] as [Toomey]191-mrs toomey was wo nt to remark . All the expenses of [Alice]134-alice 's illness were borne by [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , who bade [Mrs Toomey]191-mrs toomey spare no expense in making ' [Mrs Litvinoff]180-litvinoff '[179-petrovitch] as comfortable as might be . When at last [Alice]134-alice began to grow better [he]179-petrovitch came to see [her]134-alice very often , brought [her]134-alice books and flowers , and was as tenderly thoughtful of [her]134-alice , as anxious to gratify [her]134-alice every possible wish , as [a brother]3180-a brother could have been . ' [You]179-petrovitch are too good to [me]134-alice , '[134-alice] [she]134-alice said one day , looking at [him]179-petrovitch with wet eyes as [he]179-petrovitch stood by [her]134-alice sofa and put into [her]134-alice hand some delicate snowdrops . ' [I]134-alice do not deserve to have [people]298-people so kind to [me]134-alice . Why is it ? '[134-alice] ' [I]179-petrovitch told [you]134-alice , '[179-petrovitch] [he]179-petrovitch answered gravely . ' [I]179-petrovitch was once [[your]134-alice husband 's dearest friend]4080-your husband 's dearest friend , and [I]179-petrovitch have a right to do all for [you]134-alice that [I]179-petrovitch can . How did [you]134-alice like the book [I]179-petrovitch sent [you]134-alice ? '[179-petrovitch] [Alice]134-alice used to look forward to [his]179-petrovitch coming . [He]179-petrovitch always cheered [her]134-alice . [He]179-petrovitch never spoke of [her]134-alice or of [himself]179-petrovitch , but always of some matter impersonal and interesting . The books [he]179-petrovitch lent [her]134-alice were the books that lead to talking ; and as [she]134-alice grew stronger in body [her]134-alice mind strengthened too , and for the first time [she]134-alice tasted the delight of following and understanding the larger questions of life . [Every one]1840-every one , even [[her]134-alice lover]3539-her lover , had always treated [her]134-alice somewhat as [a child]484-a child , and [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch was [the first person who ever seemed to think it worth while to explain things to [her]134-alice]2201-the first person who ever seemed to think it worth while to explain things to her . [She]134-alice had not had the education which makes clear thinking easy ; but [she]134-alice was young , and had still [youth]2202-youth 's faculty for learning quickly . [Her]134-alice growing interest in outside matters tended — as [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch had meant it to do — to divert [her]134-alice mind from [her]134-alice own troubles ; and when at last [she]134-alice was able to take up the easier and lighter work [he]179-petrovitch had found for [her]134-alice , [she]134-alice was able to look at life ' With larger , other eyes . '[253-clare] [MDEAR Clare]253-clare , let [me]0-i implore [you]253-clare to shut that book . [You]253-clare are becoming quite too dreadfully blue . [I]0-i do n't believe [you]253-clare take any interest in any of the things [you]253-clare used to like — even [me]0-i , ' ended [Cora Quaid]236-cora , with a pout . [The two girls]4081-the two girls were sitting very snugly in [[Miss Quaid]254-miss quaid 's special sanctum]4082-miss quaid 's special sanctum , where were enshrined [her]254-miss quaid girlish treasures , [her]254-miss quaid books , and the accessories of the art in which [she]254-miss quaid hoped some day to rival [Rosa Bonheur]255-rosa bonheur . Having had a picture admitted to [the Academy]4083-the academy the season before , [she]254-miss quaid was more hopeful and consequently more industrious than ever . But on this afternoon [she]254-miss quaid had not been painting . [She]254-miss quaid had been sitting looking at [[her]254-miss quaid friend]4084-her friend and thinking what a pretty picture [she]254-miss quaid made with [her]254-miss quaid sweet serious face and sombre crape draperies ; but even the contemplation of [one 's prettiest friend]4085-one 's prettiest friend will become fatiguing at last , when talking is one 's very greatest pleasure . So [Cora]236-cora broke silence with the remark [we]4086-we have reported , and the silence [she]236-cora broke had been a very long one . '[0-i] [[You]2203-you silly child]2204-you silly child , ' [Clare]253-clare answered , laughing , and tossing [her]253-clare book on to the sofa , '[0-i] it is n't that at all . It is that [I]0-i take an interest in all sorts of other things besides . ' '[115-mamma] [Mamma]115-mamma says , ' remarked [Miss Quaid]254-miss quaid , picking up the little red - covered pamphlet and looking at it with disfavour , '[115-mamma] that this book is not fit for [any one]3772-any one to read . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i 'm sorry [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid does n't like it , '[253-clare] [Clare]253-clare answered , ' because [I]253-clare like it so much . But perhaps [I]253-clare have n't studied it enough . [I]253-clare suppose [[your]253-clare mamma]4087-your mamma has gone into it thoroughly . '[253-clare] ' Oh no , [she]4087-your mamma would n't read it for [the world]2867-the world . '[253-clare] [Clare]253-clare felt [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid 's criticism to be less crushing than it might have been . ' At eight o'clock that evening [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch stood in [the softly - lighted hall of [Marlborough Villa]69-marlborough villa]4123-the softly - lighted hall of marlborough villa . [He]179-petrovitch felt more interested in the coming evening than [he]179-petrovitch generally was on such occasions . [Hirsch]222-hirsch , who was with [him]179-petrovitch , was very much surprised to find [himself]222-hirsch within the portals of [one of [those middle - class establishments against which [he]222-hirsch had always inveighed so bitterly]4125-those middle - class establishments against which he had always inveighed so bitterly]4124-one of those middle - class establishments against which he had always inveighed so bitterly . But [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid 's manner had overborne [his]179-petrovitch determinations with its resistless flow of gush , and [he]179-petrovitch had accepted [her]201-mrs quaid invitation from sheer inability to edge in a word of refusal . [He]179-petrovitch had been in a state of mingled remorse and terror ever since , and only [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch 's strong representations to the effect that [men who set [themselves]4126-men who set themselves against society against Society]4126-men who set themselves against society should at least not fall below Society in the matter of keeping [their]4126-men who set themselves against society word , had induced [him]179-petrovitch to face the dreadful ordeal of meeting [half - a - dozen well - dressed Social Reformers]4127-half - a - dozen well - dressed social reformers in [a large and luxurious drawing - room]4128-a large and luxurious drawing - room . It would be impossible for [any human being]4129-any human being to be quite as glad to see [any other human being]4130-any other human being as [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid appeared to be to see [[her]201-mrs quaid two new friends]4131-her two new friends . [They]4131-her two new friends came in together , and while [Hirsch]222-hirsch looked round on the handsome furniture with a savagely appraising glance , prompted equally by [his]179-petrovitch Jewish blood and [his]179-petrovitch Socialistic convictions , [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , having seen that [Clare]139-clare was present , delivered [himself]179-petrovitch an unresisting prey to [[his]179-petrovitch hostess]1397-his hostess , knowing that to even [her]1397-his hostess eloquence an end must come , and knowing , too , that sooner or later [he]179-petrovitch would find [himself]179-petrovitch beside [the girl whom [his]179-petrovitch paper on [Socialism]206-socialism had seemed to impress so much , the first time [he]179-petrovitch had ever been in [that room]2074-that room]4133-the girl whom his paper on socialism had seemed to impress so much , the first time he had ever been in that room . [He]179-petrovitch had been in [that room]2074-that room more than once since but never without seeing a very vivid vision of the fair face , shining eyes , and red lips , slightly parted in the interest of listening , [the girlish figure]4136-the girlish figure bent forward the better to catch every word of [his]179-petrovitch . It was not only the flattery of [her]1397-his hostess undisguised interest in [him]179-petrovitch which had painted for [him]179-petrovitch this memory - picture , and had given [him]179-petrovitch a constantly - recurring desire to see the original again . [He]179-petrovitch was pretty well skilled by this time in reading the faces of [his]179-petrovitch fellow - creatures , and when all the thanks and congratulations of [[the Cleon]202-the cleon 's visitors]4137-the cleon 's visitors were ringing in [his]179-petrovitch ears , [he]179-petrovitch had known perfectly well that the only heart [he]179-petrovitch had touched , the only mind that had followed [his]179-petrovitch reasoning , and the only soul that understood [him]179-petrovitch , were those of [the dark - eyed girl at [his]179-petrovitch side]4138-the dark - eyed girl at his side . And the look those dark eyes had given [him]179-petrovitch when [he]179-petrovitch said good - night , had haunted [him]179-petrovitch ever since . From the seat of honour on the sofa beside [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid , [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch looked , perhaps rather longingly , towards the other end of [the room]2910-the room , where [Hirsch]222-hirsch and [Vernon]221-vernon were talking to [the two girls]4081-the two girls . It was unworthy weakness , perhaps , in [a Friend of Humanity]4141-a friend of humanity , but [he]179-petrovitch could not help straining [his]179-petrovitch ears to try to catch what [they]4081-the two girls were saying , and wondering what subject [they]4081-the two girls could be discussing to bring such interest into [Clare]139-clare 's face . This effort interfered somewhat with the lucidity of [his]179-petrovitch replies , until [Mr Quaid , who had hardly spoken before]233-mr quaid , brought [him]179-petrovitch up short with the question , — '[0-i] What do [you]2246-you mean , now , by Socialism ? ' and [the Socialist , with an imperceptible shrug of the shoulders]4142-the socialist , with an imperceptible shrug of the shoulders and a sort of '[2246-you] in for a penny in for a pound ' feeling , gave up trying to do two things at once , and plunged heart and soul into explanations , knowing quite well neither of [[his]179-petrovitch hearers]705-his hearers would understand them . If there is any truth in the old adage [his]179-petrovitch ears should have burned , for [the group at the end of the room]4144-the group at the end of the room were discussing nothing less than [himself]179-petrovitch . An enthusiastic remark from [Vernon]221-vernon and sympathetic rejoinders from [Clare]139-clare and [Cora]236-cora had sufficed to mitigate in the Austrian that sense of being trapped by the enemy with which [he]179-petrovitch had entered [the room]2910-the room , for [he]179-petrovitch saw that [these young people]4146-these young people had , at anyrate , one thing in common with [him]179-petrovitch — a great respect for and interest in [[his]179-petrovitch Russian friend]4147-his russian friend . And knowing this , [his]179-petrovitch tongue was loosed ; and [his]179-petrovitch love of [[his]179-petrovitch friend]4148-his friend overcoming in some degree the difficulties presented to [him]179-petrovitch by the English language , [he]179-petrovitch began to tell tale after tale of [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch 's kindness , bravery , self - sacrifice , and nobility . [His]179-petrovitch knowledge of English had improved in the last four months , and [[his]179-petrovitch hearers]705-his hearers found it easy to understand [him]179-petrovitch . '[0-i] [I]0-i have only known [him]2247-him half a year , ' [he]179-petrovitch said at last ; '[2247-him] and in that time [I]0-i know of [him]2247-him more good than of [any other man in half a lifetime]2248-any other man in half a lifetime . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i 've known [him]2247-him less time than that , ' chimed in [young Vernon]221-vernon ; '[2247-him] and even [I]0-i can see that [he]2247-him 's different to [any one else]3887-any one else . [The only person [I]0-i ever knew who was in the least like [him]2247-him]2250-the only person i ever knew who was in the least like him is [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff . ' '[121-litvinoff] Thereby [I]0-i see [you]0-i know not well either [the one]2251-the one or [the other]305-the other , ' said [Hirsch]222-hirsch , with some return to [his]222-hirsch normal grumpiness . '[0-i] [I]0-i do n't agree with [Mr Vernon]221-vernon , ' put in [Clare]139-clare ; '[0-i] the principles of [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff and [Mr Petrovitch]179-petrovitch may be the same , but it seems to [me]0-i that [the two men]3340-the two men are utterly different . ' '[121-litvinoff] Yes , ' said [Miss Quaid]254-miss quaid . '[121-litvinoff] [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff has much more of the dash and " go " that [one]504-one expects in [a revolutionist]3689-a revolutionist . [Mr Petrovitch]179-petrovitch is very solid , [I]0-i should think ; but [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff is certainly more brilliant and sparkling . ' [Hirsch]222-hirsch smiled sardonically . '[121-litvinoff] [Mademoiselle]261-mademoiselle is happy in [her]261-mademoiselle epithets . Froth sparkles in the sunshine and the most precious metal is the most solid . [I]0-i will tell [you]2256-you one thing of [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch . When [you]2256-you can tell [me]0-i such another of [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , [I]0-i will say [Mr Vernon]221-vernon is right — [the two men]3340-the two men are like . ' It was on [your]2256-you Christian festival of Christmas — in [a Russian town]4150-a russian town , no matter to name it — there was a chase , and all [the townspeople]4151-the townspeople turned out of [their]4151-the townspeople doors for the pleasure - excitement of seeing it . [The chased]4152-the chased ? [Only [a poor woman]4154-a poor woman , on [her]4154-a poor woman way from [Moscow]28-moscow to [the Austrian frontier]730-the austrian frontier]4153-only a poor woman , on her way from moscow to the austrian frontier . [Her]4154-a poor woman crime ? [She]4154-a poor woman was [a Jewess]4156-a jewess . For this , [men]466-men and [boys]448-boys , with savage dogs , with sticks , with stones , with all that [their]4151-the townspeople devilish brutality told [them]4151-the townspeople to use against [her]4154-a poor woman , hunted [her]4154-a poor woman down , shouting , deriding , exulting . And [she]4154-a poor woman fled from [them]4151-the townspeople , but slowly , for [she]4154-a poor woman was not young . And [those who took no part in the bloody pursuing]4159-those who took no part in the bloody pursuing looked on , smiling , many of [them]4151-the townspeople , and [those who smiled not , with interest]4160-those who smiled not , with interest ; [men who were well born]4161-men who were well born , and had not the ignorant superstition for whose sake [we]4162-we can pardon any crime to [the poor]1102-the poor . [Those who hunted [her]4154-a poor woman]4164-those who hunted her were [men who knew not [their]4165-men who knew not their right hand from their left right hand from [their]4165-men who knew not their right hand from their left left]4165-men who knew not their right hand from their left — thanks to [[their]4165-men who knew not their right hand from their left priests]4166-their priests — and [those who looked on approving]4167-those who looked on approving were [men of [your]4169-your world—"cultured]4168-men of your world—"cultured , " how [you]4169-your say ? '[2258-the poor woman] [The poor woman]2258-the poor woman fled , and still more slowly ; a stone had hit [her]2258-the poor woman hard , and [she]2258-the poor woman felt already at the sickness of death . At a corner a tarantass across [the road]3300-the road barred [her]2258-the poor woman way . [Its coachman]2260-its coachman had stopped for the pleasure of seeing the sport . [A Jewess stoned to death]2261-a jewess stoned to death ! The excellent pastime ! ' [She]4154-a poor woman looked around ; no way of escape . [The driver of the tarantass]4170-the driver of the tarantass raised [his]4170-the driver of the tarantass whip . [He]4170-the driver of the tarantass , too , would taste the pleasures of cruelty . [She]4154-a poor woman threw [her]4154-a poor woman arms up , and called upon [Jehovah]262-jehovah , whom [she]4154-a poor woman worshipped . Before the lash could fall , from within the tarantass sprang [a young man]3048-a young man , and snatched from [the driver]4172-the driver 's hand the whip . To let it fall on [her]4154-a poor woman with more force ? Not so . To sweep it full across the faces of [the foremost in the crowd]4173-the foremost in the crowd . [He]4170-the driver of the tarantass caught [the despised Jewess]4174-the despised jewess in [his]4170-the driver of the tarantass arms , and lifted [her]4174-the despised jewess into [[his]4170-the driver of the tarantass carriage]4175-his carriage . [The crowd]392-the crowd — [cowards]4177-cowards as well as [bullies]4178-bullies — drew back . [He]4170-the driver of the tarantass sprang upon the seat beside [the driver]4172-the driver , seized the reins , turned the horses , and to [them]392-the crowd , too , used the whip — so well , that [he]4170-the driver of the tarantass carried away from [that Russian town]4180-that russian town the saved life of [a woman]554-a woman . [He]4170-the driver of the tarantass took [her]554-a woman to a place of safety , and when [she]554-a woman was strong enough sent [her]554-a woman to join [[her]554-a woman son]4182-her son in [Vienna]70-vienna . [She]554-a woman was [[my]2262-he mother]1730-my mother . [She]554-a woman owed [her]554-a woman salvation from a death shameful and agonising to — '[2262-he] [He]2262-he stopped short suddenly and glanced expressively at [the broad - shouldered figure at the other end of the room]2263-the broad - shouldered figure at the other end of the room . [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid being now completely occupied with [the new arrivals]2269-the new arrivals , [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch seized the golden opportunity , and when [the room]2910-the room settled down again into repose , [Clare]139-clare found that [he]179-petrovitch occupied the ottoman beside [her]139-clare , where [Hirsch]222-hirsch had been sitting before . [Hirsch]222-hirsch had been set going by one of [Mr Quaid]233-mr quaid 's broad - based questions , and [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley and [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch were virtually alone . And yet , though [each]2273-each had wished often enough to see [the other]305-the other again , now that [they]2275-they were side by side it seemed to be not so easy to talk . It is always so difficult to chatter about trifles when [one]504-one is anxious to talk seriously , and it is difficult , almost up to the point of impossibility , to plunge into reasonable conversation in [a room full of inconsequent prattle]2277-a room full of inconsequent prattle . Do [you]0-i think , what [you]0-i said just now , that knowing the truth could make [me]0-i unhappy ? Oh no . It is knowledge without action that makes [me]0-i sad . '[0-i] ' No , no ; that is not [my]0-i thought , '[0-i] [he]0-i answered , in a voice that seemed to have caught a thrill from [her]2293-her own . ' Think a little longer . '[0-i] ' That 's one of [your]0-i leading principles , is n't it ? Independent thought . '[0-i] ' Yes . '[0-i] ' But [ordinary people]4198-ordinary people ca n't thoroughly think out all subjects . [One]504-one is obliged to take a great many of [one]504-one 's opinions at second - hand . '[0-i] ' Well , but neither can one act in all directions — and where [one]504-one has to act [one]504-one should think first . As for taking opinions at second - hand , that is a thing [you]0-i should never dare to do . If [you]0-i are not able to think for [yourself]0-i , [you]0-i should have no opinions . [[Your]0-i English Clifford]4203-your english clifford has told [you]0-i that if [you]0-i have no time to think [you]0-i have no time to believe . '[0-i] ' [I]0-i am sure [you]0-i are right . But [I]0-i am sure , too , that to think for one 's self means in most circles social ostracism ; and it wants very strong convictions to make one face that . '[0-i] ' Social ostracism , '[3756-the socialist] answered [the Socialist]3756-the socialist , with unutterable contempt in the gesture which accompanied [his]3756-the socialist words ; ' social ostracism , and by whom imposed ? Look at [the people around [you]0-i]4204-the people around you . '[3756-the socialist] [Clare]139-clare glanced nervously at [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid . ' See how small are [their]4204-the people around you aims , how trivial [their]4204-the people around you interests , how great [their]4204-the people around you love of ease , how small [their]4204-the people around you love of truth ; see what narrow minds [they]4204-the people around you have , what blinded eyes ; see all the good that would be in [them]4204-the people around you crushed out by the very conventionalities which [they]4204-the people around you uphold . How can [we]4205-we think it of any value , the opinion of such as these ? Or if [their]4204-the people around you condemnation should pain [us]4205-we , what a little thing is such a pain compared with the lifelong con sciousness of having , from the fear of it , crushed out the spark of truth in [our]4205-we own souls ? What a little thing compared with eternal truth is even life itself ! [We]4205-we come out of the darkness , and into that darkness must return . Is it not better , seeing the little time that is [ours]4205-we , to know that [we]4205-we at least have listened to the wail of agony that ever goes up to the deaf heavens?—that [we]4205-we have done what [we]4205-we could in [our]4205-we little day to help forward a better time for [those who shall come after [us]4205-we]4206-those who shall come after us , than to know that [we]4205-we have had the good opinion of " [respectable people]4207-respectable people " ? '[201-mrs quaid] ' If [one]504-one could only hope that [one]504-one could help it forward ! '[139-clare] sighed [Clare]139-clare . ' Hope ? [We]4205-we know it . These things will be . It is a question of the little sooner or the little later . There is no standing still . [He]4210-he that is not with [us]4205-we is against [us]4205-we . But [we]4205-we shall triumph in the end . [We]4205-we know that all this misery , all this sin , all this selfishness , all this stupidity even , are the direct result of the social milieu . It is this knowledge that makes [us]4205-we [the deadly enemies of the Capitalist system]4211-the deadly enemies of the capitalist system , and that is why [we]4205-we are hated by [those who profit by it]4212-those who profit by it . '[2295-he] [He]2295-he spoke in a low voice , full of suppressed excitement . When [he]2295-he ended [the girl]367-the girl drew a long breath . '[2295-he] ' Oh , [[my]201-mrs quaid dear]362-my dear [Mr Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , '[201-mrs quaid] exclaimed [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid , who pausing out of breath from [her]201-mrs quaid exertions in the cause of education , had caught the last dozen words , ' [you]179-petrovitch are really too severe ! As [Hirsch]222-hirsch and [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch went away together , [the Austrian]3564-the austrian said , — '[2305-the lady who is always charmed] So , [the lady who is always charmed]2305-the lady who is always charmed will charm [herself]2305-the lady who is always charmed with making [you]2303-you meet [him]2306-him , bon grè , mal grè . But not in [that house]2307-that house . ' '[2305-the lady who is always charmed] Good , ' grunted [Hirsch]222-hirsch ; and [the two men]3340-the two men fell to smoking silently . IT took [Richard Ferrier]130-richard just three months to decide what course [his]130-richard future life should take . [He]130-richard was too old for [the Army]72-the army or [Civil Service]73-civil service . [The Church]74-the church was equally out of the question , for a reason equally potent . Need [we]4223-we say that [his]130-richard first idea had been to earn [his]130-richard living by literature ? In these days of extended education and cheap stationery , it always is the very first idea of any one whose ordinary source of income is suddenly cut short . [Richard]130-richard had always felt at college that [he]130-richard had a decided faculty for writing ; but an uninterrupted stream of returned MS . , '[2305-the lady who is always charmed] declined , with thanks ' by all sorts and conditions of [editors]4224-editors , convinced [him]130-richard in less than three months that , if writing indeed were [his]130-richard vocation , it was one that [he]130-richard must forego until [he]130-richard could pay for the publishing of [his]130-richard own works , which was not exactly the view [he]130-richard had in wishing to adopt it . [He]130-richard had no interest in the law , and [he]130-richard knew well enough that [he]130-richard had not talent to enable [him]130-richard to dispense with interest . Besides , [his]130-richard leanings had never been that way . The medical profession inspired [him]130-richard with far more interest . [His]130-richard favourite study had always been biology . [He]130-richard had enough money to live on sparingly till the necessary four years should have expired , and it seemed to [him]130-richard better to adopt a profession than to go in for trade in any form or shape . [He]130-richard had had enough of trade . [He]130-richard made a round of visits among special chums of [his]130-richard own , and during the time so occupied had thought long and seriously about [his]130-richard future , and , of all the ideas that came to [him]130-richard , that of being [a doctor]3275-a doctor was [the one with most attractions and fewest drawbacks]4226-the one with most attractions and fewest drawbacks . So early in March [he]130-richard entered [himself]130-richard as [a student at [Guy 's]265-guy]4227-a student at guy 's , determined to throw [himself]130-richard heart and soul into [his]130-richard new career , and to let the dead past be . No return to the conditions of that past seemed possible to [him]130-richard , and , though [he]130-richard determined to think of it as little as [he]130-richard could , there were some things about it that haunted [him]130-richard disturbingly . But [he]130-richard hoped , among [new friends]4228-new friends and with new ambitions , to forget successfully . [A man]2882-a man has [his]2882-a man life to live , and life is not over at twenty - five , even when [one]504-one has lost [father]301-father , fortune , and heart 's desire . One windy , wild , bright March morning [he]130-richard was walking up to [the hospital]4232-the hospital as usual from [[his]130-richard lodgings in [Kennington]76-kennington]4233-his lodgings in kennington . [He]130-richard looked as cheerful as the morning itself as [he]130-richard strode along with an oak stick in [his]130-richard hand , and under [his]130-richard arm two or three shiny black note - books with red edges . Opposite [St Thomas 's Street]4234-st thomas 's street [he]130-richard paused to watch for a favourable moment in which to effect a crossing ; and before [he]130-richard had time to plunge into the chaos of [vans]4235-vans , [omnibuses]4236-omnibuses , [cabs]378-cabs , [carriages]4238-carriages , [trucks]4239-trucks , barrows and blasphemy , the touch of a hand on [his]130-richard arm made [him]130-richard turn sharply round . [It]4240-it was [[his]130-richard foster - mother]4241-his foster - mother , with a basket on [her]4241-his foster - mother arm , [her]4241-his foster - mother attire several shades shabbier than [he]130-richard had been used to see it , and [her]4241-his foster - mother worn face lighted up with pleasure at meeting [him]130-richard . '[2308-ah'm] Eh , but [Ah'm]2308-ah'm glad to see [thi]2309-thee face , [[my]0-i lad]3012-my lad , ' [she]4241-his foster - mother said earnestly , as [he]130-richard turned and shook [her]4241-his foster - mother hand heartily . '[0-i] [I]0-i thowt as there was [na]2311-na more nor two pair o ' shoulders like these , and [I]0-i know'd it was [thee]2309-thee or [Rowley]112-rowley the minute [Ah]2308-ah'm seed [thee]2309-thee . '[0-i] The familiar North - country sing - song accent sent a momentary pain through [the young man]2891-the young man 's heart as [he]2891-the young man answered , — ' [I]2891-the young man 'm[2891-the young man] awfully glad to see [you]0-i again ; but what in the name of fortune are [you]0-i doing [here]2895-here ? ' '[2891-the young man] There 's na fortune in't but bad fortune , [lad]2907-lad , ' [she]2315-she answered ; '[2311-na] [tha]2311-na know'd well enough when [thee]2311-na and [Rowley]112-rowley fell out as [Thornsett]30-thornsett would n't be a home for any o ' [us]4242-we for long . '[2315-she] There was no reproach in [her]2315-she tone . [Her]2315-she speech was only a plain statement of fact . ' But what made [you]0-i come to [London]6-london ? Oh , but it is big , [Master Dick]106-dick . [Ah'm]2311-na getting a bit used to it now , but when first [we]4242-we came here the bigness and the din of it used to get into [my]2315-she head like , till times [Ah]2311-na felt a'most daft wi '[2315-she] it . ' By this time [he]0-i had piloted [her]2315-she across , and [they]4242-we were walking side by side towards [London Bridge]79-london bridge , whither [she]2315-she told [him]0-i [she]2315-she was bound . '[0-i] [I]0-i 'm afraid [Hatfield]134-alice found [himself]134-alice mistaken about the work ; there are [no mills in [London]6-london]4245-no mills in london , '[130-richard] said [Richard]130-richard . ' No , or if there be [we]4242-we never found them ; but [the master]1664-the master 's had a bit o '[130-richard] luck , and [he]2316-he 's getten took on at [a place [they]2318-they call [Dartford]78-dartford]2317-a place they call dartford ; m'appen [you]130-richard 've heerd on it ? ' '[130-richard] Well , [I]0-i am glad to hear that . [I]0-i hope [all the hands]2319-all the hands have done as well . ' '[2319-all the hands] [No one]494-no one 's gladder nor [me]0-i . '[2324-she] No more did [Richard]130-richard , but [he]130-richard forbore to say so ; and [she]2324-she went on , the pent - up anxiety and sorrow of the last few weeks finding vent at last , — ' An '[2316-he] [he]2316-he 's bitter set against [Rowley]112-rowley . '[106-dick] cried [Dick]106-dick , losing control of [his]106-dick tongue at the sudden implication of [himself]106-dick in these charges ; ' what could [I]106-dick do ? ' How did [tha]0-i find it out ? '[141-mrs hatfield] [Mrs Hatfield]141-mrs hatfield persisted : and [Richard]130-richard in desperation told [her]141-mrs hatfield the whole story . It seemed to [her]141-mrs hatfield as convincing as it had done to [him]130-richard . [The mother]3271-the mother asked [him]0-i innumerable questions about [Alice]134-alice — how had [she]134-alice looked , how had [she]134-alice spoken ? It grieved [him]0-i not to be able to give [her]3271-the mother pleasanter answers , but , rather to [his]0-i surprise , [her]3271-the mother mind seemed to dwell less with sorrow on [Alice]134-alice 's want and hard work , than with pleasure on the thought that [[her]3271-the mother daughter]1329-her daughter had given up [[her]1329-her daughter lover]3539-her lover , or , as [she]3271-the mother called it , returned to [the narrow path]2341-the narrow path . But why had [she]134-alice not returned to [[her]134-alice mother]3281-her mother ? And that question [Dick]106-dick could not answer . All these questions and replies had taken some time , and [the Dartford train]2343-the dartford train had gone . [Dick]106-dick found out the time of [the next train]2344-the next train , and then came and sat down beside [her]3271-the mother , and did [his]106-dick best to cheer [her]3271-the mother , in which attempt [his]106-dick real affection for [her]3271-the mother assured [him]106-dick a measure of success . By the time the [Dartford]78-dartford train was due [she]3271-the mother was calm again and reasonably cheerful . [He]106-dick led [her]3271-the mother to tell [him]106-dick of [their]2345-their life since [they]2345-their had come to [London]6-london ; how nearly everything had been turned into money ; how the basket on [her]3271-the mother arm contained all that [she]3271-the mother had been able to keep ; and how [she]3271-the mother was going down to join [[her]3271-the mother husband]1245-her husband , and to try to take root with [him]1245-her husband in a fresh soil . From [her]3271-the mother [he]106-dick heard for the first time of [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's visit to [Thornsett]126-thornsett , of the rioting of the mill hands , and , though [she]3271-the mother did not say so in so many words , [he]106-dick could see that [she]3271-the mother placed the two events in the relation of cause and effect . [She]3271-the mother told [him]106-dick , too , of [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's bravery , and of the fate of the luckless [Isaac Potts]252-isaac ; and [Dick]106-dick , though [he]106-dick could n't help feeling interest and admiration at this recital , did not like the way in which [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley 's name and [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's were coupled in [Mrs Hatfield]141-mrs hatfield 's account of the help , advice , and kindness shown to the hands before [they]2347-they dispersed from [Thornsett]30-thornsett . [Her]3271-the mother words suggested to [him]106-dick vague suspicions ; but [he]106-dick could n't think much just then , for it was time to take [Mrs Hatfield]141-mrs hatfield 's ticket and to see [her]3271-the mother off . This [he]106-dick did , and when [he]106-dick had seen [her]3271-the mother comfortably seated in [a corner of [a second - class carriage]2349-a second - class carriage]2348-a corner of a second - class carriage , [he]106-dick said good - bye to [her]3271-the mother , giving [her]3271-the mother at parting a very hearty hand - shake , and a sovereign , which [he]106-dick could ill afford . '[106-dick] [He]106-dick drew back from [the train]1421-the train as [it]1421-the train began to move , and waved a farewell . As [she]3271-the mother disappeared [Dick]106-dick began to wonder what [he]106-dick should do with [himself]106-dick . The lecture [he]106-dick had been about to attend was hopelessly lost and there was nothing particular to be done till after lunch . Obedient to what would have been the instinct of [most young men under such circumstances]2351-most young men under such circumstances , [his]106-dick first thought was to take a ticket to [Charing Cross]65-charing cross , that being a more cheerful place for the consideration of any problem than [the station where [he]106-dick found [himself]106-dick]2352-the station where he found himself . [He]106-dick was just turning to go down to [the booking office]2356-the booking office when — ' Great heavens , how wonderful ! '[106-dick] [he]106-dick said . ' said [Richard]130-richard , very slowly . [He]130-richard sat down on the wooden seat without another word . [He]318-sir did not know how much [this man]976-this man knew of [Alice]134-alice , and [he]318-sir felt it would be unfair to tell [her]134-alice story , as far as [he]318-sir knew it , to [one who seemed to know [her]134-alice only as [a married woman]4276-a married woman]4275-one who seemed to know her only as a married woman . '[0-i] The reason [I]0-i was so surprised when [I]0-i heard [you]2376-you call that — lady [Mrs Litvinoff]180-litvinoff , was that [I]0-i have known [her]180-litvinoff from [a child]484-a child , and did not know that [she]180-litvinoff was married . [I]0-i — [I]0-i — also knew [a Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff in [London]6-london a few months ago , and certainly did not know that [he]121-litvinoff was married . The connection of the two names startled [me]0-i . [I]0-i must also tell [you]2376-you that it did more than startle [me]0-i ; it relieved [me]0-i . ' '[2376-you] [You]2376-you are , then , very much interested in [[my]0-i friend]1506-my friend ? ' said [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch . '[466-men] Well , [I]0-i am interested , very much interested , but not quite in the way that [men]466-men generally are when [they]466-men talk about being interested in [a woman]554-a woman . [I]0-i thought [[my]0-i brother]3376-my brother had done [her]1316-that young woman a great wrong . Can [you]2384-you tell [me]0-i whether [he]3376-my brother did or not ? ' '[107-roland] So far as [I]0-i know [Mrs Litvinoff]180-litvinoff 's story , ' said [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , speaking very deliberately , '[107-roland] no wrong of any sort has ever been done [her]1316-that young woman by [any one of that name]2385-any one of that name . ' '[1316-that young woman] Ay , but , ' said [Richard]130-richard , '[1316-that young woman] so far as [you]2384-you know ; but do [you]2384-you know all ?
