' '[0-i] [It]2388-it was not [[my]0-i brother]3376-my brother ? ' '[2388-it] It was not [[your]2384-you brother]2894-your brother . ' [Richard]130-richard had just said that [he]130-richard felt greatly relieved . If that statement was true , [his]130-richard looks certainly belied [him]130-richard . '[2388-it] One question more , ' [he]0-i said . '[2388-it] [I]0-i want to know exactly how far wrong [I]0-i have been . Do [you]2384-you know if [[my]0-i brother]3376-my brother has had any communication at all with [her]1316-that young woman since [she]1316-that young woman left [her]1316-that young woman home?—did [he]3376-my brother know where [she]1316-that young woman was ? ' '[3376-my brother] [I]0-i believe that [he]3376-my brother has had no communication with [her]1316-that young woman , and that [he]3376-my brother did not know where [she]1316-that young woman was . ' '[3376-my brother] Can [you]2384-you tell [me]0-i who [this Litvinoff]180-litvinoff is , then ? Is [he]3376-my brother the Count [Michael Litvinoff]121-litvinoff that [I]0-i know , or knew ? If so , did [he]3376-my brother marry , and when did [he]3376-my brother marry [her]1316-that young woman ? and why did [she]1316-that young woman leave [him?—for]2392-him?—for [she]1316-that young woman did leave [some man]2393-some man ; [she]1316-that young woman told [me]0-i so . ' '[1316-that young woman] Ah , ' said [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch , '[2384-you] [you]2384-you said one more question ; that question [I]0-i answered because [I]0-i thought [you]2384-you were really concerned in knowing the answer . Forgive [me]0-i , these other matters [I]0-i think do not concern [you]2384-you . ' '[0-i] Well , ' [Richard]130-richard answered , '[0-i] [I]0-i knew [that girl]3186-that girl when [she]3186-that girl was [a baby]2395-a baby , and [I]0-i 've always been fond of [her]3186-that girl , and [I]0-i should naturally be glad to hear anything about [her]3186-that girl . [I]0-i am glad to see [her]3186-that girl looking so much better , and better cared for than when [I]0-i met [her]3186-that girl last . ' [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch bent [his]179-petrovitch head silently . [They]4278-they had stopped by this time just opposite [the Borough Market]4279-the borough market . '[0-i] [I]0-i am sorry [you]2384-you will not tell [me]0-i more about [her]3186-that girl ; but since [you]2384-you have told [me]0-i that [[my]0-i brother]3376-my brother has not injured [her]3186-that girl in any way , [I]0-i do n't know that [I]0-i have any right to ask [you]2384-you more . [I]0-i must thank [you]2384-you for telling [me]0-i what [you]2384-you have done , and ask [you]2384-you to excuse [my]0-i seeming curiosity . ' [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch bowed ; [young Ferrier]130-richard did the same , and [they]4280-they parted — [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch turned across [the bridge]927-the bridge , while [Richard]130-richard retraced [his]130-richard steps towards [the station]3655-the station . [He]130-richard made [his]130-richard way to [the telegraph office]4283-the telegraph office , and sent off this message:—'Richard Ferrier , [[Guy]4284-guy 's Hospital]81-guy 's hospital , [London]6-london , to [Gates]114-gates , [The Hollies]4285-the hollies , [Firth Vale.—Please]82-firth vale.—please wire [me]2397-he [[my]2397-he brother]3376-my brother 's address at once if [you]4287-you know it . '[2397-he] Then [he]2397-he crossed [the station - yard]2398-the station - yard , and ran down the steep stone steps which are part of [the shortest cut to [the hospital]4232-the hospital]2399-the shortest cut to the hospital , and as [he]2397-he went [he]2397-he felt more wretched than [he]2397-he had ever been before . [He]2397-he had always believed in [himself]2397-he so intensely that an actual injury would have been less hard to bear than this sudden shattering of [his]2397-he faith in [his]2397-he own judgment . [He]2397-he had been so utterly mistaken — so wrong all round . Everything had seemed to point to [[his]2397-he brother]2917-his brother 's guilt . Now everything seemed to have pointed to [his]2397-he innocence . If [Richard]130-richard 's eyes had not been so blinded by — what ? It was a moment for seeing things clearly , and [Richard]130-richard saw that [his]130-richard own passion and jealousy had perverted [his]130-richard view of all that had taken place in the autumn . That meeting in [[Spray]168-spray 's Buildings]811-spray 's buildings — of course it was the likeliest thing in [the world]2867-the world that [Roland]107-roland really had seen [Litvinoff]180-litvinoff , and at the thought of [that sympathetic nobleman]2404-that sympathetic nobleman [the young man]2891-the young man ground [his]2891-the young man teeth . How completely [he]2891-the young man had been fooled ! It must be the same [Litvinoff]180-litvinoff — for had not [Alice]134-alice been present at [his]2891-the young man lecture in [Soho]23-soho ? How had [Alice]134-alice met [such a man]2406-such a man ? Oh , that might have happened in a thousand ways . Had [Litvinoff]180-litvinoff really married [her]134-alice ? [Richard]130-richard thought [he]130-richard had not . [He]130-richard remembered [Litvinoff]180-litvinoff 's moustache , and felt sure that [he]130-richard had not . Felt sure ? How could [he]130-richard feel sure of anything , when here , where [he]130-richard had been so absolutely certain , [he]130-richard was proved to have been wrong ? What fearful blunders [he]130-richard had made — what a horrible muddle [he]130-richard had got everything into — what irretrievable mischief [he]130-richard had done ! But , though [he]130-richard blamed [himself]130-richard deeply and bitterly , [he]130-richard still , not unnaturally , blamed [Litvinoff]180-litvinoff with still more bitter earnestness . One thing only was clear to [him]130-richard . [He]130-richard must find [Roland]107-roland at once , tell [him]107-roland all the circumstances , and beg [his]107-roland pardon . It would be all right again between [him]130-richard and [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother , towards whom [he]130-richard now felt a rush of reactionary affection . But how about the mill hands , now scattered far and wide beyond recall — beyond the reach of [his]130-richard help — through this same mad folly of [his]130-richard ? In an impulse to do something for at least [one of those who had suffered through [him]130-richard]2408-one of those who had suffered through him , [he]130-richard turned off from [the hospital]4232-the hospital and took a hansom to [[his]130-richard rooms]2410-his rooms , where [he]130-richard unlocked [his]130-richard desk , and , taking a five - pound note from [his]130-richard slender stock of money , enclosed it in an envelope , which [he]130-richard addressed to [Mrs Hatfield]141-mrs hatfield at the address [she]141-mrs hatfield had given [him]130-richard , in a hand not [his]130-richard own . [He]130-richard would do more for [them]2411-them when [he]130-richard and [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother had begun to work [the mill]2936-the mill again . That would be one big result of [his]130-richard new knowledge . [His]130-richard medical studies would be at an end , and [he]130-richard would be once more Ferrier of [Thornsett]30-thornsett . But that was poor compensation for all the rest . When [Mr Gates]114-gates ' answering telegram came it was a wet blanket on [Richard]130-richard 's longing to make [his]130-richard confession and talk things over with [Roland]107-roland — for it ran [thus:—'Robert Gates]114-gates , [The Hollies]83-the hollies , [Firth Vale]11-firth vale , to [Richard Ferrier]130-richard , [Guy]265-guy 's Hospital.—Don't know [his]130-richard address — [he]130-richard is expected [here]2895-here in a few days . Has left [Chelsea]61-chelsea , and is making visits on [his]130-richard way [here]2895-here . Glad [you]114-gates want [him]130-richard . Letter follows . '[130-richard] So [he]130-richard could not see [Roland]107-roland that day , after all , and there was nothing for it but to possess [his]130-richard soul in patience until [he]130-richard heard again from [Gates]114-gates . So [he]130-richard spent the evening with [some congenial acquaintances who had diggings in [Trinity Square]84-trinity square]2414-some congenial acquaintances who had diggings in trinity square , and managed to get through the night without being driven to distraction by [his]130-richard remorseful self - tormenting thoughts . But the next morning [he]130-richard remembered , with a start , for the first time , that , not content with believing [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother to be guilty of a disgraceful action , [he]130-richard had accused [him]130-richard of it to [Clare Stanley]139-clare , and , worse than that , to [[Alice]134-alice 's own mother]2416-alice 's own mother . [He]130-richard felt [he]130-richard could never face [Clare]139-clare again after that , come what might . But [the Hatfields]243-the hatfields ? At least it would be only fair to make what reparation [he]130-richard could by undeceiving [them]2417-them . [He]130-richard would go down to [Dartford]78-dartford that very day , and tell [them]2417-them how mistaken [he]130-richard had been . [He]130-richard went by [the same train]2418-the same train which had carried [Mrs Hatfield thither]141-mrs hatfield on the preceding day . Arrived at [Dartford]78-dartford the Dismal , [Richard]130-richard betook [himself]130-richard to the address that had been given [him]130-richard , which , after some difficulty , [he]130-richard found to be one of [a row of [small , ill - favoured , squalid cottages a little way out of [the town]1633-the town]2420-small , ill - favoured , squalid cottages a little way out of the town]2419-a row of small , ill - favoured , squalid cottages a little way out of the town . There were [a good many children]2422-a good many children about , who stared at [him]130-richard with open - eyed curiosity , and did dreadful things to [their]2422-a good many children mouths with [their]2422-a good many children grimy little fingers in the excitement of seeing [a gentleman]497-a gentleman stop at [No . 5 Earl 's Terrace]2424-no . 5 earl 's terrace . The battered , blistered green door had no knocker . The handle of [Richard]130-richard 's umbrella afforded an impromptu one , and , in answer to the spirited solo which [he]130-richard proceeded to execute with it , the door was opened , and by [[his]130-richard foster - mother]4241-his foster - mother [herself]4241-his foster - mother . [She]4241-his foster - mother looked very pale and worried , and had evidently been crying . [She]4241-his foster - mother did n't seem surprised to see [him]130-richard ; [she]4241-his foster - mother was in that state of mind when nothing seems worth being surprised about . ' Come in , [lad]2907-lad , '[4241-his foster - mother] [she]4241-his foster - mother said . ' [Ah]130-richard got [thi]130-richard kind token . [Ah]130-richard know'd '[4241-his foster - mother] twas [thee]130-richard as sent it , and m'appen [Ah'll]130-richard need it more nor [tha]130-richard thowt when [tha]130-richard sent it , for [t ' maister]4291-t ' maister 's giv '[130-richard] up [his]130-richard work an ' gone off . '[4241-his foster - mother] [She]4241-his foster - mother had set a chair for [him]130-richard , and as [she]4241-his foster - mother finished this speech [she]4241-his foster - mother sat down [herself]4241-his foster - mother and looked hopelessly at [him]130-richard . ' Gone — gone ! Left [you]130-richard ! Why , [he]107-roland must be out of [his]107-roland mind . '[4241-his foster - mother] ' [His]107-roland mind 's right enough ; it 's [his]107-roland soul as [Ah'm]110-god feared about , [Dick]106-dick . [He]107-roland 's gone to have it out wi '[4241-his foster - mother] [Rowley]112-rowley , and get at the rights of it . ' '[4241-his foster - mother] But where is [Roland]107-roland ? Where 's [he]107-roland gone to ? ' '[107-roland] [He]107-roland 's gone to [Thornsett]30-thornsett . ' '[107-roland] Why , [Roland]107-roland is n't [there]2994-there . ' '[107-roland] Thank [God]110-god ! [God]110-god be praised , if it 'll on'y please [His]107-roland good providence to keep ['em]4292-'em fra meetin '[107-roland] ! ' '[107-roland] But how came [he]107-roland to go ? How did it happen ? Tell [me]0-i all about it ? ' It seemed that when [[her]4293-her husband]1245-her husband had met [her]4293-her at [Dartford Station]86-dartford station , [she]4293-her , pleased with having met [Richard]130-richard , had told [him]130-richard of [the rencontre]4295-the rencontre . That [he]130-richard had closely questioned [her]4293-her , and when at last [he]130-richard had learned every word that had passed between [them]4296-them , [he]130-richard had turned suddenly on [her]4293-her , and told [her]4293-her that this was the first time [he]130-richard had ever even thought of such a thing being possible as that [Roland]107-roland had been the cause of [Alice]134-alice 's ruin , and that now [he]130-richard did know [he]130-richard would not lose a day in facing [him]130-richard with the accusation . '[2427-you] Do [you]2427-you mean to say , ' said [Richard]130-richard , '[2427-you] that it 's through [me]0-i [he]2428-he thinks that [Roland]107-roland took [her]2429-her away ? ' '[2428-he] [I]0-i do n't say it was [thy]2427-you fault , [lad]2907-lad . [I]0-i 'm more to blame than [thee]2427-you . [I]2428-he should a - kept [my]2428-he clattering tongue quiet , and [I]2428-he should a - known [[my]2428-he own man]4297-my own man better after a '[2428-he] these years nor to think that if [he]2428-he had a - thowt it was [Rowley]112-rowley [he]2428-he wouldna ha ' faced [him]2428-he wi '[2428-he] it long sin ' . '[130-richard] ' This is devilish pleasant ! '[130-richard] said [Richard]130-richard , rising and taking a stride across [the little room]2431-the little room ; but how did [he]130-richard go ? ' It appeared [he]130-richard had started off with but a pound , or little more , in [his]130-richard pocket , intending to walk the greater part of the way , and only telling [her]2432-she that [she]2432-she would n't hear of [him]130-richard until [she]2432-she saw [him]130-richard back again . '[130-richard] And what do [you]2432-she think will happen when [they]2433-they do meet ? ' [he]0-i asked . '[2432-she] Oh , [Ah'm]2434-ah'm feared to think ! ' [she]2432-she said , wringing [her]2432-she hands and beginning to weep . '[2432-she] [I]0-i 'll tell [you]2432-she what [I]0-i 'll do , ' said [Richard]130-richard . '[0-i] [I]0-i 'll go straight down to [Thornsett]30-thornsett now , and keep a look - out for [Hatfield]134-alice . [I]0-i 'll stop any more mischief , any way . [I]0-i think [I]0-i can promise [you]2432-she that nothing much will happen if [they]2433-they do meet . ' [She]2432-she caught hold of [his]130-richard hand , and began to thank [him]130-richard . '[0-i] Oh , do n't thank [me]0-i ! ' [he]0-i said ; '[0-i] the whole sad business has been [my]0-i fault from beginning to end . [I]0-i found out yesterday , almost directly [I]0-i left [you]2432-she , that [Rowley]112-rowley was as innocent of doing any harm to [Alice]134-alice as [I]0-i am , and [I]0-i found out , too , that [she]134-alice is well and pretty happy , and , [I]0-i heard , married . If it had n't been for [me]0-i , [Hatfield]134-alice would n't have gone off on this wild - goose chase . But [I]0-i must get back now ; [[my]0-i train]2435-my train goes in twenty minutes , and [I]0-i want to catch [the three o'clock train for [Firth Vale]11-firth vale]2436-the three o'clock train for firth vale . ' [He]0-i caught [the three o'clock train]4298-the three o'clock train to [Firth Vale]11-firth vale , having managed , by a very hurried farewell , to escape the torrent of questions [Mrs Hatfield]141-mrs hatfield would have liked to pour out . [He]0-i felt that , all things considered , the less [he]0-i said about the matter the better . [He]0-i had been wrong too often , and too much . THERE was rejoicing in [the house of [Robert Gates]266-gates]4299-the house of robert gates , as over a prodigal returned , when [Richard Ferrier]130-richard avowed that [he]130-richard had been mistaken all through in [his]130-richard quarrel with [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother , and that [he]130-richard was now only anxious to acknowledge [his]130-richard error , and to do [his]130-richard best to set things going again on the old footing . But [he]130-richard had some days to wait before [he]130-richard could make [his]130-richard confession . [Thornsett Edge]1-thornsett edge had remained unoccupied , for there was some difficulty in letting [a furnished house near [a deserted village]4302-a deserted village]4301-a furnished house near a deserted village . [People]298-people did not seem to care about [the vicinity of all those empty shells of [homes]2187-homes]4304-the vicinity of all those empty shells of homes . So [Roland]107-roland had decided to occupy [it]1-thornsett edge again , and [he]107-roland was coming down there to get things ready for [[his]107-roland aunt]2888-his aunt 's reception , and was making a few visits to [old friends]3077-old friends on [his]107-roland way . [He]107-roland had written down to [the old couple in charge]4308-the old couple in charge to have [the place]936-the place ready , as [he]107-roland might come down any day . Two days passed and [he]107-roland had not come , and [Richard]130-richard was getting tired of the constant inquiries and congratulations which assailed [him]130-richard at [The Hollies]83-the hollies . [He]130-richard thought [he]130-richard would go [home]303-home , and be there to welcome [Roland]107-roland when [he]107-roland arrived . So [he]130-richard sent over [his]130-richard portmanteau , and took up [[his]130-richard quarters]4311-his quarters in [[his]130-richard old room at [Thornsett Edge]1-thornsett edge]4312-his old room at thornsett edge . [He]130-richard was in a very tender and remorseful frame of mind in those days . [He]130-richard wandered all over [the old house]4313-the old house , full filled of memories of the time when [he]130-richard and [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother played together [there]2994-there as [children]1446-children ; of the time when , later , [they]1446-children thrashed each other as [schoolboys]4317-schoolboys , with right good will . There were haunting thoughts of the dissension that had grown up between [them]1446-children , and of the shadow that the knowledge of it had cast upon [[their]1446-children father]1091-their father 's deathbed . The necessity which [he]130-richard felt [himself]130-richard to be under of keeping a sharp look - out for [John Hatfield]135-john hatfield , fortunately served as a kind of antidote to the rush of memories and associations which came over [Richard]130-richard , now that [he]130-richard was once again in [[his]130-richard home]3710-his home . [He]130-richard walked down to [the village]3667-the village to seek out [the few '[0-i] hands ' who had clung like rooks to [[their]4321-the few ' hands ' who had clung like rooks to their old haunts old haunts]4322-their old haunts]4321-the few ' hands ' who had clung like rooks to their old haunts , and there [he]130-richard saw sad sights and heard sad stories enough to have driven [him]130-richard mad had [he]130-richard not known that it would soon be in [his]130-richard power to set things in some degree right again . [He]130-richard resolved , and felt sure of [Roland]107-roland 's co - operation in [his]130-richard scheme , to seek out as many of [the old '[0-i] hands]4323-the old ' hands ' as could be got word of , and to give each of [them]4323-the old ' hands enough to get a [home]303-home together again . Of course [he]130-richard thought often of [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley ; but the past months of unusual action and changed surroundings had altered [his]130-richard feeling for [her]122-miss stanley , which was fortunate for [him]130-richard , since [he]130-richard had falsely accused [[his]130-richard own brother]4325-his own brother to [her]122-miss stanley — a meanness which [he]130-richard knew it to be quite impossible for [such a woman as [Clare]139-clare]4326-such a woman as clare ever to forget or forgive . [He]130-richard thought of [her]122-miss stanley now without any of the old passion , as [he]130-richard might have thought of [one who had died long before]4327-one who had died long before , or of one whom [he]130-richard had loved in some other life . This did not prevent [him]130-richard from feeling furiously jealous of [Litvinoff]180-litvinoff , to whom [he]130-richard seemed to have transferred all the anger that had burned in [him]130-richard against [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother , intensified by a galling consciousness of the complete success which [Litvinoff]180-litvinoff had achieved in [his]130-richard attempt to deceive and mislead [him]130-richard . There should be a reckoning for that , [Richard]130-richard thought . [He]130-richard felt glad [he]130-richard had always mistrusted [the man]3262-the man . It showed that [his]130-richard judgment was worth something sometimes , and this pleased [his]130-richard self - love . On the third day came a telegram from [Matlock]267-matlock , which said that [Roland]107-roland would be at [home]303-home that evening . [Richard]130-richard roamed about [the house]291-the house in restless impatience all day . How should [they]4332-they meet ? [He]130-richard should not dare to go to the door to greet [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother lest [he]130-richard should imagine that it was a renewal of hostilities , not a welcome [home]303-home , that was intended . [Richard]130-richard had no eye for dramatic effects , nor any leaning thereto , but [he]130-richard charged [the old people]4335-the old people to say nothing of [his]130-richard presence , and to leave [him]130-richard to announce [himself]130-richard to [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother when [he]130-richard should think well . [[His]130-richard brother]2917-his brother would have done exactly the same thing from absolutely opposite motives . So when [Roland]107-roland walked up to [[his]107-roland home]3710-his home in the teeth of the wild March wind the only welcome that met [him]107-roland was that of [the old woman in charge]4339-the old woman in charge , and this seemed to [him]107-roland to be so inconsequently effusive , and [the good lady]1450-the good lady [herself]2437-herself seemed so unreasonably radiant , that [he]107-roland was quite flattered . It was pleasant to [him]107-roland to be appreciated and admired , even by [a '[0-i] person in charge]4341-a ' person in charge . ' '[0-i] The fire 's [i]0-i ' [the dining - room]1444-the dining - room , [Mr Roland]107-roland , '[2437-herself] [she]2437-herself said ; ' an '[2437-herself] [I]0-i 'll dish [ye]2438-ye up the supper in less nor half a minute , [sir]318-sir . It 's a glad day for [Thornsett]126-thornsett as sees [yer]2438-ye back agen . ' [[Mrs Brock]268-mrs brock 's son]4343-mrs brock 's son had worked in [the mill]2936-the mill — a fact which made the anticipated reconciliation peculiarly interesting to [her]2437-herself . [Richard]130-richard from [his]130-richard ambush in [[his]130-richard own room]2913-his own room heard the greeting , heard [the well - known voice]4346-the well - known voice giving orders about rugs and hat - boxes in the well - known tones . Then [he]130-richard heard doors open and close . After a while a savoury smell from the hot supper that was being carried in rose to [his]130-richard altitude . The dining - room door was opened , and shut several times . At last it was closed with a more decided touch , and in the noise of its closing was a settled sound as of a door that did not mean to open again just yet . [Richard]130-richard knew that the supper had been cleared away , and that [Roland]107-roland was most likely assisting digestion with tobacco and grog . This would be the time , [he]130-richard decided , to put in an appearance and to get through [his]130-richard proposed reconciliation . [He]130-richard went softly [downstairs]834-downstairs , and paused a moment with [his]130-richard hand on the dining - room door . [The house]291-the house was very still . As [he]130-richard stood there [he]130-richard heard a cinder fall from the fire in [the dining - room]1444-the dining - room , and the great hall clock at the foot of the stairs ticked louder than usual , as it seemed . [He]130-richard turned the handle and went in . [Roland]107-roland was sitting in the big arm - chair by the fire where [[their]4350-their father]1091-their father had been used to sit . As the door opened [he]130-richard looked up with a sort of displeased curiosity to see who it was that had the assurance to enter unannounced . When [he]130-richard saw who it was [he]130-richard gave a start , and the expression of [his]130-richard face changed to something deeper and sterner . [He]130-richard got up . '[0-i] [I]0-i understood from [Gates]266-gates , ' [he]130-richard said , '[266-gates] that [you]266-gates renounced all claim to be in [this house]2440-this house so long as half the possible rent was paid [you]266-gates . [I]0-i mean to pay [you]266-gates [your]266-gates half . May [I]0-i ask , then , what [you]266-gates want [here]2895-here ? ' '[0-i] [I]0-i want to beg [your]266-gates pardon , ' began [Richard]130-richard , [his]0-i hand still on the lock — when [[his]0-i brother]2917-his brother interrupted [him]0-i with , — '[0-i] Had n't [you]266-gates better close the door ? [I]0-i suppose [you]266-gates do n't want all [the world]2867-the world to hear anything [you]266-gates may have to say . ' [His]0-i tone was so icily cold that [the other]305-the other found it hard to go on as [he]0-i had intended . [He]0-i did [his]0-i best , however . '[266-gates] [I]0-i am very sorry for all that happened in the autumn . [I]0-i was quite deceived and misled , and [I]0-i beg [your]266-gates pardon . [I]0-i ca n't say more , and [I]0-i hope [you]266-gates 'll let bygones be bygones . ' [He]0-i held out [his]0-i hand . At this point in the scene [Dick]106-dick had fancied that [[his]106-dick brother]2917-his brother would clasp [his]106-dick hand with reciprocating affection , and all would be forgiven and forgotten . But [the other actor]4355-the other actor evidently intended a different '[266-gates] reading ' of the part assigned [him]106-dick . [He]106-dick made no movement to meet the outstretched hand . On the contrary , [he]106-dick put [his]106-dick hands in [his]106-dick pockets with a too expressive gesture , and was silent . '[0-i] Come , [Roland]107-roland , ' said [Dick]106-dick , who , knowing [himself]106-dick to have been in the wrong , displayed a patience which surprised [himself]106-dick ; '[0-i] make it up , [old man]2443-old man . ' '[2443-old man] [I]0-i am not sure , ' said [the other]305-the other slowly , '[0-i] that [I]0-i care to make it up , as [you]107-roland call it . No " making - up " can alter all that has gone wrong through [your]107-roland foolishness . [I]0-i 've gone through the worst of the trouble now , and , to tell [you]107-roland the truth , [I]0-i 'm not inclined to lay [myself]0-i open to any more experiences of this kind . [You]107-roland might be " deceived and misled " again . '[0-i] [Richard]130-richard , who had remained standing , gave the slightest possible stamp of impatience , which [[his]130-richard brother]2917-his brother did not observe . ' And as for the money , '[130-richard] [he]130-richard went on , ' [I]130-richard dare say [I]130-richard can do as well without it as with it . '[130-richard] ' Look here , '[106-dick] said [Dick]106-dick , [his]106-dick face flushing hotly ; ' if [you]107-roland suppose [I]106-dick care a straw about the dirty money , [you]107-roland 're[106-dick] mistaken ; only one of [us]2445-us ca n't have any without the other now . Come , [Roland]107-roland , be [friends]2905-friends , if it 's only for [the old dad]2447-the old dad 's sake . ' [Roland]107-roland seemed to have what [the children]1187-the children call the '[107-roland] black dog on [his]107-roland shoulder , ' but this appeal was not lost . [He]107-roland made an effort to overcome the resentment and bitterness that filled [him]107-roland , and after a moment held out [his]107-roland hand , saying , — '[107-roland] Very well , [I]0-i 'll shake hands . [I]0-i suppose [we]2445-us shall manage to scrape along together as well as [a good many brothers]2448-a good many brothers . ' And this was the reconciliation that [Richard]130-richard had had [his]130-richard heart full of for the last three or four days . It was piteously unlike [his]130-richard dreams of it . When [they]2445-us had shaken hands , [Dick]106-dick sat down . There was a silence — a very awkward silence . [Roland]107-roland passed the whisky along the table , and [the other mechanically]4358-the other mechanically helped [himself]107-roland . '[0-i] [I]0-i think , ' [Roland]107-roland said presently , '[0-i] that [you]2449-you owe [me]0-i an explanation of all this . ' '[2449-you] Of course [I]0-i do , ' assented [Richard]130-richard eagerly ; '[2449-you] but [you]2449-you are so — well , unapproachable ; but [I]0-i 'll tell [you]2449-you every word about it , ' which [he]0-i did , omitting no particulars which bore on the case . '[0-i] So [he]2450-he called [her]2451-her [Mrs Litvinoff]180-litvinoff , did [he]2450-he ? '[2450-he] [I]0-i should think [she]2451-her had just taken the name by chance , but for one thing . ' '[2451-her] And that is ? And was this really all the ground [you]2449-you had for doing what [you]2449-you did ? ' There was contempt in [his]0-i tone . '[180-litvinoff] No , ' said [Richard]130-richard . [I]0-i 've told [you]2449-you everything . ' '[0-i] The whole thing is over and done with now , ' [he]0-i answered ; '[0-i] and after to - night [I]0-i do n't want to ever speak about it ; but [I]0-i will tell [you]2449-you if [you]2449-you like . ' said [Dick]106-dick , to whom a generous action like this , even though only attempted , could not fail to appeal most strongly . '[0-i] But how is it now ? ' [he]106-dick went on , stung by a host of conflicting feelings . '[0-i] Have [you]107-roland made the running ? Have [you]107-roland won [her]139-clare ? ' '[107-roland] No ! ' [he]106-dick answered bitterly . '[107-roland] The closing of [the mill]2936-the mill settled that for [me]0-i as well as for [you]2449-you . [Some one else]3878-some one else has had as good a chance as [ours]2457-we , though , and has made a better use of it . [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff is a constant visitor at [the house where [she]139-clare is]2458-the house where she is , and [I]0-i do n't doubt [she]139-clare will marry [him]121-litvinoff ; unless , indeed , [he]121-litvinoff is married already . [I]0-i wish [I]0-i 'd never had that [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff down here . But who could have foreseen this ? ' '[2457-we] [We]2457-we 've both been [fools]1980-fools . ' [Roland]107-roland did not seem to relish this broad statement . '[1980-fools] [I]0-i ca n't think how , ' [he]107-roland was beginning , when [Mrs Brock]268-mrs brock came in with coals , and almost purred with pleasure at seeing [the two]2933-the two amicably drinking [their]2933-the two whisky at the same hearth . '[0-i] Look here , [old man]2443-old man , ' [he]0-i said ; '[2443-old man] [I]0-i 'm as sorry as [a fellow]3123-a fellow can be about all this , and [I]0-i ca n't think how [I]0-i could have been such [a fool]4362-a fool . That 's what [you]2443-old man were going to say , was n't it ? But since [we]4363-we 're[0-i] agreed on that , do n't let 's say any more about it . [I]0-i think [I]0-i 'll have a run round [the garden]292-the garden before [I]0-i turn in . Good - night . ' '[0-i] Good - night , ' [Roland]107-roland answered , but in a manner whose evident effort after cordiality made the failure of that effort the more painful . '[0-i] [I]0-i shall go to bed ; [I]0-i 'm dead beat — been knocking about all day . '[0-i] Then [they]2463-they shook hands again , and [Richard]130-richard went out . [He]0-i had thought that [Roland]107-roland would have met [his]0-i apologies with ready acceptance — [his]0-i revived brotherly love with equal enthusiasm — and the nature of the reconciliation jarred upon [him]0-i . And yet , as [he]0-i told [himself]0-i , [he]0-i thoroughly deserved it all . No doubt time would soften [[his]0-i brother]2917-his brother 's sense of injury , and some day [they]2463-they might be as [good friends]4266-good friends again as [they]2463-they had been before [Clare Stanley]139-clare 's prettiness had come , like a will - o'-the - wisp , to lead [them]2463-they into all sorts of follies . [He]0-i tried to think [he]0-i would be glad if [she]139-clare married [Roland]107-roland . Anything , [he]0-i thought , rather than that [she]139-clare should marry [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff . [He]0-i passed [the limits of [the garden]292-the garden]2466-the limits of the garden and strolled down [the road]3300-the road , deep in thought . It was only when [he]0-i had nearly reached [the mill]2936-the mill that [he]0-i remembered with a start that [he]0-i had told [[his]0-i brother]2917-his brother nothing about [John Hatfield]135-john hatfield and [his]135-john hatfield revengeful projects . However , [Roland]107-roland could come to no harm now — [he]107-roland was probably safe in bed — and [he]107-roland could tell [him]2917-his brother in the morning . So [he]0-i strolled on , smoking reflectively , and with a heart not light . [JOHN HATFIELD]135-john hatfield had left [Dartford]78-dartford , [[his]135-john hatfield wife]522-his wife , and [his]135-john hatfield work , driven by an impulse as vague as it was irresistible . [He]0-i did not know what [he]0-i meant to do ; [his]0-i one idea was that [he]0-i must face [[his]0-i daughter 's betrayer]2472-his daughter 's betrayer , and tax [him]135-john hatfield with [his]135-john hatfield crime . [He]0-i did not very much care what came after . But the long tramp through [England]15-england , broken though it was by many a lift from good - natured waggoners , had given [him]0-i time for thinking . Reflection did not soften [his]0-i resentment . On the contrary , the more [he]0-i thought , the harder [his]0-i heart felt , and each new hour of solitary musing left [him]0-i more bitter , more vindictive , more angered than [he]0-i had been the hour before . [[His]0-i wife]522-his wife 's story convicted [him]0-i of the one fault from which [he]0-i had always believed [himself]0-i to be free — blind stupidity . The loss of [[his]0-i daughter]382-his daughter had never been out of [his]0-i mind for half an hour at a time since [she]382-his daughter had gone away , and [he]0-i had thought and thought , till [his]0-i brain had seemed to spin round , over every least detail of [her]382-his daughter flight , and of the time just before it , in the hope of finding out who was [[her]382-his daughter betrayer]2475-her betrayer . And yet in all [his]0-i thinking [he]0-i had never come anywhere near the truth . [Other people]381-other people had , though ; [he]0-i knew that , as [he]0-i remembered hints [he]0-i had sneered at from [some of the least brilliant of the hands]2477-some of the least brilliant of the hands — fools [he]0-i had often called [them]2477-some of the least brilliant of the hands . Yet , [fools]1980-fools as [they]1980-fools were , [they]1980-fools had been able to see more clearly than [he]0-i , [the father , whose brain sharpest love and sorrow ought surely to have had power to quicken]2479-the father , whose brain sharpest love and sorrow ought surely to have had power to quicken . Added to all this , the thought that [he]0-i had gone on working for , taking the money of , and , to a certain extent , living in a condition of dependence on , [the man who had wronged [him]0-i , and then had turned [him]0-i out on to [the world]2867-the world]2480-the man who had wronged him , and then had turned him out on to the world , stung [his]0-i spirit almost to madness . The spring woke early that year , and the weather was bright and glad , the air clear and sweet and joyous with a thousand bird - voices . [The Midland woods]2482-the midland woods and hedges that [he]0-i passed were beginning to deck [themselves]2482-the midland woods in the fresh greenness of [their]2482-the midland woods new spring garments . [Their]2482-the midland woods beauty brought no peace to [him]0-i . [He]0-i but noticed [them]2482-the midland woods to curse [their]2482-the midland woods monotony and apparent endlessness . The only things [he]0-i did notice with anything like satisfaction were the milestones and fingerposts , which told [him]0-i that so much more ground had been got over . [He]0-i put up at night at [the cheapest and poorest - looking inns [he]0-i could find]2483-the cheapest and poorest - looking inns he could find . [They]2483-the cheapest and poorest - looking inns he could find were good enough to lie awake in , for [his]0-i feverish longing and impatience to reach [his]0-i end almost consumed [him]0-i and made sleep an impossibility . Eager as [he]0-i was to get on , [he]0-i had self - restraint enough to spend none of [his]0-i store of money — such a little store as it was — on travelling . [Roland Ferrier]107-roland might not be at [Thornsett]30-thornsett after all , and [he]0-i might have to follow [him]0-i , or mayhap return to [Dartford]78-dartford and bide [his]0-i time ; and so , though [his]0-i progress was straight and steady it was slow , and [he]0-i did not reach [Thornsett]30-thornsett until the night that had witnessed the explanations between [the brothers]356-the brothers . [He]0-i had done more than twenty - five miles that day , and [he]0-i was footsore and tired out when , as night was falling , [he]0-i reached the top of [the hill at whose foot]2485-the hill at whose foot lay [the village which had been [[his]0-i home]3710-his home for thirty years]2486-the village which had been his home for thirty years . All along [he]0-i had been determined to make straight for [Thornsett Edge]1-thornsett edge , and to confront [Roland]107-roland at once . [He]0-i felt that [the young man]2891-the young man might be surprised into more admissions than [he]0-i would choose to make if [he]0-i were prepared . But physical fatigue is wonderfully effective in upsetting mental decision . [Hatfield]135-john hatfield felt that neither in body nor in mind was [he]0-i fit to go through at once with the part [he]0-i had chosen . [He]0-i must rest — sleep , if possible . [He]0-i threw [himself]0-i down on the heather by [the pathside]2489-the pathside , and leaned [his]0-i head on [his]0-i arm , while [he]0-i debated what to do . Nature decided for [him]0-i , and [he]0-i fell asleep . When [he]0-i woke , a young moon was shining coldly down upon [him]0-i . [He]0-i felt stiff , and not rested . The heather was wet with night - dew . How late was it ? [He]0-i thought by the moon about eight o'clock . [He]0-i would go down to [the village]3667-the village and see who was left in [the old place]2491-the old place ; perhaps [he]0-i might get a lodging [there]2994-there . [The Spotted Cow]3933-the spotted cow was closed , [he]0-i had heard . [He]0-i limped down [the steep stony street]2494-the steep stony street . There were no lights to be seen . As [he]0-i reached [the house that had been [his]0-i]2495-the house that had been his , [he]0-i saw that [it]2495-the house that had been his was empty , and a longing came over [him]0-i to get inside [it]2495-the house that had been his . Why not sleep [there]2994-there ? So , turning aside , [he]0-i went up [the three stone steps]2497-the three stone steps and along [the narrow paved pathway that ran under the windows separating [the house]291-the house from [the tiny front garden]2500-the tiny front garden]2498-the narrow paved pathway that ran under the windows separating the house from the tiny front garden . [His]0-i hand fell on the latch of the door quite naturally , and it never occurred to [him]0-i that it would not yield to [his]0-i touch as it had been wo nt to do . But it did not yield . [He]0-i was in that frame of mind when any resistance is intolerable . [He]0-i drew back and then threw [himself]0-i against the door with all [his]0-i weight . It gave way noisily and [he]0-i went in . [He]0-i passed round the wooden screen , and stood in the middle of the flagged floor . To return to [a house where [we]2502-we have been happy , even if [we]2502-we have left [it]2501-a house where we have been happy , even if we have left it for greater happiness for greater happiness]2501-a house where we have been happy , even if we have left it for greater happiness , is always sad if not painful ; but to go back to [a house that seems to hold within [its]291-the house desolate walls]2503-a house that seems to hold within its desolate walls , not only all [our]2502-we memories but all [our]2502-we possibilities of happiness — when [we]2502-we have left [it]291-the house in sorrow , to take back to [it]291-the house an added load of new , unexpected , intolerable trouble — this , let [us]2502-we be thankful , is not given to [many of [us]2502-we]871-many of us . [John Hatfield]135-john hatfield could not bear it . [He]0-i cast one look round at the dark , fireless hearth , the uncurtained window , turned , and came out . Sleep [there]2994-there ? [He]0-i would rather sleep on [the bare hillside]2506-the bare hillside , or in [the churchyard]2507-the churchyard itself , for that matter . The rush of memories drove [him]0-i before it . [He]0-i could not stay in [the village]3667-the village . [Every other house in [it]3667-the village]2509-every other house in it had been [a home]2510-a home too , and was crowded with recollections almost as maddening as those that peopled [[his]0-i own home]2511-his own home , in which — bitterest thought of all — [Roland Ferrier]107-roland had lisped out childish prattle , and climbed on [his]107-roland knee to share [his]107-roland caresses with [baby Alice]134-alice . And at the remembrance [his]0-i resolution came back . [He]0-i would go to [Thornsett Edge]1-thornsett edge then and there , let come what might . Weak as [he]0-i was , [he]0-i was strong enough to make [his]0-i tired feet carry [him]0-i so far , and once there [his]0-i passion could be trusted to give [him]0-i strength to say and do all that needed to be said and done . [He]0-i clenched [his]0-i nerves , as though the pain of [his]0-i bruised feet would grow less by being despised , and [he]0-i walked on . But when [he]0-i reached the turn in [the road]3300-the road that brought [the mill]2936-the mill in sight [his]0-i mood altered again , and almost before [he]0-i knew that [his]0-i intention had changed [he]0-i found [himself]0-i limping painfully down the stone steps into [the little hollow]2514-the little hollow . As [he]0-i caught sight of the door where [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff had stood on the night of the fire [he]0-i muttered a curse on [the man who had stood between the ' hands '[0-i] and [their]2516-their purpose that night]2515-the man who had stood between the ' hands ' and their purpose that night . [He]0-i felt faint and giddy . The many square windows of [the mill]2936-the mill seemed to look on [him]0-i like eyes , and the broken panes in them lent them a sinister expression . The few past months had changed the face of [the mill]2936-the mill wonderfully . [No one]494-no one had repaired the damage done by [the rioters]2090-the rioters , and the wind and rain had had [their]2516-their will of [the place]936-the place . [It]936-the place looked now , [Hatfield]134-alice thought , as though [it]936-the place had been deserted for years instead of months . Everything was deadly still . The only sounds were the trickling of [the stream]2522-the stream as it flowed past , and [his]0-i own heavy breathing . [He]0-i was becoming unaccountably sleepy . Why should [he]0-i not sleep [here]2895-here ? [He]0-i would go on to [Thornsett]30-thornsett in the morning . [He]0-i stumbled downward till [he]0-i reached the wall of [the mill]2936-the mill . [He]0-i soon found a window that could be unfastened by passing [his]0-i hand through one of its broken panes and turning round the primitive hasp . It was rusty , and moved , as it were , reluctantly . Still , it did move , and [he]0-i opened the window and crept through it . [He]0-i found [himself]0-i on the edge of a huge stone tank , or vat . One more forward movement and [he]0-i would have been plunged in the dark - looking water that half filled it . [He]0-i shuddered . How could [he]0-i have been such a fool as to forget the position of that tank ? [He]0-i crept round the edge of it , and reached the stone - paved floor of [the basement]2525-the basement . There lay a mass of something dark . It was the great stone that had thundered through the roof of [the mill]2936-the mill just after [young Roland Ferrier]107-roland had given [the deputation]1922-the deputation [their]1922-the deputation answer . [Hatfield]134-alice looked up at the ugly hole in the ceiling , a hole that repeated itself in the two upper floors and the roof , through which [he]0-i could see the sky . The moon was shining brightly by this time , and [the many - windowed building]2528-the many - windowed building was lighted well enough for [the man]3262-the man to find [his]3262-the man way about . Had it been dark , [he]0-i thought [he]0-i should not have had much difficulty . [He]0-i went up [the stairs]369-the stairs , and made [his]0-i way to [a room on [the second storey]2532-the second storey , where [he]0-i fancied there would be some soft rubbish [he]0-i could lie down on]2531-a room on the second storey , where he fancied there would be some soft rubbish he could lie down on . [He]0-i was not disappointed , and , yielding to the utter weariness that had come to [him]0-i , [he]0-i lay down , and in a moment slept . [He]0-i had not been asleep three minutes when [he]0-i awoke with a start to find [himself]0-i sitting up and listening . What had [he]0-i heard ? The click of a door and a footstep . [He]0-i was widely , nervously , intensely awake now . Had it been fancy , born of the utter desolation and loneliness of [the place where [he]0-i was]2533-the place where he was ? [He]0-i listened strainedly . No . This at least was no fancy . There was a footstep resounding hollowly through [the great empty rooms]2534-the great empty rooms . [Some watcher]2535-some watcher , perhaps , from whom [he]0-i ought to keep [himself]0-i hidden if [he]0-i did not want to be handed over to [the constable]2536-the constable as [a vagrant]2537-a vagrant . What an ending , that , to [his]0-i journey ! Yes , [he]0-i must lie quiet , and yet , how could [he]0-i ? Suppose — and at the thought [his]0-i blood ran coldly through [his]0-i veins — suppose [old Richard Ferrier]130-richard had got up from under that white stone in [Thornsett churchyard]126-thornsett , and had come down to keep watch over what [[his]130-richard sons]2875-his sons had so little regarded . The footsteps came nearer , and [Hatfield]134-alice sprang to [his]0-i feet and walked not away from , but towards , the sound . The impulse of [a naturally brave man]2539-a naturally brave man when [he]2539-a naturally brave man is frightened is to face the fearsome thing as speedily as may be . [Hatfield]134-alice opened the door . Then [he]0-i sprang forward , for [he]0-i saw [no ghost]2540-no ghost , but , as it seemed to [him]0-i , the object of [his]0-i search — not [old Richard]130-richard , but [young Roland]107-roland , standing with [his]107-roland back to [him]0-i . The bright moonlight lighting up [the figure]2541-the figure left no room in [his]0-i mind for a doubt . At the sight , all [his]0-i ideas of asking for explanation vanished in an instant , and left [him]0-i with no impulse but to catch [the young man]2891-the young man by the throat and to squeeze the life out of [him]2891-the young man . As [the other]305-the other turned at the sound of the opening door [he]0-i gave a cry of horror at the sight of the wild , haggard figure springing at [him]0-i — the white , angry , maddened face close to [his]0-i own . ' Keep back ! '[0-i] [he]0-i almost screamed , as [Hatfield]134-alice rushed upon [him]2891-the young man , but even as [he]0-i spoke [the man]3262-the man 's hands fastened on [his]3262-the man throat , and [the two]2933-the two closed in a silent , deadly struggle . [They]2933-the two had hardly grasped [each other]2934-each other when [both]2937-both remembered the danger that lay behind [them]2933-the two — that black gap in the floor — and [each]2273-each tried to edge away from it without loosening [his]2273-each hold . Too late , though . The strain of [the strong men]2549-the strong men wrestling was too much for the splintered boards already rotted through by the rain and snow of the past months . Crash went the flooring beneath [their]2933-the two feet , and as [the two]2933-the two went through , fast locked in [each other]2934-each other 's arms , [Hatfield]134-alice , above [[his]0-i adversary]2552-his adversary , saw , in a flash of intensest horror , that the face below [him]0-i was not that of [Roland]107-roland , but of [Richard]130-richard . It was the last thing [he]0-i ever saw in [this world]668-this world . In another moment [he]3262-the man was lying , [a dead man]2554-a dead man , at the bottom of the great tank . Again the stillness of [the empty mill]2555-the empty mill was undisturbed , and the only movement in [it]2555-the empty mill was that of the heavy - coloured water as it settled down again into stagnation over [him]3262-the man . [Roland]107-roland went to bed that night without troubling [himself]107-roland much about [[his]107-roland brother]2917-his brother . [He]107-roland had been deeply wronged , and [he]107-roland was [a man who , not easily offended , was , when once alienated , implacable . [He]107-roland did not find it easy to forgive . Though [he]107-roland had shaken hands with [[his]107-roland brother]2917-his brother]2557-a man who , not easily offended , was , when once alienated , implacable . he did not find it easy to forgive . though he had shaken hands with his brother [he]107-roland had not forgiven [him]2917-his brother , and [he]107-roland came down to breakfast the next morning quite prepared to keep up [his]107-roland rôle of injured innocence , and to prevent [[his]107-roland brother]2917-his brother from experiencing much satisfaction in the reconciliation . [Richard]130-richard had always been [an early riser]2560-an early riser , and [Roland]107-roland quite expected to find [him]130-richard in [the dining - room]1444-the dining - room waiting , but [he]130-richard was not [there]2994-there . [He]107-roland waited some little time , and then desired [Mrs Brock]268-mrs brock to see if [Mr Ferrier]107-roland was in [[his]107-roland room]3391-his room , and it was not till [she]268-mrs brock returned with the intelligence that [he]107-roland was not and that [his]107-roland bed had not been slept in , that [Roland]107-roland began to wonder in anxious earnest where [[his]107-roland brother]2917-his brother could be . A very short search showed that [he]107-roland was not in [the house]291-the house or [grounds]2566-grounds . Could [he]107-roland have gone to [the churchyard]2507-the churchyard ? No , thought [Roland]107-roland ; [Dick]106-dick was n't [that sort of fellow]2568-that sort of fellow . Perhaps [he]107-roland had gone over to [Gates]266-gates , and had stayed all night . In a very short time [Roland]107-roland was at [The Hollies]83-the hollies questioning eagerly , and , with an inexplicable feeling of dread and anxiety growing stronger upon [him]107-roland with each moment , [he]107-roland learned that [Dick]106-dick had not been [there]2994-there . [He]107-roland would go down to [the village]3667-the village , and [Mr Gates]114-gates volunteered to come with [him]107-roland , though [he]114-gates laughed cheerfully at the idea of there being anything to worry about in [Dick]106-dick 's non - appearance . ' [He]106-dick 's playing off some trick on [you]114-gates , '[114-gates] [he]114-gates said . ' However , come along , and [we]2571-they 'll soon find [him]106-dick . '[114-gates] So [they]2571-they walked together towards [the village]3667-the village . ' Hullo , '[114-gates] said [Mr Gates]114-gates , as [they]2571-they passed [the mill]2936-the mill , ' that door 's no business open ! Perhaps [Dick]106-dick 's up to some games in there . '[114-gates] The door [he]114-gates pointed at was one opening from [the mill]2936-the mill on to [a flight of stone steps that ran sideways outside [the building]2576-the building from [the second storey]2532-the second storey to the ground]2575-a flight of stone steps that ran sideways outside the building from the second storey to the ground . ' Whether [he]106-dick 's there or not , '[2931-the lawyer] [the lawyer]2931-the lawyer went on , ' [some one]4364-some one has been [there]2994-there , and [we]2571-they 'd better see who it is . '[2931-the lawyer] So [they]2571-they went down , and , crossing [the courtyard]1561-the courtyard , between whose stones the grass was springing already , ran up the steps and passed through the open door . [The whole place]2180-the whole place was flooded with the brilliant morning sunlight . [The two]2933-the two made a few steps forward . [They]2571-they saw the hole in the floor , and paused . Then [Roland]107-roland 's heart seemed to stand still , for [he]107-roland saw on the board at the edge of the gap a hat , and [[his]107-roland brother]2917-his brother 's silver - headed walking stick , and [he]107-roland knew what had happened . With an exceeding bitter cry [he]107-roland turned from [Gates]114-gates and sprang down [an inner staircase]2583-an inner staircase , glancing at [each floor]2584-each floor as [he]107-roland passed [it]2583-an inner staircase , and on the stones at the bottom [he]107-roland found what [he]107-roland sought — [Dick]106-dick . Or was it [Dick]106-dick ? Could [this mangled , twisted , bloody mass]2585-this mangled , twisted , bloody mass be [[his]107-roland brother]2917-his brother ? The pitiless light came through the cobwebbed windows , and showed plainly enough that it was [Dick]106-dick , or [Dick]106-dick 's body . ' Run for [Bailey]239-doctor bailey , '[107-roland] [he]107-roland shouted to [Gates]114-gates , who had followed [him]107-roland ; and [he]107-roland went . Then [Roland]107-roland lifted [Richard]130-richard 's head . Was [he]130-richard alive ? Yes . At the movement a spasm of agony contracted [his]107-roland face , and [his]107-roland eyes opened . ' Do n't move [me]107-roland , [old man]2443-old man , '[107-roland] [he]107-roland whispered ; and [the other]305-the other knelt beside [him]107-roland , [his]305-the other arms under the poor head . [He]107-roland could not speak , for [he]107-roland saw that [[his]107-roland brother]2917-his brother was dying . After a moment [Richard]130-richard spoke again , very faintly . ' [I]130-richard 'm[130-richard] glad [you]107-roland 've come . ' [He]130-richard could only say a few words at a time , and between the sentences came long pauses , in each of which [Roland]107-roland fancied the last silence had come . '[130-richard] [I]0-i wanted [you]107-roland , [old fellow]2591-old fellow . It 's nearly over now . It 's been like hell lying here . [I]0-i know [he]2917-his brother 's somewhere near , and [I]0-i could n't help [him]2917-his brother . It was [Hatfield]134-alice , and [he]2917-his brother mistook [me]0-i for [you]107-roland . [He]107-roland had drunk of the Nepenthe of Death . [THE [Clare Stanley]139-clare who studied [Bakounin]139-clare and quoted [Matthew Arnold]139-clare]139-clare was [a very different girl from [the Clare Stanley]139-clare who had in the autumn entertained the reprehensible idea of bringing to [her]139-clare feet the interesting stranger at [[Morley]118-morley 's Hotel]417-morley 's hotel]4372-a very different girl from the clare stanley who had in the autumn entertained the reprehensible idea of bringing to her feet the interesting stranger at morley 's hotel . In looking back on that time , which [she]139-clare did with hot cheeks and uncomfortable self - condemnation , it really seemed to [her]139-clare that [she]139-clare had changed into another being — development , when it is rapid , being always bewildering . It would be interesting to know with what emotions the rose remembers being a green bud . Pleasanter ones perhaps than those of [the woman whose new earnest sense of the intense seriousness of life]4374-the woman whose new earnest sense of the intense seriousness of life leads [her]139-clare to look back — not with indulgent eyes — on the follies of [her]139-clare unawakened girlhood . The story of [the sleeping beauty]4375-the sleeping beauty is an allegory with a very real meaning . [Every woman]4376-every woman 's mind has its time of slumber , when the creed of the day is truth and the convention of the day is morality . [The fairy prince]4377-the fairy prince 's awakening kiss may come in the pages of a book , in the words of [a speaker]4378-a speaker , through love , through suffering , through sorrow , through a thousand things glad or sad , and to some it never comes , and that is the saddest thing of all . [Clare]139-clare had slept , and now was well awake , and it was no word of [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's that had broken the slumbrous spell . Sometimes [she]139-clare almost wished it had been , for [she]139-clare could not conceal from [herself]139-clare the fact that [she]139-clare had succeeded in doing what [she]139-clare had desired to do , and that [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff was at [her]139-clare feet . The position became [him]121-litvinoff , certainly , but [she]139-clare felt a perverse objection to being placed on a pedestal , and a new conviction that [she]139-clare would rather look up to [a lover]4379-a lover than down at one . And yet why should [she]139-clare look down on [him]121-litvinoff ? [He]121-litvinoff was cleverer than [she]139-clare , with a larger knowledge of life — had done incomparably more for the cause [she]139-clare had espoused . [He]121-litvinoff was brave , handsome , and , to some extent , [a martyr]4380-a martyr , and [he]121-litvinoff loved [her]139-clare , or [she]139-clare thought so , which came to the same thing . Verily , [a man with all these qualifications]4381-a man with all these qualifications was hardly the sort of lover for [a girl under the twenties to look down upon]4382-a girl under the twenties to look down upon . But could [she]139-clare help looking down on [him]121-litvinoff , for was [he]121-litvinoff not at [her]139-clare feet ? And that was not the place , [she]139-clare thought , for [a man who had drawn the sword in such a war as [she]139-clare and [he]121-litvinoff had entered upon]4383-a man who had drawn the sword in such a war as she and he had entered upon . What right had [a man who had taken up arms in that cause to lay them down]4384-a man who had taken up arms in that cause to lay them down , even at [her]139-clare feet ? No , no . [[Her]139-clare lover]3539-her lover , if [she]139-clare had one , must be at [her]139-clare side — not there . This reaction to [the Count]3057-the count 's detriment had set in on New Year 's Day , when [he]121-litvinoff had told [her]139-clare that [he]121-litvinoff held no cause sacred enough to give [her]139-clare even inconvenience for the sake of it , and the tide was still ebbing . [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff appeared quite unconscious of that fact though , for [he]121-litvinoff continued to call on [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid with a persistence which quite justified all [Cora]236-cora 's animadversions . [Miss Quaid]254-miss quaid 's penetration was at fault , but [the Count]3057-the count 's was not . [He]121-litvinoff was perfectly conscious of the change in [her]139-clare state of mind , and knew that [his]121-litvinoff chance of being [master of the Stanley money - bags]4388-master of the stanley money - bags was far less than [he]121-litvinoff had thought shortly after [[their]4389-their late master]4390-their late master 's death . [Suspense]270-suspense was the one thing [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff could not bear — at least , [he]121-litvinoff could bear it when the balance of probabilities was in [his]121-litvinoff favour ; but when the chances did not seem to be on [his]121-litvinoff side — no . [He]121-litvinoff knew perfectly well that it is hardly '[139-clare] correct ' to ask [a girl]3064-a girl to marry one three months after [[her]3064-a girl father]391-her father 's death ; but [he]121-litvinoff was not [an enthusiastic devotee of '[2443-old man] correctness]4393-an enthusiastic devotee of ' correctness . ' [He]121-litvinoff habitually posed as [a despiser of conventions]4394-a despiser of conventions , and this attitude very often stood [him]121-litvinoff in good stead , even with [people who preferred the stereotyped rôles of life for [themselves]4395-people who preferred the stereotyped rôles of life for themselves]4395-people who preferred the stereotyped rôles of life for themselves . Avowed unconventionality serves as a splendid excuse for doing all sorts of pleasant things which [conventional people]4396-conventional people dare n't do ; hence perhaps its growing popularity . '[2598-his] [He]2598-his either fears [his]2598-his fate too much , Or [his]2598-his deserts are small , Who dares not put it to the touch , To gain or lose it all . ' The lines ran in [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's head persistently one spring morning while [he]121-litvinoff sat at [his]121-litvinoff late breakfast . '[2598-his] It really is time [I]0-i struck for fortune . [I]0-i do hope this is not a bill , ' [he]0-i said to [himself]0-i as [he]0-i took it . ' '[2600-the mysterious stranger] [The mysterious stranger]2600-the mysterious stranger does n't waste [his]2600-the mysterious stranger words . [He]2600-the mysterious stranger 's almost as careful of [them]2599-they as [the fellow with the dirty collar — Bursch]2601-the fellow with the dirty collar — bursch , or [Kirsch]271-kirsch , or [Hirsch]222-hirsch , or whatever it was . The best of being mixed up with [the revolutionary party]2602-the revolutionary party is that such beautifully unexpected things are always befalling one . [I]0-i wonder why [he]2600-the mysterious stranger could n't have waited till to - morrow night . It lends a spice to an important matter to discuss it at forbidden times and in a secret manner at [the houses of [friends]2905-friends]2603-the houses of friends . That 's another of [our]2605-we characteristics — to plot when [we]2605-we 're supposed to be talking frivol only , and to play cards or go to sleep when [we]2605-we 're[2606-the distressed lady friend] supposed to be plotting . Wonder what the important matter is . [The distressed lady friend]2606-the distressed lady friend again , perhaps . Well , before [I]0-i commit [myself]0-i on that matter , [I]0-i 'd better settle things one way or the other with [la belle Clare]139-clare . Upon [my]0-i soul , [I]0-i do n't much care which way they are settled . If [I]0-i 'm not to shine as [the county magnate]4398-the county magnate and [the married man]4399-the married man at [Aspinshaw]105-aspinshaw , by Heaven , [I]0-i 'll find out [[my]0-i own little girl]4400-my own little girl , and go in for virtuous retirement in [the Quartier Latin]89-the quartier latin . '[0-i] [He]0-i pushed [his]0-i chair back , and sat biting [his]0-i moustache irresolutely , and frowning heavily at the breakfast - table . ' Yes , '[0-i] [he]0-i said at last , rising ; ' [I]0-i 'll have a shot for it now , as [I]0-i 've gone so far , and [I]0-i 'll shoot as straight and as steady as [I]0-i can . [He]0-i seemed satisfied , lighted the inevitable cigarette , and half an hour after noon was in [[Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid 's library]2607-mrs quaid 's library , alone with [Clare Stanley]139-clare . [Mrs Quaid]201-mrs quaid , [he]0-i had known , would be absent on some educational errand , and [Cora]236-cora would be at [the National Gallery]46-the national gallery . [He]0-i knew that [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley was not averse to a quiet morning spent in uninterrupted reading and copying , and [he]0-i had rightly thought that [he]0-i should have a very fair chance of finding [her]122-miss stanley alone . The resolution of [his]0-i , which had faltered before the remembrance of that other face , grew strong again as [he]0-i saw [her]122-miss stanley , for [she]122-miss stanley looked charming , and it was not in [his]0-i nature to be indifferent to the charms of [any woman]1009-any woman , even if [she]122-miss stanley were not [the woman]3264-the woman . " ' Somehow [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff did not look delighted . Perhaps [he]0-i wanted to talk about something else . ' Then , as a faint change in [her]122-miss stanley face showed [him]0-i that [he]0-i had made a false move , [he]0-i hastened to add , '[0-i] But it will all happen some day , [you]122-miss stanley know . ' '[2614-you] Oh , no , no , no , ' [she]122-miss stanley said . '[2614-you] Never let [us]2613-us lower [our]2613-us standard . ' Then [she]122-miss stanley looked at [him]0-i , at [his]0-i handsome , insouciant face , at the half - cynical droop of [his]0-i mouth , at the look in [his]0-i eyes — the sort of look [an old cardinal who knew [the Church]74-the church and [the world]2867-the world might turn on [an enthusiastic young monk]4407-an enthusiastic young monk]4405-an old cardinal who knew the church and the world might turn on an enthusiastic young monk — and [she]122-miss stanley felt a sudden regret for that heart - warm speech of [hers]122-miss stanley . [She]122-miss stanley went on , smiling a little , — '[2614-you] [You]2614-you must make allowances for the hopeful faith of [a new convert]2615-a new convert . Perhaps when [I]0-i 've held [my]0-i new belief a little longer [I]0-i shall be less en l'air . But [I]0-i must say [I]0-i hope not . ' '[0-i] [Your]2614-you new beliefs make [you]2614-you very happy , then ? ' '[2616-they] [They]2616-they make [me]0-i want very much to live to see what will happen . It would be terrible to die now before anything is accomplished . [You]2614-you see , [I]0-i ca n't help believing that [we]2617-we shall accomplish something , although [I]0-i know [you]2614-you think [me]0-i very high - flown and absurd . ' '[2614-you] [You]2614-you know [I]0-i think [you]2614-you perfect , ' [he]0-i said , in a very low voice , and went on hurriedly : '[2614-you] But , for [Heaven]242-heaven 's sake , do n't talk about dying ; the idea is too horrible . Ca n't [you]2614-you guess why [I]0-i have seemed not sympathetic with [your]2614-you new religion ? [I]0-i have known what it is to believe strongly , to work unceasingly , never to leave off hoping , and trying to show [others]658-others [my]0-i hope . [I]0-i have known what it is to have no life but the life of [the cause]4076-the cause ; to go through year after year still hoping and striving . [I]0-i have known all this , and more . [I]0-i have known the heart - sickness of waiting for a dawn that never comes . [I]0-i know how [one]504-one may strain every nerve , tax every power , kill [one]504-one 's body , wear out [one]504-one 's brain , break [one]504-one 's heart against the iron of things as they are , and when all is sacrificed , all is gone , all is suffered , have achieved nothing . It is from this [I]0-i would save [you]2614-you . That [you]2614-you should suffer is a worse evil than any [your]2614-you suffering could remedy . [The cause]4076-the cause will have [martyrs]2625-martyrs enough without [you]2614-you . ' '[2625-martyrs] [Martyrs]2625-martyrs , yes ; but how can it have too many [workers]2627-workers ? ' [she]2614-you asked , not looking at [him]0-i . '[2628-a worker] To be [a worker]2628-a worker is to be [a martyr]4380-a martyr , ' [he]0-i answered , rising and standing near [her]2614-you ; '[4380-a martyr] and that is the reason why [you]2614-you are the only convert [I]0-i have never rejoiced over . ' '[0-i] [I]0-i do n't know , ' [she]2614-you was beginning when [he]0-i interrupted [her]2614-you . '[0-i] Do n't say that , ' [he]0-i said . '[0-i] Do n't say [you]2614-you do n't know why [I]0-i ca n't endure the thought of [your]2614-you ever knowing anything but peace and happiness . [You]2614-you know it is because [I]0-i love [you]2614-you , and [my]0-i love for [you]2614-you has eaten up all [my]0-i other loves . Freedom , the Revolution , [[my]0-i country]3176-my country , [my]0-i own ambition , are all nothing to [me]0-i . But if [you]2614-you care for the cause [I]0-i can still work in it , and with a thousand times more enthusiasm than it ever inspired [me]0-i with before , for [you]2614-you . That can be [your]2614-you way of helping it . Use [me]0-i as [your]2614-you instrument . Make any use [you]2614-you will of [me]0-i , if only [you]2614-you are safe and happy , and [mine]0-i . ' [His]0-i voice was low with the passion which for the moment thrilling through [him]0-i made [him]0-i quite believe [his]0-i own words . [Clare]139-clare had listened silently , [her]139-clare eyes cast down , and [her]139-clare nervous fingers diligently tearing an envelope into little bits , and when [he]0-i had ended [she]139-clare still did not speak , but [her]139-clare breath came and went quickly . ' '[0-i] It means that this seems the most terrible thing that could have happened to [me]0-i . That it should be through [me]0-i that [you]2614-you give up the right . ' '[2614-you] But through [you]2614-you , for [you]2614-you , [I]0-i will become anything [you]2614-you choose . '[0-i] No , ' [she]139-clare said steadily , '[0-i] [I]0-i can not love [you]2614-you . [I]0-i am very , very sorry — ' '[0-i] Spare [me]0-i [your]0-i pity , at least , ' [he]2614-you said . '[0-i] But one thing [I]0-i must ask . Why did [you]2614-you let [me]0-i see [you]2614-you again after New Year 's Day ? For [I]0-i told [you]2614-you the same thing then , and [you]2614-you knew then that [I]0-i loved [you]2614-you . ' It was true — but [Clare]139-clare hated [him]2614-you for saying it . '[0-i] [I]0-i have changed so much since then , ' [she]139-clare said slowly . Several things both bitter and true rose to [his]2614-you lips . [He]2614-you did not give them voice , however . [He]2614-you had never in [his]2614-you life said an unkind thing to [a woman]554-a woman . It occurred to [him]2614-you that [he]2614-you was accepting [his]2614-you defeat rather easily , and [he]2614-you looked at [her]139-clare to measure the chances for and against the possible success of another appeal . But in [her]139-clare face was a decision against which [he]2614-you knew there could be no appeal . [He]2614-you felt angry with [her]139-clare for refusing [him]2614-you — angry and unreasonably surprised ; and then , in one of the flashes of light that made it so hard for [him]2614-you to understand [himself]2614-you , [he]2614-you saw that if [she]139-clare was to blame for refusing [his]2614-you love , [he]2614-you was ten thousand times more to blame for having sought [hers]139-clare , and this truth brought [others]658-others with it . ' And the door shut behind [him]2614-you , and [Clare]139-clare was left standing in the middle of [the room]2910-the room with [her]139-clare eyes widely opened , and [her]139-clare hand still outstretched . [She]139-clare stood there till [she]139-clare heard the front door closed , and then sank into a chair . [She]139-clare did n't want to go on making notes about '[2632-a traitor] The Prophetic Vision ' any more . The interview had not been a pleasant one , and it was not pleasant to think over . One of the least pleasant things in [this world]668-this world is a granted wish , granted after it has ceased to be wished . And [Clare]139-clare could not forget that [she]139-clare had desired to win [this man]976-this man 's admiration , at least . [She]2631-she could not forget that [he]2614-you had saved [[her]2631-she father]391-her father 's life — that [he]2614-you had been the first to speak to [her]2631-she of many things once unknown or unconsidered , but now a part of [her]2631-she very life — and [she]2631-she could not forget that when [she]2631-she had first thought of the possibility of [his]2614-you asking [her]2631-she to marry [him]2614-you [she]2631-she had not meant to refuse [him]2614-you . There had been much about [him]2614-you to attract [her]2631-she , and if [she]2631-she had never met [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch [she]2631-she might have given [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , even now , a different answer . But in [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch [she]2631-she found all the qualities that had fascinated [her]2631-she in [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff , and all on a larger scale , and with a finer development . [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff now seemed to [her]2631-she like a dissolving view of [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch seen through the wrong end of a telescope . [He]179-petrovitch lacked the definiteness of outline , the depth of tone , the intense reality of [the other man]4415-the other man . Perhaps [he]179-petrovitch seemed more brilliant and dashing ; but [Hirsch]222-hirsch 's story had shown what [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch was . Added to all this was one significant fact . [She]2631-she had admired in [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff one quality or another , and had desired to attract [him]121-litvinoff . To [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch [she]2631-she [herself]2631-she had been attracted , not by any specific quality or qualities , but by [himself]179-petrovitch — by [the man]3262-the man as [he]179-petrovitch was — and this attraction grew stronger with each meeting . A fortnight had now passed since the second time [she]2631-she had seen [him]179-petrovitch , and somehow or other [she]2631-she had seen [him]179-petrovitch very often in that time . [She]2631-she knew well enough that neither [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff nor [Petrovitch]179-petrovitch had come to [Marlborough Villa]69-marlborough villa to see [its mistress]4417-its mistress . And [she]2631-she had been sufficiently certain about [the Count]3057-the count 's motives for [his]179-petrovitch visit , but could [she]2631-she be certain about the motive which brought [the elder man]1501-the elder man [there]2994-there so constantly ? Of any effort to make [him]179-petrovitch care for [her]2631-she [she]2631-she was not guilty . In [her]2631-she new frame of mind [she]2631-she would have felt any such attempt to be degrading , alike to [herself]2631-she and to [him]179-petrovitch . And though [she]2631-she knew [he]179-petrovitch came to see [her]2631-she , [she]2631-she could not be sure why [he]179-petrovitch came . Was [his]179-petrovitch evident interest in [her]2631-she only the interest of [an apostle]4421-an apostle in [a convert]3688-a convert ? Only , [she]2631-she thought , it would be the highest honour in [the world]2867-the world and the deepest happiness to be [the woman whom [he]179-petrovitch loved]4424-the woman whom he loved . [She]2631-she thought of this without a single thrill of gratified pride . '[238-countess litvinoff] Which was , perhaps , a too hasty conclusion . To [the reader who has followed the fortunes of [Count Litvinoff]121-litvinoff]2637-the reader who has followed the fortunes of count litvinoff so far [we]2638-we need hardly mention the fact that as soon as [he]121-litvinoff was clear of [Marlborough Villa]69-marlborough villa [he]121-litvinoff pulled out [his]121-litvinoff cigar - case . It had always been a favourite theory of [his]121-litvinoff that a cigar and not a [mill - pond]2639-mill - pond was the appropriate sequel to an unsuccessful love affair . Not that it had ever occurred to [him]121-litvinoff as even remotely possible that such an experience could ever be [his]121-litvinoff . Here it was , however , and [he]121-litvinoff had one of those opportunities which always charm [the thinker]2640-the thinker — that of being able to apply to [his]121-litvinoff own case a theory invented for [other people]381-other people . [He]121-litvinoff took a meditative turn round [[Regent]273-regent 's Park]2642-regent 's park . It is a strange fact which [we]2638-we do not remember to have seen commented on by [any other writer]2643-any other writer — that when [a man]2882-a man comes away from an interview with [a girl to whom [he]2882-a man has been making love [he]2882-a man is inevitably driven to think , not of [her]2646-her alone , but also of one , two , three or more of the other girls to whom [he]2882-a man has from time to time made love in the remote or recent past]2645-a girl to whom he has been making love he is inevitably driven to think , not of her alone , but also of one , two , three or more of the other girls to whom he has from time to time made love in the remote or recent past . Such is the depravity of [the ' natural man ']4431-the ' natural man '[121-litvinoff] that these thoughts are not generally sad ones . But [Litvinoff]121-litvinoff 's thoughts were genuinely sad . [He]121-litvinoff had said to [Miss Stanley]122-miss stanley that [he]121-litvinoff was [a traitor]2632-a traitor and [a villain]2633-a villain , and it had not been said for dramatic effect . [He]121-litvinoff meant it . [He]121-litvinoff would have given a good many years of any life that might lie before [him]121-litvinoff to undo a few of the years that lay behind . ' [I]121-litvinoff am not consistent enough for [a villain]2633-a villain , '[121-litvinoff] [he]121-litvinoff said to [himself]121-litvinoff . '[121-litvinoff] After a minute 's hesitation [he]2649-he turned into [the Zoological Gardens]2650-the zoological gardens , where [he]2649-he spent some thought on the wasting of an hour or so among the beasts , incurred the undying hatred of an alligator by stirring [him]2649-he up with the ferule of [his]2649-he stick , irritated [the llama]2651-the llama to the point of expectoration , and grossly insulted [the oldest inhabitant of [the monkey - house]2653-the monkey - house]2652-the oldest inhabitant of the monkey - house .
